SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill seeks to repeal part of the Australian design rule No. 19.01 which deals with electrical connections on motor cycles.

The aim of the Australian design rule which has come into effect as of 1 March 1992 is to force all new motor cycles that are sold from 1 March onwards to have the headlight wired in such a way that when the engine is started the headlight will automatically come on.
We are dealing specifically with clause 19.6.106.9 of the Australian Design Rule No. 19.01 of the Motor Vehicle Standards Bill 1992 which we are moving to have repealed.

The Government seems to have neglected to consult with the users regarding this new regulation. In my experience no one single motor cyclist has been pleased to have this design rule forced upon them.

There has been much research into the pros and cons of having lights wired on. The key point is that when you look for the research evidence, both in Australia and overseas, you find that what is lacking is conclusive evidence that this measure actually adds to road safety. What this means is that the government hastily made this decision without properly researching the issue and has gone ahead without properly consulting those most directly affected.

The decision as to whether to turn on the motor cycle light during the day should be up to the rider. A responsibility, as with other vehicles, that is up to the driver. The majority of cyclists do turn their lights on for part of their day riding but surely experienced riders, who are quite adamant that having the light on can add to the risk, should be allowed to make their own decisions regarding safety.
Apart from the freedom of choice aspect there is the question of legal liability.

It is not clear whether or not this Bill will add to the liability of the motorcyclist who could be involved in a accident with a motor car. The difficulty lies in proving whether or not the light was actually on. The globe may have been smashed in the accident, it may have blown two minutes before the impact, or the day before. Along with the legal liability question there are the ramifications for insurance.

This new design rule could also add a false sense of security. People could believe that by having the light wired on it will somehow make them safer. This, in many cases, could be the exact opposite. Questions arise concerning the ability of some motorists to judge the speed and distance apart of an oncoming vehicle with its headlight on, thus adding to the danger, not to the safety on the roads.
But where this design rule is at its most ridiculous is with agbikes having to have their light wired on.

While I support most vehemently every effort to increase road safety, I believe that this issue of motor cyclists being forced to have their light on is a misguided move by the Minister, further highlighting that this government is out of touch with the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: MUTUAL ASSISTANCE IN BUSINESS REGULATION BILL 1992

In recent times we have seen the rapid internationalisation of financial markets. In practice, geographic and political boundaries are becoming more and more irrelevant to the way in which the world goes about its business.

This trend towards internationalisation has led in turn to world markets becoming increasingly interdependent. Trends in one national market have immediate effects on other markets throughout the world. No better example of this interdependence can be found, Mr President, than in the stockmarket crash of 1987 which spread almost simultaneously through the world's established and emerging securities markets.

This process of internationalisation creates administrative, jurisdictional, detection and enforcement difficulties not only for the international aspects of trading but also for the regulation of domestic markets.
This in turn increases the scope for the pursuit of undesirable market practices across national boundaries and the penetration of domestic markets by undesirable operators.

Integral to the maintenance of investor confidence in, and the efficiency of, national financial markets must be the development of effective international co-operation between the national business regulatory agencies responsible for administering and monitoring those markets. This co-operation involves the capacity to seek from, and provide to, such agencies in other countries flexible, speedy and effective assistance.

This need for increased co-operation and assistance has been recognised in a number of international forums. The International Organisation of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) has called upon its member organisations to provide reciprocal assistance in obtaining information in respect of market oversight and prevention of fraud.

At the Commonwealth Law Ministers meeting in Auckland in 1990, Ministers identified the need for mutual assistance in the area of business regulation. That meeting noted that voluntary co-operation between agencies needed to be reinforced by legislative provisions to enable powers of compulsion to be exercised in the fulfilment of requests in appropriate cases.

Similarly, Mr President, the OECD, in its review of the impact of internationalisation on financial markets, noted the need to achieve world wide regulatory coverage of international conglomerates. The OECD recommended the development of arrangements for exchanges of information between national regulators which supervise different parts of financial conglomerates as one way of ensuring appropriate regulation of these bodies.

In answer to these international calls for closer cooperation, Mr President, this Bill sets up the framework for Australian agencies, such as the Australian Securities Commission and the Trade Practices Commission, to provide assistance to their overseas counterparts. As a result of the legislation, these agencies will be better placed to seek assistance in their own investigations from their foreign counterparts.

In short, Mr President, the proposed legislation would enable prescribed Australian agencies, with the Attorney-General's consent, to compel the provision of information documents and sworn testimony in aid of requests from foreign agencies.

The scheme established by this Bill will complement the obtaining and exchange of information between countries for the purposes of criminal prosecutions which is established by the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act.

Under the proposed scheme for mutual assistance between business regulators applications by the foreign agency will be made to the Australian agency in the first instance which will make an initial assessment of the application and either reject or pass it on to the Attorney-General. In making this initial decision the prescribed agency will take into account amongst other things:
the resource cost to the Australian agency;
the availability of the same information to the foreign agency from other sources;
the likelihood of the Australian agency successfully obtaining the information sought in the application;

the extent to which the foreign agency has corresponding functions and responds to or is likely to respond to a similar request from an Australian agency, including the existence of any memorandum of understanding between the applicant and the prescribed agency relating to mutual assistance.
If the Australian agency does not reject the application the Attorney-General may decide whether to authorise the collection of the information sought by taking the following matters into account:
national interest considerations;
international law and comity including whether the overseas agency has a corresponding facility to provide mutual assistance;

whether the information sought is likely to be used for the purpose of punishing a person for an offence of a political nature or punishing or prejudicing a person on account of a person's race, sex, religion, nationality or political characteristics;

whether the information is sought for the purposes of the administration or enforcement of business regulatory laws as opposed to an investigation of indictable criminal offences such as organised crime (in which case recourse should ordinarily be had to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act).
Where the Attorney-General has authorised the Australian agency to act on a request the agency will be able to require a person to:
provide specified information, evidence or documents relating to the subject of a request contained in the application;
attend before the agency or a member of the agency to provide information on oath or affirmation;
otherwise assist the Australian agency in responding to the request contained in the application.
Mr President, the Bill will also contain extensive safeguards to ensure that persons who are required to provide assistance are appropriately protected.

First, hearings will be held in private, with attendance being limited to persons whose presence is requested by the witness or whose presence is authorised by the Commonwealth agency taking the information and representatives of the foreign regulator. Witnesses will be able to be represented by lawyer or by any other person with relevant expertise such as an accountant or an expert of the law of the requesting agency's country. Witnesses will be eligible to be paid travelling and other expenses.

While self-incrimination will not be a reasonable excuse for failing to answer a request by the Commonwealth agency, self-incriminatory evidence or information (as opposed to documents) will not be able to be used for criminal proceedings against that person. In addition, foreign agencies which request assistance in obtaining information or evidence will be required to provide undertakings that any such evidence provided by a person that incriminates that person, will not be used by that agency in criminal proceedings against that person.

Mr President, the level of protection against self-incrimination which is provided by this Bill corresponds with the level of protection which will be available to persons required to provide assistance to the Australian Securities Commission in its domestic investigations as a result of the amendments contained in the Corporations Legislation (Evidence) Amendment Bill 1992.
Similarly, Mr President, the Bill preserves to an appropriate degree legal professional privilege.

In addition to these safeguards, the provisions of the Privacy Act will continue to apply to Commonwealth agencies when gathering information under this legislation. Persons required to provide assistance will have the benefit of the comprehensive protection in that Act relating to the collection and use of personal information.

Mr President, during 1991 Parliament passed three important Corporations Law measures. A fourth reform Bill has been exposed for public comment earlier this month. This Bill complements those corporate law reforms by ensuring that Australian agencies play an integral role in international business regulation.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMEND MENT BILL (No. 2) 1992
The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 will amend several Acts within the Attorney-General's portfolio.
The Bill contains amendments of a minor policy nature or which correct existing legislation. None of the amendments concern major new policy proposals or sensitive policy issues.

Only the proposed amendments to the Judges' Pensions Act will have any financial impact. The amendments to that Act are expected to have a minor revenue impact, as pensions which would have ceased to be payable will now be payable. It is expected that the number of additional pensions will be small.
The proposed amendments are explained in the Explanatory Memorandum circulated with the Bill.

The Bill contains amendments to the Judges' Pensions Act to provide that surviving spouse pensions will continue to be payable after remarriage. Provision is also made for the reinstatement in certain circumstances of a widow or widower's pension which has ceased to be payable under current law.

The proposed amendment to the Defence Force Discipline Appeals Act 1955 will simplify the process of approving leave of absence for members of the Defence Force Discipline Appeal Tribunal by providing that the Minister, rather than the Governor-General, may approve leave.

The Bill also makes a number of minor amendments to the Family Law Act. It will amend the definition of `order under this Act' in section 112AA. The amendment will make clear that the sanctions available to the Family Court for dealing with breaches of its orders will be available when a person fails to comply with a subpoena.

The Bill will repeal sections 116A and 116B of the Family Law Act which provide for payments to States and Territories for financial assistance in family law matters. These sections were made redundant by new legal aid funding arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories.

The Bill will also amend section 123 of the Family Law Act to update the maximum penalty that may be set for breaches of Family Court Rules. The Rules impose penalties for failure to comply with a summons, for failure to comply with a garnishee order and for making false or misleading statements to the Court. Substantial penalties are required to deter breaches of the Rules.
I table the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we adjourned this matter last night I was in the process of explaining that the arguments which were put in favour of this legislation, namely, that there was a shortage of logs and that this was due to the locking up of forests in national parks and in heritage areas, were demonstrably false. I was reading a quotation from the Resource Assessment Commission, and I will begin that quotation again. The Resource Assessment Commission said:

SPEECH.PARA: An important consequence of the prolonged period of overcutting is an impending shortage in the supply of hardwood sawlogs—
quite clearly identifying the overcutting as the source of the problems. The quotation continues:

This coincides with, and is caused by, the cutting out of most of the unreserved old growth well before significant numbers of regrowth saw logs reach harvestable size. This anticipated outcome is probably the main reason that milling quotas have been reduced progressively in all states. This reduction, rather than the inclusion of timber producing areas in national parks, is the main cause of the dwindling supply of hardwood sawlogs.
The Resource Assessment Commission also rebutted the ridiculous claim, which we heard repeated last night, that access to forest was being impeded by the Australian Heritage Commission. It concluded:

The listing of a place on the Register of the National Estate imposes very few legal restrictions on activities that may be conducted on that place. National Estate listing, for example, does not equate with the declaration of conservation reserve status, nor does it preclude logging in forests.

This is not an earth shattering finding, as anyone who has read the Australian Heritage Commission Act and followed its operation will know. Nevertheless, the truth has not been allowed to get in the way of a good story, and I am sure later on today we will hear that good story, false as it is, repeated endlessly—particularly by the Opposition. We are now debating a Bill which explicitly excludes the Heritage Commission from a continuing role in monitoring projects which have been granted so-called resource security.

PARA.TAB: The National Association of Forest Industries backed up its complaints with a breathtaking claim that $4.8 billion of investment in timber and paper processing projects depended on the passage of this resource security legislation. According to Michelle Grattan, writing in the Age on 8 March last year, Senator Button—not in any way averse to embroidering the truth—claimed that as much as $20 billion of investment in resource processing projects might go ahead. It is hard to believe that Senator Button exceeded the industry's hyperbole by more than 400 per cent, but it seems that he did. In the same article, Senator Richardson was quoted as saying the debate was really about one Tasmanian pulp mill. It has become quite obvious that Senator Richardson was much closer to the truth, but even he has been proved to be optimistic. North Broken Hill has told the Government that passage of this Bill would not guarantee—and I repeat that, would not guarantee—that it would proceed with a pulp mill in northern Tasmania.

In its draft report, the Resource Assessment Commission noted that neither the Association nor any other industry representative had guaranteed that projects would proceed if legislation were enacted, and that representatives of companies involved in the industry had stated that current capital costs and market conditions would prevent immediate investment. In other words, there is no urgency about this legislation at all. The same conclusion was drawn in a memo in October last year by the Deputy Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Sandy Hollway, to Mr Hawke and other Ministers, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The attitude expressed in original responses of industry indicates that investment will not be forthcoming—
I emphasise that—
In that case, proceeding further would involve much pain for no gain.

Contrary to the long and loud howls of the forest industries, the facts of the matter are that, firstly, national parks and reserves are not responsible for the loss of timber resource available for logging; secondly, the Australian Heritage Commission has not posed any significant obstacle to the timber industry; and thirdly, resource security will not produce an investment bonanza.

PARA.TAB: In other words, the pillars on which this Bill rests are mirages. It should never have reached this chamber; it should have remained nothing more than a fantasy in the minds of those who want to wish away the environmental and economic realities of Australia in the 1990s. It is hardly surprising, therefore, that the provisions of this Bill are anathema to ecologically sustainable development, to sensible economic policy, and to sound environmental management. The first stated objective of the Bill is to `identify, and facilitate the protection and conservation of, forest areas of significant environmental, cultural or heritage value'. This is supposedly to be achieved by a comprehensive integrated assessment process that involves consideration of the environmental, cultural, heritage, social and economic impact of the project. In other words, it is already predicated on the idea that there will be some intrusion into those areas.

If one reads the fine print, all that is required is that the Minister `must be satisfied' that an appropriate assessment has been completed. This is a loophole big enough for several large logging trucks to drive right through. If all the Ministers have to do is show that they are satisfied, they have the discretion to simply accredit previous studies as meeting the assessment criteria, whether or not those studies are adequate. If their decision is challenged in the courts, they do not have to show that the assessment was thorough, but merely that they were satisfied that it was appropriate.

This is not merely an academic point because the Tasmanian Government fully expects that the 1.1 million hectares of so-called multiple use forest which it has designated for logging will not be—and I stress `will not be'—subject to further assessment. This was made absolutely clear by the members of the Forests and Forest Industry Council of Tasmania at a recent Democrat seminar on resource security held in Hobart, despite the fact that at least some of those 1.1 million hectares had not been assessed at all—again I stress `had not been assessed'; for example, a large area adjoining the Mount Field National Park. A further 10 per cent of forest was included in the logging zone, against the recommendation of the Parks, Wildlife and Heritage Department that it be nominated for World Heritage listing. The Tasmanian Aboriginal Land Council told our seminar that it had not been—again I stress `had not been'—consulted on resource security by the Federal and State governments. That surely underlines the weakness of that first criterion in the Act, which relates to the surety with which forest areas would be identified to facilitate the protection and conservation of those areas.

Tasmania's attitude guarantees that a Commonwealth-State assessment process would be either a whitewash or a brawl. Given that the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow is alleged to be a world-scale pulp mill, the odds would be heavily in favour of a chlorine bleached whitewash. The irony of this legislation is that a real commitment to up front, integrated and thorough project assessments would negate any need for resource security legislation under which the Commonwealth gives up its environmental powers. This is because a genuine assessment would greatly reduce the chance of environmental surprises springing out of the woodwork and preventing access to certain forest areas once the project is under way. I draw a strong contrast between this legislation and my private member's Bill on threatened species which would see such a comprehensive up-front assessment of areas with management plans put in place before—I stress again `before'—projects would be proposed.

The major reason for the uncertainty which industry complains about is the lack of a comprehensive assessment process. If a thorough survey of the value of a forest area is not conducted before logging is approved, it is inevitable that surprises will result. Far from being the product of environmental laws which are too stringent, uncertainty in resource allocation is a result of laws which are too weak. We simply do not know enough about this nation's ecosystems. The surveys now being conducted are grossly underfunded and will take literally centuries to finish—by which time, as with the painting of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, we will have to start all over again because the Australian environment will have been totally transformed by the greenhouse effect and continuing human plunder.

In this context the Democrats have given their qualified support to the recent agreement between the Heritage Commission and the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management, which was based on a survey of the southern forest region for National Estate values. It is a step—but only a step—in the right direction which makes resource security legislation redundant.

At the recent seminar in Hobart conducted by the Australian Democrats we put this view to members of the Forests and Forest Industry Council of Tasmania, who agreed that our view was logical but that logic would not solve the problem to which resource security had become the only answer. The Democrats reject the view that illogical legislation should be passed simply to appease a section of industry. The main reason why this Bill would be an environmental and economic disaster is that it would entrench the logging of native forests and lock out better alternatives for decades to come.

The problems of the forest industries have not been caused by environmental laws or the environment movement, or even by the overwhelming majority of Australians who oppose native forest logging. They have been caused most of all by economic factors. But the industry has chosen to identify a scapegoat rather than to tackle the real problems. The industry just wants to fight an enemy it thinks it can beat.

The fact is that native forest logging is a dying industry. As the forest economist Judy Clark has documented in detail, it is dying because native forest hardwoods are increasingly being displaced in the sawn timber market by plantation softwoods from Australia, New Zealand and Chile. It is dying because the export woodchip market will soon be dominated by supplies from huge plantations of Australian eucalypts in such countries as Brazil, Chile, Portugal, Spain and South Africa. It is dying because of the woeful incompetence of State forestry commissions who subsidised an uneconomic interest at huge expense to the public purse.

The Resource Assessment Commission's figures show—and I think the Senate needs to have these figures drummed into its collective head—that between 1927 and 1989 the forestry commissions ran up deficits of $4.4 billion, in absolute terms, not adjusted for inflation. To take their relative value, if those debts which were run up in earlier years were adjusted, it would make that figure much higher. These same forestry commissions would have an even greater role in forest management if this Bill were to pass.

No amount of legislation will revive the prospects for native forest logging. What is needed is enough Government wit and vision to move the Australian industry into plantations for its own sake. What is also needed is for the Government to recognise that to encourage investment in large export oriented pulp mills based on chlorine bleaching is to place bets on the survival of dinosaurs. Ecologically sustainable development demands that we move to industrial processes that minimise effluent and resource consumption. The depressed state of the international pulp and paper markets suggests that the most sensible strategy is import replacement based on non-wood fibre.

For the pulp and paper industry, the rational conclusion is to encourage the further development of medium scale pulp and paper plants employing relatively benign chemical processes and using recycled paper, plantation timbers to the extent that one has to phase them out, and non-wood fibre sources as feed stock. Judy Clark has documented numerous investment proposals that meet these criteria, yet the Government and the Opposition have failed to get behind these alternative industries as the best way to eliminate our pulp and paper trade deficit through the 1990s. I recently spoke to canegrowers in northern Queensland who would dearly love to build a kenaf based paper industry from the ground up, provided they could get some government assistance for development purposes. It is these opportunities that the Government should be looking at. It is these opportunities on which the Government has turned its back.
It is worth asking why the Government decided to proceed with a Bill which is so fundamentally misconceived. Several answers suggest themselves.

First, at the time that the decision was made, the Hawke Government had been under attack from a militant and macho industry which was waging a high profile scare campaign, backed up with truck blockades of this very building, in its attempt to water down its environmental obligations. The Government lost its nerve and simply appeased the industry and the ACTU.

Second, the Government felt pressured to send a signal to the business community at large that it could make decisions which—although only window-dressing—would be seen as pro-investment and against the wishes of the environment movement. So Mr Hawke publicly reneged on a pre-election commitment to leaders of the Australian Conservation Foundation that he would not proceed with resource security legislation.

Third, there was a belief within the Labor Party, which has since been exposed as hopelessly optimistic, that the survival of the Field Government depended on Commonwealth resource security legislation being passed.

Fourth, this Government and its bureaucracies have failed to comprehend the constraints imposed by the real world—ecological constraints as well as economic constraints. For all the lip service being paid to ecologically sustainable development, it is a new label on an old bottle as far as this Government and this Opposition are concerned. Rather than heading in an economic direction which offers some hope of future economic viability, the Government is maintaining its charge towards the cliff. This is lemming legislation, a blueprint for economic and ecological suicide.

It is well known that, as Treasurer, Mr Keating was vehemently opposed to this Bill. As Prime Minister, he has given it no support but has instead endorsed the cooperative regional assessment model as an alternative. But rather than withdraw the Bill he has been content to let the Opposition and the Democrats defeat it. That, we would agree with the Opposition, is incredibly cynical. His reasoning appears to be that, had he taken the initiative to scrap the Bill, he would have reopened divisions within Caucus and brought the wrath of industry down on his head. By handing the hatchet to the other parties he has directed the wrath of industry onto the heads of the Opposition.

The Opposition, despite its total lack of understanding of ecologically sustainable development, had—at least until recently—managed to grasp that this legislation is an appalling millstone around the neck of any government. It removes the discretion to exercise judgment in major project approvals by making it compulsory for a government to grant resource security once the conditions have been met. In media statements and in the speech made in the House by the Deputy Leader of the National Party in the second reading debate, the Opposition has advocated project by project resource security instead.

But the Opposition is also engaged in a damage redirection exercise. It does not want to upset the business community and has done a back flip by endorsing amendments drawn up by the National Association of Forest Industries, despite the fact that these amendments do not provide for case by case approvals. If the Opposition is seriously committed to these amendments, it has, in effect, abandoned its opposition to the Bill and will be exposed for its abject inability to hold a principled line in the face of interest group pressure.

However, it is more likely that the Opposition is conducting a publicity stunt aimed at painting the Government as anti-business and blaming it for the demise of this Bill. The Opposition is banking on Caucus preventing the Government from accepting any significant amendments, thus ensuring that the Bill will not pass and the Opposition will not be saddled with it if it wins government at the next election.

No matter what the outcome of this debate, it is blindingly clear that this is a Bill that no party in this chamber really wants. It is the product of woolly thinking and loss of nerve, yet the Australian Democrats are the only party which has had the guts to state its opposition publicly and consistently and stick to its position. The farcical and cynical game being played by the other parties does them no credit.
For the sake of the environment and, I stress, the economy, this legislation deserves the speediest possible demise. The Democrats, therefore, totally oppose this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Forest Conservation and Development Bill, which is better known throughout the community as resource security legislation. As it stands, it represents absolutely nothing other than the attempt of the Hawke and Keating governments to be all things to all people.

PARA.TAB: Having betrayed the resources industry on which Australia's economic survival depends, through the `prevent mining at all costs' decision regarding Coronation Hill, this Labor Government now presents a belated sop to the same industries. It was very disturbing to hear Senator Coulter's contribution a little while ago when he said that for the sake of the environment, and the economy, this Bill must meet its early demise. It is absolutely unbelievable to think that the Democrats can stand in here and honestly profess that they care about the economy or jobs or exports or Australia's income. That matters not to the Australian Democrats. If it did matter to them, they would be trying to make sure that this piece of legislation actually had some substance to it. It is a severely flawed piece of legislation and we have said that to the industry all the way along the line. Of course, the industry has now come out in support of the position that we are taking in trying to make this very seriously flawed piece of legislation somewhat better by amending it at the committee stage.

If Senator Coulter is in any doubt whatsoever, maybe he should have checked his fax machine before he came in here this morning. If he had checked it he would have found out that all the major industry groups are very much in favour of tidying up this legislation. He pays no attention to what the Forestry Protection Society, the Forest Industries Association, the Australian Forest Growers, the New South Wales Forest Products Association Ltd or Slater Contracting Co. Pty Ltd have had to say. Clifton Court Smith Ogilvy and Mather have sent us information on that, as have the Australian Logging Council Ltd, Hardys-Tumbarumba, Ford Timbers, the Pulp and Paper Manufacturers Federation—

TALK.START.PARA: —They have $4 billion worth of public money. No wonder they support it.

—Oh dear, oh dear, he is getting loopier by the day. To continue, the Australian Paper Manufacturers, Kempsey Timbers and NAFI, the whole lot, have come out in support of what we are trying to do. And yet Senator Coulter interjects and says, `Yes, of course, they would be interested because it means money and everything else'. Of course they are interested because the situation will provide jobs. It will provide export income and it will provide income for the rest of Australia. But that is not what the Australian Democrats want. Quite frankly, we are now putting the Government to the test to make sure that that is what it wants as well.

PARA.TAB: This legislation needs amendment. It is for that reason that we will be putting up the 17 amendments in the committee stage and it is also for that reason that we have sought to send it off to the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. That is the committee that will be able to assess the evidence provided by the witnesses who will be affected by this. It will also be able to assess the evidence that has been provided by the States and by the Premiers. All of this is particularly important if we are to turn this country around. Sadly, of course, the Democrats do not want to do it.

There is no security in this Labor Government as it continues to follow the example of Senator Richardson, who made it his business to buy green preferences at the expense of blue-collar jobs. If the electoral equation means short term vote gains for this Government, well and good. Of course, the Democrats are in exactly the same position. They have lost ground, they have no ground, they stand for nothing, other than for a few little trees that might be able to regenerate. They do not worry about the industry at all. They do not worry about the jobs that that industry will generate. We are talking about trying to make some legislation responsible legislation. To this end, the unamended Bill is deliberately framed to give the minimum anxiety to the extreme green lobby which, in spite of its public opposition to anything that appears to assist forest resource industries, can rest easy in the knowledge that this Bill will still enable a Labor government to intervene at any stage of a project. That is not what is desirable. It is not what is needed by the industry and it is not what is needed by Australians.

Indeed, when introducing the Bill last year the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) acknowledged that there may be circumstances where the Government would wish to `take a second look at the way a project with legislated resource security is being conducted'. What does that mean, other than that the Government can and probably will interfere? It is not much use for the Minister to say that such circumstances would be `remote' and `unexpected', as he did. In recent years, through Coronation Hill and through the Tasmanian deal with the Greens, Labor has taught both business and resources employees that it cannot be trusted. That is a simple fact of life. We have seen these deals being done regularly for short term gain in votes, and we know where the Democrats stand in that area.

But nor does it mean much to acknowledge and disclaim the `industry's feeling of uncertainty, engendered by fear of the Commonwealth using its powers to remove significant tracts of forest from productive investments'. That is also a quote from Mr Griffiths. This does not make sense. These fears can only remain and increase when constructive advice from the industry is ignored, and action can be taken under this Bill against approved projects because of `major physical impact' on the environment, an endangered species, or a significant Aboriginal area if such circumstances are `not foreseen'. Who are they trying to bluff? There is enough information, there is enough research, there are enough agencies and so forth prepared to investigate these things long before they are approved. Why, then, should the Labor Party have an override in all cases?

In cold, hard terms we can expect all the Green lobbies to produce all of these unforeseen circumstances once they are determined to stop a project. We are dealing with a profound anti-growth ideology that must on occasion be confronted and denied if we are to have an economic future. It is for that reason that the Australian Democrats must also be confronted and denied on a lot of issues for which they stand. If they were really serious about a lot of these things, they would be supporting our action in trying to amend this legislation. If it is not going to be amended then that is clearly a different story, but to bury their heads in the sand—as they do regularly on other issues, and particularly on this one—is nothing short of a disgrace.

If the Commonwealth does intervene, what does this Bill say about compensation for the resource security that will have been revoked, or about an alternative resource? Without amendment it offers absolutely nothing, and the Democrats are quite happy to go along with that. Clause 23 of the Bill states directly that no compensation is payable when the Commonwealth makes a decision in regard to a project that has resource security.

This Bill also has the major defect of being confined to projects worth $100m, thus providing no recognition or protection for Australia's 1,200 sawmills. It is not particularly convincing for the Minister to refer to Government approval of `a non-legislative form of resource security' for the bulk of the forest industries. The people at the sharp end of these industries know that without legislative backing there is absolutely no security.

Unlike the Government and the Democrats, the Opposition has sought to meet the concerns of the industry and its employees. We are, therefore, moving the 17 amendments to which I referred earlier, and referring this Bill to the Committee to be able to investigate it fully—and, of course, in order to produce legislation that will provide some basic security to the forest industry. We consider that particularly significant, and we certainly hope that by the end of the Committee's inquiry the Government, and even maybe the Democrats, will. I do not hold out much hope, I might add, for the Democrats.

The `no compensation' provision of clause 23 must be removed, and with it a major concern of the industry. A new clause 22A will require the Minister to consider what steps can be taken to give an enterprise access to alternative resources. It is not specific, but it ensures that the principle is recognised, giving investors a very positive signal. It is about time some investors in Australia had some positive signals provided to them by government.

The remainder of our amendments, of course, are directed to including within this Bill accredited State forest industry development plans. Clause 11A couples this with an assurance of modernisation of facilities within the area, an increase in the value of production from the area and the maintenance of plantations—all are very significant amendments. These are sensible, moderate amendments that have the support of the key players in our national industry, led by the National Association of Forest Industries which stated yesterday that `the amendments will make the legislation genuinely workable'. They will provide a basis for investment and long term employment. Why is it that both the Government and the Australian Democrats will not look at the industry position and what it thinks is workable within reasonable bounds?

In particular, I would acknowledge the support of the Forest Industries Federation of Western Australia whose input has been of great, constructive assistance right from the word go. Again, only yesterday that body requested the Premier of Western Australia to intervene in support of these amendments. It is a great shame, of course, that the Labor Government of my State has not shown the same dedication to the forest industry that has been displayed by the Tasmanian Government—the new Tasmanian Government, I might say. It should have been in there battling for our forestry workers a lot earlier in regard to this inadequate Bill so that such a request would be unnecessary.

Once again, members have seen fit to sit on their hands, and not to worry about growth and development in Western Australia. As time goes by, we have more and more examples of Premier Lawrence just doing nothing to make sure that Western Australians can have more jobs, more investment, and more export dollars coming into the State. It is about time, particularly in the light of WA Inc. and all the squandering that has gone on in that State, that they started to produce some export dollars and provide some jobs.

This Labor Government, and of course the Democrats, try to ignore the fact that the lack of sustainable development of forest industries in Australia means that our trade deficit increases by $1.5 billion on timber products. We are importing 63 per cent of writing paper, 44 per cent of newsprint, and 48 per cent of softwood sawn timber requirements. It is a situation that can only deteriorate unless our forest industries know when and where they can get on with the job. But do the Democrats worry about our having a balance of payments problem? Do they worry about jobs? Do they worry about bringing money into the country by sending our products out? No, they could not care less!

It is not only a matter of preserving jobs in the timber industry, or creating new jobs in such areas of high unemployment as Tasmania. It is a national task of fostering export and import replacement industries, and this dimension has been absent from Government actions thus far. The proposed amendments are moved in order to ensure that State forest industry development plans have particular relevance to the future of the industry in Western Australia.

The joint report by the Australian Heritage Commission and the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management was released last month. In general terms, it provides a balance between the needs of conservation and those of the timber industry over 2.5 million hectares of public land. I believe it was unfortunate there was no direct input from the timber industry when the process was commenced in September 1990. As a Western Australian, I would frankly consider that the Department of Conservation and Land Management needed no outside input in establishing sensible rules and procedures with the industry, as were laid down in a 10-year regional management plan of December 1987 that gave resource security while proposing 95,000 hectares of new parks and reserves.

I do regret that the Australian Heritage Commission did not accede to the advice of CALM that listings in the register be confined to the 660,000 hectares of national park, conservation park and nature reserves established by 1987. Nonetheless, with 44 places across all tenure systems considered for listing in the register, and a further 40 sites significant for floral species also considered, we now have an agreement that should satisfy all responsible conservation concerns.
The report makes the very significant statement that National Estate listing can create:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . an undifferentiated perception by the general public that no forests listed in the Register of the National Estate can, or should be logged, regardless of the values for which they are listed.

This perception, it must be added, is deliberately fostered by the hardline environmentalists, who take such listing as an essential focus for protests against the continuation of logging and woodchip exports.

PARA.TAB: The Western Australian forest industries have seen what has happened in Gippsland and in the Eden region of New South Wales, where timber industry resources lost out because of the successful pressure to include National Estate forests as national parks. All too easily the hardline greens can play upon the lack of distinction in the minds of the urban public between National Estate listings and national parks, creating the kind of pressure to which both the Hawke and the Keating governments have always succumbed.

We should equally be very wary of the increasing use of the emotive term `wilderness', which, by definition, once applied to an area excludes all economic and indeed human activity. It involves blanket preservation rather than conservation and is nothing more than a feel-good phrase that may involve a massive economic cost.

Under Labor, the bottom line shows that there is more respect for the people in the koala suits than the people in the hard hats. The Democrats have long since supported that theory and will make sure that anyone in a hard hat is simply pushed out of any region at all.

Instead of rhetoric in the One Nation or `One Job' statement about supposed streamlining of environmental processes to let projects go ahead, why does this Labor Government not prove its credentials by accepting the 17 Opposition amendments that the forest industries have stated are essential to future investment?

If this Labor Government is truly concerned for the future of forest and farming industries in the south-west of my State, or anywhere else for that matter, it must not only enact legislative backing to agreements made with the participation of the Australian Heritage Commission but also review the operations of the Commission itself.

Continued viable agriculture in the south-west of Western Australia is a natural resource, and private farming land should not be subject to AHC listing without a better system of consultations than is being exercised at present. It is not good enough that, of 330 land-holders in the Manjimup area, many received notice of preliminary listing after a public meeting was called by the AHC on 13 February, as letters had been sent out only two days before. That situation is highly unacceptable.

Clearly, the AHC has been forced to recognise the justice of the concerns of south-west landowners by now withdrawing these listings of private land. The question remains, however, of what would have happened if so solid a protest had not been made by those people and many others, and what may happen in the future unless AHC procedures are reformed.

While there was no legal requirement for the AHC to approach land-holders prior to the initial listing, the AHC is now implicitly admitting that its failure to make such approaches was wrong. Thank heaven it is at last admitting it. Hopefully, it will not venture into such a project again.

It may have been well and truly stated that the listing of private land on the Register of the National Estate does not impose legal constraint on the landowner as to the usage and disposal of property, but merely upon the Commonwealth. However, it is not so much the actions of the AHC but those of both the Hawke and Keating Labor governments that make the community profoundly mistrustful of the implications of any such listings.

It is a fact that a potential purchaser of farming land in Manjimup would, all things being equal, prefer to buy land that was not on the Register. The effect of listings on land value should not therefore be ignored.

The reality of the situation is that it is not enough for the AHC to restate that listing involves no legal disability on the landowner. The question is being asked of what future legal constraints may be imposed once property is on a register. It would be wise for the Government and the Democrats to remember that people are not fools when they ask, `Why list land areas if nothing is going to be done?'. That is a very, very good question and it is one that is in the minds of many, many people as the process goes on and on. The responsibility comes back to this Labor Government to provide an unequivocal, legislative assurance that listings of private land in the Register of the National Estate will never involve legislative constraint on private property. If this assurance for the future cannot be given, the AHC should not list private land. So why will the Government not give that assurance? One can only wonder.

This Bill purports to give security to major forest resource projects. The Liberal and National parties cannot support it without the essential amendments we are proposing in support of the National Association of Forest Industries, because it gives no such security.Without genuine resource security, Australia will be inexorably transformed into a very much poorer country—as if we can afford that today!

This Labor Government, as much as dark green extremists, will bear a major responsibility, having put forward legislation that was wilfully ineffective. In effect, the move of the Opposition to amend the Bill gives the Government breathing space to wake up to its responsibilities to the industry and to Australia. We should all remember the golden rule so tragically displayed in other parts of the world that poor countries degrade their own environments. It is about time the Government and the Democrats started to take heed of that fact. I certainly hope that this legislation is amended in the form that we are proposing when it gets to the Committee next week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Forest Conservation and Development Bill, which seems to be otherwise known as the resource security Bill. I would firstly like to make it clear that at present this Bill guarantees no development and no security. Anyone who believes otherwise is being sadly deluded.

PARA.TAB: The Bill will keep intact forever this Government's great anti-development record. There has not been one major industry established in Australia since this Government came into office, and this will ensure that that remains the case. What a record of destruction, of forestry and mining in particular but of industry in general!

At the moment, with the discussion that is going on, if we wish it I have a very easy way out. I could destroy whatever credibility I have and vote for this rubbish, if I wished to. I could be a one-day hero and hoodwink the Tasmanian electors into believing that it would help them if I did. I could lie to those electors and tell them that the Bill is okay. I could at the same time sell out all the small sawmillers in the country towns throughout Australia, the whole 1,200 of them, and any prospect there is of any other development in any of the milling areas of Australia.

I say now that I will not. I am prepared to stand by that. It causes me no concern at all to do what I know is right, namely, to challenge the bona fides of this Government and call on it to accept the NAFI amendments and get the pulp mill project back on the track. That is what we are on about.

The amendments that we are talking about, briefly summarised, would be as follows: to extend the eligibility for resource security to areas involving an investment of under $100m; where resource security is lost because of unforeseen circumstances, to provide access to alternative resources; and to remove the provision of clause 23 of the Bill, in which it is stated that no compensation is payable.

That is what we are talking about. There is no great socialist philosophical jargon involved in this—none at all. If the Government's bona fides are such that it wishes to proceed with this legislation, that is what it takes.

The subject has raised considerable interest, particularly in my State, where the pulp project is the reason for the Bill in the first place. The people of Tasmania are absolutely desperate. After nearly a decade of this Government at a national level destroying the future of Australia and after 2 1/2 years of the most diabolical government combination ever in Tasmania, the situation there is absolutely desperate, and the people of Tasmania reflect that.

As honourable senators might imagine, I am having a lot of calls, a lot of phoning, a lot of writing, a lot of visits from people who say, `Why can you not get this settled? We want legislation to enable the pulp mill to be built'. I say, `I am in exactly the same position. I want legislation that will get the pulp mill built and at the same time preserve the position of the sawmillers and those in the other rural areas of Australia where milling is of importance'.

The amount of misinformation that is being peddled about the country is enormous. We have to bring people back to the truth. The implications of what is going on are not understood. I have not yet found one person who has come to me with a reason for wanting us to support the legislation as it stands who has ever seen or read the Bill. Only by reading the Bill can people see what is wrong with it. It has built up all sorts of hopes on no foundation at all. It is mean, paltry and pathetic for the Government to produce such rotten legislation under the guise of doing something that it is clear it will not do.

We know that the Australian Democrats oppose the Bill. They make no secret of that. Whatever reasons they may cook up do not matter because we know they are opposed to it, and at least they come out and say so. The Government has yet to demonstrate its bona fides for even wanting resource security legislation. As far as the coalition is concerned, we totally support security of resource. It should not be necessary to have legislation to provide one of the absolute, basic fundamentals, but we do need legislation because of the antics of the Government. One has only to look back at the Evans spy flights and the Richardson fiasco over the Wesley Vale mill to realise that.

Every developer is entitled to be given real security. The investors and developers of Australia should be able to insist on its being workable. They should know that their investment is going to be satisfactory. They should not have to wonder whether, if they invest their money, they might lose it all. They should not have to require legislation just to provide security for employment and investment. The coalition supports the NAFI amendments because those amendments would provide that security.

I noticed that the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) even said that there was overwhelming support for the legislation. I do not know where he got his overwhelming support from because it just has not worked out that way. To say that he has overwhelming support is one of the grossest pieces of misstatement that one could imagine. Of all the people who have contacted me who have been aware of the facts, not one has said that he or she would support this legislation as it is proposed, except as a last resort. Two people have said that they would like the legislation passed as it is, as a last resort, if we cannot get it amended.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only two?

—Only two. Of all the people whom I have been in touch with, that is the limit. Against that, I have a little file here of people who have written to the contrary or made suggestions. I will go back as far as 16 October 1991, to a letter which was in response to the letter of 4 October from the then Prime Minister. This project was first produced on 4 October. On 16 October NAFI, the national association representing all the sawmillers and forest users in Australia, made seven points to the then Prime Minister. They read:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Although the Bill is entitled the Forest Conservation and Development Bill it would in fact at best provide for conservation and development of only a section of Australia's native forests.
2. In its current form it does not deliver security for the existing industry. . .
3. The legislation is selective and discriminatory in that it only provides for $100m plus projects.
4. The approval process appears to be largely open ended.
5. The exceptions in the legislation are so all-embracing that our legal advice is that the legislation would deliver only an illusion of security.
6. There is a lack of symmetry and complementarity between the Commonwealth and State approaches to forest policy. . .
7. The draft legislation would lead to a level of involvement by the Commonwealth in industry operations far in excess of that required to ensure ecologically sustainable forest use.
On 17 October, in response to the same letter, the Pulp and Paper Manufacturers Federation of Australia—representing APM, APPM, ANM and all these other major companies—in brief, said:
. . . we find a number of areas of major disagreement with the Bill:
. It does not provide security of wood resource for existing operations. . .
. It does not cover new projects of less than $100 million.
. The proposed legislation has a number of open-ended clauses which relate to unforeseen environmental impact and to the matter of compensation.
. There appears to be an excessive and unnecessary set of regulations as part of the procedures to monitor the forest operations. . .
For these reasons, the Federation cannot support the proposed Bill in its current form . . .
The Queensland Timber Board on 21 October said:
Resource Security legislation, which is underpinned by a $100 million threshold, can have no relevance to the Queensland industry.
In a media release on 18 December NAFI again complained about the non-compensation clauses and the regional exclusions. In a letter to the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, of 21 January, it also said:
. . . we cannot give our full support because it does not give coverage for most of our members.
It went on:

In conclusion, the NAFI attitude toward the current legislation can be summed up as follows: The Association could not provide full national support for the existing legislation but would not oppose its passage if it could provide the basis for a northern Tasmanian pulpmill. If, however, provision was made for the eligibility criteria to include scope to cover State or regional forest assessments, provided they were carried out to Commonwealth standards, and the compensation issue was dealt with satisfactorily, a great deal of public support would be forthcoming from the industry together with a lot more investment and protection of jobs.
On 23 January Timber Investments Management Private Ltd in a letter said:

We have decided not to show any expression of interest at this time as we are not confident that the Australian government will continue to permit the cutting of natural hardwood forests in the longer term.
On 13 February the President of NAFI said to the Prime Minister:

Since the Government's decision in March last year to support resource security for projects over $100m it has become increasingly clear that the bulk of the industry will only be able to achieve its investment goals if the eligibility criteria under the legislation is expanded to encompass regional forest management plans such as those passed by the Parliament of Tasmania, and more recently agreed between the Federal Government and the government of Western Australia.
We therefore urge you to include a commitment to broadening the eligibility of the resource security legislation in your February economic statement to include a regional approach.
And so it goes on again. On 18 February NAFI, in a press release, said:

Twenty-four of Australia's leading forest industry business and union leaders have written to Prime Minister Paul Keating urging the inclusion of regionally-based resource security legislation in the February 26 Economic Statement.

Of course, these included every one of the major paper companies, every one of the major timber companies and many of the leading union people in Australia—and the ACTU. On 19 February, NAFI put out a press statement which said, in part:

PARA.TAB: 1. The current legislation is not supported by NAFI in its current form as it will exclude most of the industry. . .

2. NAFI's policy is for Commonwealth legislation based on a regional approach and the alternative of a non-legislative intergovernmental agreement is not supported; and in addition the `no compensation' clause should be removed from the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Where are all these letters of support? I have not seen them. If people wanted me to support this legislation, I am sure that I would have letters from them. Where are they? What is Mr Griffiths doing to hold these people who would want to support his legislation? I can go on: in a press release dated 29 February, NAFI says:
The Bill should be amended to incorporate the following principles:

PARA.TAB: . . . alternative resource at the same quantity, quality and price;
the `no compensation' clause should be removed from the current legislation.
The $100 million threshold will remain for major projects.

SPEECH.PARA: On 13 February a letter was written from NAFI to the Prime Minister:

. . . jointly urge you to include a commitment for regional resource security. . . the bulk of the industry will only be able to achieve its investment goals if the eligibility criteria under the legislation is expanded to encompass regional forest management plans such as those passed by the parliament of Tasmania. . .
Here we go again—it is supported by all those union people, all those industry people. On 28 February, Pacific Dunlop, not a minor player in this, wrote:

. . . there is a great deal of scepticism that the enhanced intergovernmental agreements to which you have referred many times will provide the necessary security. . . would urge you to recognise the crucial importance to the hardwood sawmilling industry of the amendments sought by NAFI.
Australian Paper Manufacturers, on 28 February, wrote:
I would urge you to consider appropriate amendments as suggested by NAFI.
The Victorian Forest Industries Association, on 2 March, in a letter to Mr Griffiths, wrote:

. . . strongly support a regional approach to the legislation. . . I find it distressing that it has not been possible, so far, to negotiate what seem to be fairly straight forward amendments that would satisfy all industry sectors and gain unanimous industry support.

And that is a fact. This goes for me too: I will give this my absolutely total support and the coalition will give it total support—on the approval of this minor amendment. It is not a major issue. There is nothing in the philosophy of the Labor Party that says that this cannot be done. There is nothing in the new publication, whatever its name is, that says that we cannot do this. It is not contrary to Labor policy in any way. It completely fits in with the statement of the Minister back in March last year. Why has it suddenly become a major obstacle, if the Government's bona fides are not in question? On 5 March, NAFI wrote:

Continuing claims by Government Ministers that the National Association of Forest Industries supports the Forest Conservation and Development Bill in its current form were denied today by NAFI Executive Director, Dr Robert Bain.

Dr Bain described media comments attributed to the Minister for Resources as a `mischievous' attempt to gain political mileage out of a situation where thousands of jobs and billions of dollars in new investments were at stake.
On 1 March 1992 NAFI put out a press statement which said:
NAFI, the ACTU and timber unions and the Federal Opposition are agreed on the amendments that are required to make this legislation broadly workable.
Mr Griffiths, on 5 March, put out a statement that said:
. . . the support for the legislation is overwhelming.
He said:
the ACTU wants it passed.
But the ACTU was one of the signatories I read out who want it amended. He said:
the timber unions want it passed.
No—they too were on that list of people who want it amended. He said:
the National Association of Forest Industries want it passed.

No, I am sorry, I have read out enough of its literature that, I feel sure, would lead the Senate to understand that it is not part of it either. But he does not go on to say where all this overwhelming support is coming from. I can tell him where it is not coming from—even though he has them listed. On 6 March, NAFI put out a statement which said:
NAFI, the ACTU and timber unions and the Federal Opposition are agreed on the amendments. . .
Again, it is still quite right. It continued:
They strongly reaffirmed the position that the current legislation cannot be supported.
On 5 March, Don McFarlane, the President of NAFI, referred to the critical need for this Bill to be amended and passed. He said that reasonable amendments to the Bill could make it workable.

PARA.TAB: Premier Lawrence was put under pressure from the Western Australian Forest Industries Federation. The Federation's press release says:

SPEECH.PARA: The letter to the Premier says that without the amendments, the legislation does not offer long term security or the confidence for industry to invest in projects throughout the south-west.
The Premier of Tasmania, as long ago as 24 March, said in a letter to the Prime Minister:
I urge the Government to support them too—
that is, the amendments he is talking about—
to ensure the industry gets the resource security it needs.
Where is this mountain of support that the Minister claims to have? On 24 March, the Forest Protection Society of New South Wales said the same. The Australian Forest Growers also say:
Australia's . . . tree plantation owners today joined calls for the Federal Government to adopt proposed amendments to its resource security legislation as a matter of urgency.
The Queensland Timber Board's Public Affairs Manager, Christine Bongers, said:
. . . the federal government's Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 was woefully inadequate.
The Forest Protection Society of Western Australia states:
The CALM/AHC agreement on forests will be strongly opposed if industry amendments are not included in Resource Security Legislation to be debated in the Federal Senate tomorrow.
The Forest Protection Society of New South Wales states:

. . . New South Wales FPS members were urging the Government to accept amendments to the Legislation to cover forestry activities in this State, notably the sawmilling sector. Without such amendments, the Legislation will leave New South Wales industry out in the cold.

Does Mr Griffiths worry about the New South Wales industry, or the Western Australian industry, or the Queensland industry, or the tree growers? Not a bit of it. In its press release, Kempsey Timbers Pty Ltd states:
Kempsey Timbers Pty. Ltd. has urged the Commonwealth Parliament to support the industry/union amendment package. . .
Australian Paper Manufacturers states:
Amendments endorsed by the Federal Opposition are supported by APM and would protect jobs in Gippsland now. . .
The Federal Government could accept these amendments without a major change to the intention of the Bill.
Association of Forest Industries in Victoria says:

The Victorian Association of Forest Industries today reaffirmed its support for industry and union amendments to the Forest Conservation and Development Bill (1991), endorsed by the Federal Opposition this week.
The Pulp and Paper Manufacturers Federation of Australia says:

`. . . the organisation which represents the major pulp and paper companies supports amendments for regional resource security supporting smaller sawmill investment, however, there is both a principle and a practicality at stake here', Mr La Fontaine said.
In a press release, Ford Timbers states:
Ford Timbers, today urged Federal Parliament to approve amendments to its controversial Resource Security Legislation to ensure that the future of the forest industry is secured.
Hardys Tumbarumba said:
Hardys urge all sides of Federal Parliament to adopt the industry/Union amendments to the Federal Resources Security Legislation.
In a press release, the Australian Logging Council Limited says that it is:

. . . calling for the successful passage of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill in the Federal Parliament today. . . Passage of this legislation, incorporating the NAFI amendments, will protect working class Australians and at the same time provide a real boost to our economy.
A letter from Clifton Court Smith Ogilvy and Mather states:

If the amendments developed both by industry and the Unions—amendments which we believe are quite reasonable—to cover all eligible development plans are not put and passed in the Senate tomorrow, so much will have been achieved for so little.
Slater Contracting Co. Pty Ltd, Logging and Earthmoving Contractors, states:
We urge you to accept the amendments to the above legislation, as supported by the timber industry and unions.
The New South Wales Forest Products Association Ltd states:
The NSW forest industries today issued a call to all members of the Federal Senate to support amendments to the resource security legislation currently before it.
NAFI, as of 24 March, states:

Mounting support for joint industry and trade union Senate amendments to the Forest Conservation and Development Bill (1991) could not be ignored by the Keating Government, the Executive Director of the National Association of Forest Industries, Dr Robert Bain, said today.
"The amendments will make the legislation genuinely workable," he said.

I am sorry that I could not produce something to give Mr Griffiths some heart that he had overwhelming support but I have not had one letter to that effect. I have had, as I say, the councils of Tasmania, the Premier, the past Premier, the log carters, chambers of commerce, industry groups, unions, APPM—all those groups and people—seeking a resolution and legislation that would provide security.

PARA.TAB: The Tasmanian people are desperate to get resource security. As the Minister at the table, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson), knows only too well from his previous experience that this legislation could not provide it, would not provide it and I have very grave doubts that it was ever intended to provide it.

Since the Gordon below Franklin fiasco, Tasmania has declined. We are now playing with an industry, the second biggest industry in Australia, that encompasses 250,000 employees. The Government is playing games with them. There has been a 120 per cent increase in timber imports since 1983-84 and not one step has been taken by the Government that is going to improve that in any way. In fact, the Government is only taking steps that cloud the issue even more, that take away any sense of security and that would make employment and investment absolutely unthinkable.

The media, of course, are no help. They are always trying to go for the quick bash and the beat-ups and the sensations. They are trying to build these conflicts into the situation. In fact, I was not terribly impressed yesterday morning when a reporter of some sort rang me up and threatened me that, if I did not make a statement to him live on the air then, he would take certain actions against me. I think that is about as far down as it gets. I really believe that, when it gets to that stage—whoever it is, whether in the Government or not—of putting a journalist of this nature up to that sort of story, the game is going too far.

The APPM is the major participant at this juncture. It has said that its bottom line position is that it believes that we should pass the legislation. The APPM says that, of course, as a member of NAFI, it accepts what NAFI says, and, as a member of the Pulp and Paper Manufacturers Federation of Australia, it accepts what the Federation says. But APPM would like these amendments and it believes at present that it would naturally improve the legislation a lot if it had them.

That is the closest that the Government can go to saying that it has support. It has very limited qualified support and we cannot overlook that. It is good for APPM that it has in the legislation the other qualifications that it wants before it does its final feasibility, before it goes out looking for a partner and before it starts arranging any of its finances. It is a long, long way from being a cut and dried operation. But, with the fiasco we have had in the past and the way that this Government and this Minister have treated Tasmania in the past, I am not expecting too much.

I believe that if Mr Griffiths is allowed to just settle down in the cold light of dawn and go through the issues that have been raised and the degree of non-support that he has accumulated, if he looks at his Labour Party policy and talks to his ACTU and union friends, he will find that there is nothing wrong with acceding to the request that is being made. It represents no change to his Party's philosophy, but to the 250,000 employees in the industry throughout Australia, it would make all the difference in the world and give them some security. This legislation will not give them security. If the Government is trying to pretend that it is giving security when it has no intention of doing it, this is the way to go about it.

Every commentary says that the Bill is flawed. Everybody says the same thing. Not one has come out and said that it is not. How can the Government and the Minister ignore this evidence? How can the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Richardson, with his experience in these matters, ignore this? The Opposition will support the NAFI amendments. If the Government has any bona fides left in this whole matter, it will too. If it does, resource security will be provided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 came into being under the previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. We know the reputation of the combination of Mr Hawke and the Minister presently at the table, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson). We are well aware that Senator Richardson was one of the prime movers in getting rid of him, but we are also well aware that both Mr Hawke and Senator Richardson—Senator Richardson, in particular—brought the green votes forward for Mr Hawke on the previous occasion that Tasmania wanted a paper mill. We understand that on that occasion what Senator Richardson did was to let down not only the Tasmanian industry, but also timber industries and development in this country for many years. What he did was say to the world at large, `Do not try development in this country because there will be no guarantee you will get it.'

PARA.TAB: This Bill, of course, continues in that vein. This Bill is supposed to give security, guarantee of a resource. In other words, a company that is prepared to spend over $100 million in setting up a paper mill or any development that requires a resource of this country, should be able to look to this Bill to give it a guarantee that if it spends all that money it will have a resource at the end of the day when it starts up its business. This Bill deliberately leaves so many loopholes that, come the next election, as happened last time through Senator Richardson, the green vote will be given to the Government.

Let me tell the Senate what it says. To begin with it concerns developments over $100m, so the 1,200 sawmillers across Australia do not get a thing out of this. They are expected to spend all their money on development in the hope that the resource will be available to them at the end. There is no guarantee at all; there is not even any pretence of a guarantee. So it does nothing for all those small sawmillers round Australia, nothing at all.

The Bill supposedly gives the large companies, those spending more than $100m, some resource security. But let me explain just what it does do. It says, `Okay, we will give you this area, but we will only give you this area of forest for your resource if, even at the last minute, someone cannot find some sort of threatened species in that area. If they do, if someone can find some threatened species, no matter how small or insignificant, then at the last minute that reserve can be taken away from you and that resource will not be made available'. There is no guarantee, no suggestion, that a substitute resource would be made available. Indeed, a specific clause in the Bill says that no compensation will be available to a business that goes bust, even if it has spent all that money—over $100m—had the resource taken away from it, and been offered no other substitute resource. The Bill specifically provides that no compensation will be available.

As Senator Archer said, why will the Government not amend the legislation to take out the no compensation clause? It does not have to guarantee compensation, but it could at least remove the no compensation clause. The sawmillers and the smaller industries could then make plans knowing that if they spend $80m or $90m at least they will have some resource for the future. That is one of the amendments that we want.

Why will the Government not agree to such an amendment? Senator Archer said that to do so would not be contrary to Labor philosophy. I believe it would be very contrary to Labor philosophy because Labor philosophy says very clearly, `We have to leave the loopholes open for the next election so that if we want the Green vote we can grab it and bring it in'.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what this Bill is all about. It is nothing to do with giving industry security or with creating more of the jobs that are so necessary. We have a million unemployed already in this country. There is nothing in this Bill that has anything to do with creating jobs. It is just an assurance of more votes for the Labor Party at the next election; if they need that Green vote they can call on it. That is all it is.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister a couple of weeks ago, we all know, made that famous One Nation statement. But in that statement, he overrode the old legislation that Mr Hawke brought forward. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth, in cooperation with the States, commits itself to an accelerated and expanded program of joint regional assessments of national State forest values based on the Western Australian model.

That is fantastic; that is what we agree with; that is what we want. This was in the Prime Minister's statements just a couple of weeks ago. Okay.
