If that statement overrides this legislation, why on earth would the Government go ahead with the legislation? Why would it not say, `Okay; the new Prime Minister wants regional assessment, therefore this Bill is passe; it is no longer of any value.'?

PARA.TAB: Let me tell the Senate why. In the House of Representatives, when my colleague Chris Miles, the honourable member for Braddon, was debating this Bill, he said that the only reason the Government keeps this legislation on the Notice Paper is that it knows that back home in Tasmania APPM is urging the Government to pass it. APPM—one company—is urging it to pass it. For political reasons—because the Tasmanian senators might get a bit of a bashing over it—this Bill is kept on the Notice Paper. Let me quote from what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is only one reason: the Government wants to try to leave us with what it thinks will be the odium of the next election—the northern pulp mill.
When he said that, Mr Duncan Kerr, the only Labor member in the House of Representatives from my State, replied:
You have got it.
Mr Miles said about Mr Kerr's comment:
He says that it is purely political. He wants the odium placed on us; that is what he thinks. But I can tell the honourable member and all other Australians who are listening that it will not stick.
What did Mr Kerr say? He said:
There are no Australians listening. . .

The House was not on air. So it was because the House was not on air that Mr Kerr was prepared to acknowledge that the only reason this Bill is still on the Notice Paper is for political purposes. It does nothing for the industry at all.

PARA.TAB: As we have already said, there is only one group, one industry, one business, in the whole of Tasmania or Australia that is supporting the passage of the Bill, but even it wants it amended. APPM says, `If at the end of the day you cannot get your amendments through, then pass this Bill, no matter how bad it is'. Senator Archer has spoken about all the industries that have contacted us over the past 48 hours saying, `For heaven's sake, don't pass it without the amendments; for heaven's sake, get the Government to amend it so that it is genuine legislation'.

Let me go through just a few of those companies; Senator Archer went through so many that I will touch on just a few. Kempsey Timbers urges the Commonwealth Parliament to support the industry and union amendment package regarding the timber resources security legislation being debated today. The National Association of Forest Industries and the unions have put forward the amendments I told the Senate about a minute ago, not just for big mills but for sawmills, too, with the no compensation clause cut out and additional resource available if the promised one is excluded. These are the amendments that all these people are asking the Government to support; we do support them. We have Kempsey Timbers, Australian Paper Manufacturers and the Victorian Association of Forest Industries telling us the same thing. We have the Pulp and Paper Manufacturers Federation of Australia and Ford Timbers saying likewise. A Ford media release states:

SPEECH.PARA: Ford Timbers has been operating now for almost 80 years and we have contributed a lot to the local economy. . . We want to see our future, and the future of our employees, protected by legislation which has been properly thought out.

PARA.TAB: Mr Ford said the implementation of the proposed legislation in its current form would offer no long term security to the timber industry generally and had to be amended if industry security was to be guaranteed.

SPEECH.PARA: This is jobs we are talking about. The Government already has a million unemployed people, but it will not support these small timber sawmills.

PARA.TAB: Let us understand that the timber industry is the second largest employer of people in Australia. It employs more than 100,000 people; one of my colleagues says it is a quarter of a million. This Government is just ignoring their pleas to retain jobs in their industry. Hardys urges us `to adopt the industry-union amendments to the Federal resource security legislation, which seeks to protect existing jobs and investment and encourage future investment in the sawmilling sector'. The Australian Logging Council says the same thing. It urges the passage of the NAFI and union amendments. CCSO&M, the advertising agency, says that if the amendments developed by both industry and the unions are not included, it is a hopeless piece of legislation. Slater Contracting Company says:

SPEECH.PARA: We are a small logging business in the Eden area employing 14 people.
Over the last few years we have let the business run down because of the insecurity of the timber industry.

And why? Because of the action last time of the Minister at the table, Senator Richardson, letting down the timber industry and investors all over Australia, just to get the Green votes the Government needed to survive. So this small logging and earthmoving company with only 14 employees is going to the wall because the Government will not give it security to plan its future. Timber Investments Management says:
We have decided not to show any expression of interest. . . as we are not confident that the Australian government will continue to permit the cutting of. . . hardwood forests in the longer term.

Again, people are not investing. How many does the Minister want on the jobless queues? Is he not satisfied with a million? Does he want more? What is the reason for not doing it, apart from votes? New South Wales Forest Industries says the same thing—that the united industry-CALM-AHC agreement will be strongly opposed if the industry amendments are not included in this resource security legislation. We then come to Australian Forest Growers, who say:
If the Government is really serious about wood plantations, it must accept the amendments which have been presented by the industry.

I could spend the whole of my speech quoting from the various groups that are pleading with the Government to allow them to develop, to allow them to have security, to allow them to employ people and to re-employ those they had to sack. This Minister, Senator Richardson, who is responsible for the last effort, ignores the whole lot because he wants to leave that loophole open.

PARA.TAB: Come the next election, the Green vote will be able to be grabbed by the Government at the last minute. It does not matter about jobs. It does not matter that at the moment, because of that last election, we now have a million people unemployed. It does not matter that the leader he chose over Mr Hawke admitted that he deliberately caused the recession. He admitted that. He said it in his own words: `This is the recession we had to have'. He engineered it, and we had to get down as far as this before we could recover. He admitted that it was his responsibility that we now have one million unemployed. This is the leader that this Minister chose because he knows that, as he does himself, that Prime Minister will do and say anything at all to grab the votes that are necessary at the next election to keep the Labor Party in power.

It is the worst hypocrisy to treat a million unemployed people as mere numbers. I wonder whether those opposite have ever gone to a home that has been split by unemployment, where because the young people cannot get jobs and Dad is worried about his job, the young really have no interest in getting up early in the morning. Young people have been doing that, but they have not got the jobs, so they tend to sleep in a bit. Dad, who is getting up and is worried about retaining his job, says to the mother, `Why aren't the kids out of bed looking for a job?', and a brawl ensues because of the terrible tragedy of one in three of our Australian youth being unemployed.

This Government will not guarantee security to these small sawmillers, who have from 14 employees upwards, to enable them to plan, expand and invest. They refuse to do it, even at the pleading of all these groups. We have NAFI writing to the Prime Minister and saying that as a result of the decision of a meeting of its Association, the legislation should be withheld pending further consultations. That is what we plan to do. We plan to hold it up; not to hold it up deliberately, but to take it to a committee so that all these people's views can be put. We have all the letters. We can put the views of all these people to the Government members—because Government members will also be on that committee—and explain to them exactly what they are doing to the Australian people. I think with their ideology of not caring about anything except getting back into power they tend to forget that people are at the other end of this one million unemployed.

As Senator Archer said, we have had these appeals by all the paper manufacturers, by all the sawmillers, by all the forestry industries, the timber workers and all the rest of them, pleading with the Government to correct the Bill and make it sensible legislation that will create a secure resource for them. In the past 24 hours NAFI has said that the Federal Opposition and the Tasmanian Government have confirmed their support for the package of amendments presented to the Government last Friday. Just last Friday NAFI—the National Association of Forest Industries—and the unions presented to the Government this list of amendments that they want that will make this resource secure for them. The Government has been playing games. It has said it will consider getting rid of the no compensation clause, but it has not come up with amendments right to this minute. It is still not deleting that section from the Bill.

Even last Friday, NAFI and the unions pleaded with the Government for these amendments that we are supporting. The Government has not responded to those pleas. So we have decided to put forward the amendments that the industry and the unions want and that we want. If the Government knocks them back we will take the matter to a committee comprising honourable senators on both sides of this chamber—Labor members, Liberal members and National Party members—and we will let the industries themselves tell the Government members just what they think.

I think it is important that the Government members understand the feeling behind this legislation. The Forest Industries Federation of Western Australia is pleading with Premier Lawrence. She was asked to intervene. She has been asked to urgently contact the Prime Minister recommending the endorsement of the amendments because it not only applies to my State of Tasmania; it also applies to every other State. Western Australia is just as concerned as we are.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is having horrendous effects in New South Wales.

—Yes. If we as an Opposition let these industries down—which would be very simple—by agreeing to this dreadful legislation that would give only the big companies some so-called security, then I do not believe that this Parliament would be acting in the interests of Australians. We would see more people unemployed. We would see no investment at all amongst the sawmillers of Australia. We would see the large companies which have already approached us saying, `We need the amendments', pulling out of investment because there is no security in the Bill at all. The only thing in this Bill is the loophole to allow the Government to try to placate the Greens at the next election.

PARA.TAB: It does not do that. The Minister's attempt to placate the Greens has not worked. Indeed, the Greens say that it has not gone far enough. They do not want any development or any possibility of development. The Greens have said, `No. It is not good enough. It could allow some development. That is not what we are after. We want every tree to remain standing'.

A third of our State of Tasmania is set aside not to be used. How much more do we set aside? How many more jobs have to go before the Greens are satisfied and before this Government is satisfied that what we need is proper, secure development. We will not get that proper, secure development until we can assure industry representatives that, if they are prepared to put their money into investment, then the other side of the coin is to allow them to have the security of the resource that they have planned on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The supposed intention and purpose of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1992 is to provide for long term resource security to facilitate investment decisions by Australian timber manufacturers and to give some security and direction to the forest industry. I used the word `supposed'. This legislation is supposed to be about employment and jobs; it is supposed to be about looking after our trade deficit and doing something about the imbalance in our trade in the timber industry at the moment, with about only $1.4 billion worth of exports, yet we are importing something like $2.3 billion worth of timber products; and it is supposed to be about security of investment, but it is not really doing anything about any of those things.

PARA.TAB: Yet it is the first opportunity for this Government to show it is fair dinkum about the rhetoric of the One Nation statement. Given the chequered history of forestry in Australia—particularly in New South Wales in recent years—it is obvious that, for investment decisions to be made with any confidence, those wishing to invest be assured of the security of that investment.

The Labor Government has once again failed to deliver. It has sat on this legislation for a long time with very little result. The Bill gives absolutely no assurances, no guarantees and no direction to the forest industries. There is nothing in this legislation that says, `Go ahead, create jobs and install plant and equipment, because we will not pull the pin on you'. The majority of the industry's employees are involved in small operations, and this legislation fails to recognise that.

For the small operators there is no security of tenure, no encouragement to create wealth and no encouragement to create jobs for people in the community. They have been forgotten. Yet it is those small operators who have been affected the most by the constant interference in their industry—particularly by this Labor Government as it waxes and wanes in its efforts to woo the green vote. A new Minister at the table now, the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Richardson, can take a lot of the credit for the problems associated with the timber industry in Australia.

It seems that what the Government says is not always what it does. Even the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), who is responsible for this legislation, seems to have fallen well short of his own rhetoric. I will quote from a paper he issued in February 1991 on resource security. It read:

SPEECH.PARA: Rather, resource security is a process to identify and protect the environmental and heritage values of our forests and importantly, to enhance employment through encouraging a thriving, secure forest products industry.
He said that resource security is all those things. He said the reason we needed legislation was that:

There is a perception within industry, the trade union movement and the community that the Government has no clear process to handle forest disputes and guarantee that certain forests are available for value adding activity.
And he acknowledged that there was uncertainty in the industry. I will quote what his paper said about that. It read:

. . . there currently exists an unprecedented level of uncertainty in the industry to commit to value adding investments so necessary to address the crippling current account deficit attributed to this industry.
The paper went on:
For its part, however, industry has clearly indicated to the Government that Commonwealth legislation is essential to secure those forest areas required to underpin investment decisions.

Put simply, without the resource security process culminating in Commonwealth and State legislation then the investments will not proceed and the benefits of those investments will not be conferred on the Australian community.
The paper went on further about the benefits that would accrue from a legislative level of resource security. It read:

By providing for resource security process to address industry, employment and conservation objectives, there would be confidence for the forest industry to invest in value adding investment and for forest growers to invest in new methods to improve forest health and productivity.
The confidence and investment would also assist in accelerating the transition from primarily oldgrowth to primarily regrowth native forest resources.
He accepted the importance of the forest industries and highlighted the impact on our trade deficit. The paper read:

PARA.TAB: In 1989-90, Australia's trade deficit in forest products accounted for around 10 percent of our total current account deficit.

The Minister realised what would happen if appropriate legislation was not put in place. We have got to remember that this industry is Australia's second largest manufacturing industry, employing around 250,000 Australians in the forest and forest products, printing and allied industries. In the paper the Minister went on to say:

If a legislative policy framework for resources security is not provided, Australian forest products companies will continue to invest offshore. For example, AMCOR, one of Australia's largest forest products companies now derives 30 percent of its turnover from recent offshore investments in the pulp and paper sector.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Senate: have we got a Government in power here in Australia at the moment that would rather export jobs than export value added product? This legislation means that that is going to happen. We are going to export our jobs rather than exporting a product which we have got here in the country at the moment, a renewable resource product.

PARA.TAB: It was February 1991 when that paper came out, and that was when the legislation was drawn up. In October last year it was put to the industry, which told the then Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Resources that the legislation would not do what it was supposed to do. I quote from a letter from NAFI to the then Prime Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Although the Bill is entitled the Forest Conservation and Development Bill it would in fact at best provide for conservation and development of only a section of Australia's native forests.
I know I am repeating what some other speakers have quoted, but it is very, very pertinent that this be quoted. NAFI made the following points also:
2.In its current form it does not deliver security for the existing industry, which has been very seriously affected by decisions made by your government.
3.The legislation is selective and discriminatory in that it only provides for $100m plus projects.
4.The approval process appears to be largely open ended.
5.The exceptions in the legislation are so all embracing that our legal advice is that the legislation would deliver only an illusion of security.
6.There is a lack of symmetry and complementarity between the Commonwealth and State approaches to forest policy, land use and resource security legislation.
7.The draft legislation would lead to a level of involvement by the Commonwealth in industry operations far in excess of that required to ensure ecologically sustainable forest use.

PARA.TAB: Since then we have had a change of Prime Minister. Again the industry approached the Government, through the new Prime Minister (Mr Keating), urging a commitment to regional resource security:

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Government's decision in March last year to support resource security for projects over $100m it has become increasingly clear that the bulk of the industry will only be able to achieve its investment goals if the eligibility criteria under the legislation is expanded . . .

NAFI went on to repeat its concerns about the $100m limit, which has big effects over all Australia. On 18 February it issued, at a national level, a press release again stressing regionally based resource security.

PARA.TAB: I would like to cite some investments waiting to proceed in New South Wales. This legislation does not even cover any project in New South Wales, because of the $100m cut-off criterion.

The Federal Government has been presented with a report, FORTEC, which states that there are $95m worth of investments ready to begin in northern New South Wales immediately. This investment stretches over a 10-year period and incorporates several different companies. The legislation, without the amendment which accepts the State accredited plan, will not provide any security to begin even one dollar of that investment.

The New South Wales Government has moved towards providing security at that level with the introduction of the Timber Industry (Interim Protection) Bill. This Bill, of course, was supported by some 4,000 people who were standing in Macquarie Street, Sydney, begging for the legislation. The Federal Government must provide a means of complementing that security at the Commonwealth level. If it does not, it will fail in its responsibility to the Australian community by rejecting $5 billion worth of investment in Australia's second largest manufacturing industry.

For example, New South Wales—the State that Senator Richardson represents, that he has done so much to damage with some of his legislation passed in this place—directly employs 8,000 people in the timber industry, and that is a conservative estimate. Using the multiplier of about 2.2, that puts it up to 20,000-odd people affected. Communities that are 100 per cent affected and dependent upon this industry are places such as Grafton, Dorrigo, Wauchope, Casino, Woodenbong, Urbenville, Walcha, Glen Innes, Gloucester, Nimmitabel, Bombala and Eden. There are other places in my home State of New South Wales that are affected if we do not have the right sort of legislation. These are places such as Lismore, in which maybe 30 to 70 per cent of people are dependent on the timber industry. Also there are Coffs Harbour, Narooma, Moruya, Port Macquarie, Cooma, Newcastle and Murwillumbah. I would be failing in my duty to the people of New South Wales, including the people who live in those towns, if I did not stress to this chamber and to the people in the Government why there is a necessity to have a change in this legislation, and urge them to listen to some of the amendments that have been moved.

To have had, in September 1990, a group of people circling this Parliament in some 383 trucks with an average $250,000 invested in each truck, with each of those owners spending $1,000 per day sitting here waiting for the Government to say they can continue to work is a big worry. Those people are still waiting. They are still waiting for the Government to decide whether they will lose all their investment. They are not big boys; they are not big investors. But an investment in a truck worth $250,000 is a very big investment. Those truck owners all have wives; they all have children; they all have people who actually have to be fed and clothed. Because of the insecurity of their industry, of those 383 who were here at that protest between 30 and 50 have since gone to the wall.

This legislation was meant to be about job security. Of course, the Government said of its One Nation statement that that was what the statement was about: it was about jobs and job security. This is the first test it has had and it has failed. As I said earlier, what is going to happen is that we are going to end up exporting jobs out of Australia instead of products. This Government, this Keating Labor Government, has been crying to us about value adding—crying out about it. What is it doing here with this legislation? It is actually crucifying its value adding policies before they even have a chance to have a go.

Senator Coulter made some absolutely ridiculously spurious comments about this legislation. I think that it is Senator Walsh who says that Senator Coulter might have been talking with the fairies at the bottom of the garden or whatever. I wonder whether he is the fairy at the bottom of the garden, because he believes in something that is not really looking to Australia's future. He is not looking at giving people jobs. He actually wants to lock up the whole of Australia. I can tell him, I can tell anyone else in this chamber, and anyone else in Australia that you cannot protect the environment without a vibrant economy and you cannot protect the environment without an economy that can afford to protect it. If we look at the other countries around the world where the environmental damage really needs looking at, we will see that they are economies that cannot afford to protect themselves because they do not have an income coming in.

The conservation movement has started to realise that the Labor Party has no real interest in it. Their romance was just a vote catching exercise. When the former Minister, Senator Richardson, was removed from the environment portfolio he changed very dramatically. We all knew that at that stage the green vote no longer counted to the ALP. This legislation is a mishmash which basically pleases no-one. The green vote says that it is unhappy and the timber industry says that it is unhappy. The amendments moved by the Opposition offer genuine resource security to forest development projects, irrespective of size, and they also give environmental security. I think that needs to be remembered when looking at the way our amendments are framed.

The Opposition supports the notion of resource security. We have said repeatedly that if the legislation is properly drafted, and takes into consideration the concerns of all sectors of the industry and conservation groups, we would support it. The legislation we have in front of us today does not do that. Even members of the Labor Party in the other place have admitted the legislation is actually flawed.

Development of any resource in this country deserves immediate and serious consideration. We cannot dream or wish ourselves out of this recession. It will not just happen by thinking that there are fairies down the bottom of the garden. We will not get out of this recession by dreaming about it; we will only get out of it if people want to work, if people want to invest and if people have the security to invest. There would not be one member of this chamber who would put money into something where he or she did not have some security in knowing that the Government was not going to come down heavy-handed in the next little while and take away the chance of multiplying that investment. There would not be one person in here, not a soul.

All the timber industry is asking for is a chance to invest, to make money for Australia, to give jobs to Australians and to make sure that we have a more prosperous country than we have got at the moment. We have been knocked into the ground by Keating the Treasurer and now by Keating the Prime Minister. He has not been game to bite the bullet and say that he will give resource security, which is fundamental to this country, so that we can go ahead and have a much more vibrant economy.

The Government needs to listen to those in the industry who know a bit about it. It needs to look at what investment is being held up by flawed and inadequate legislation. The Labor Party prides itself in looking after the worker. How does this legislation protect the worker? It does the opposite; it puts people out of work. I honestly cannot understand how people who have come through the trade union movement want to do away with jobs. There is no security for jobs in companies such as Kempsey Timbers, which has written to us. It employs 25 people and looks to the Federal Government to give it the right signals to continue to invest. This legislation does not do that.

Ford Timbers at Urbenville in New South Wales, my home State, has called on the Government to adopt the amendments. Hardys Tumbarumba employs 160 people directly and has 60 contract employees. Listen to what it had to say in its letter:

SPEECH.PARA: The hardwood component of our operation comes from State Forest which is managed on a sustained yield basis. There exist significant opportunities for value adding of this resource. However in the absence of State and Commonwealth legislation which secures the availability of this resource for wood production, Hardys cannot proceed with the investment necessary for such value adding to take place.

I was on the same platform last year up in Queensland as Ministers in the Labor Government when they were talking of value-adding. Here we have a company which wants to value add but which is told by this legislation, `Invest in it if you like but we can't give you any security. You might have it taken away from you'.

PARA.TAB: The New South Wales Logging Association, representing logging contractors, is looking to us to ensure their future employment. Slater Contracting at Eden is a small company. It employs 14 people. I think Senator Archer made a comment about the company earlier here today. There are most probably 14 families—not just 14 individuals—who depend on the one small company. In Eden that is a significant number. Slater Contracting says in its letter to the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past few years we have let the business run down because of the insecurity of the timber industry.

We urge you to accept the amendments to the above legislation as supported by the timber industry and unions so that we can once again employ trainees, increase our staff and also replace our ageing equipment which will give a much needed boost to our town and country and help get the economy going.
We are just one of the many small businesses in the town that are in this situation.
Senator Archer made the point very eloquently that that is not going to happen. They are not going to invest.

TALK.START.PARA: —It cannot happen.

—It cannot happen. They are not going to invest money in something that is not going to actually achieve something for them and the community. They will not invest until this Government gets this legislation right. The evidence is there for the Government to see, if it wanted to see it. If honourable members opposite were not so absolutely tied up with and locked into a situation, if they opened their eyes, they would see that something could be done to make sure that people did have security, that there was protection from the environment, that we got our balance of payments right with the timber industry and that we could actually get more people working again and investing. If honourable senators opposite looked at the amendments honestly and fairly they would see the logic of the amendments put by my colleague Senator Tambling when he opened this debate.

PARA.TAB: Australia is in an economic mess. Legislation such as the legislation proposed by the Labor Party does nothing to alleviate that situation. If the Prime Minister is fair dinkum about getting this country back on its feet he will adopt Opposition amendments to this legislation so that we have a good balance between resource security, looking after the environment, giving people jobs and making sure that we have a vibrant industry for the future which uses a renewable resource.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President—
—Are you speaking on behalf of the Tasmanian Premier?

—I will be referring later to what the Tasmanian Premier has to say, and I will be putting the record straight. What I intended to say initially was that I am here today to speak on the Forest Conservation and Development Bill after a campaign of misinformation by the honourable senator's Government, and at last we have a chance to debate this matter in the chamber. It is fair to say that this Bill has caused this side of the chamber a fair amount of concern, and part of that concern has been the pressure we have had put on us by individuals who, I am afraid, do not understand fully the consequences of this Bill.

PARA.TAB: As a Tasmanian, I am acutely aware of the value of our forest industries to the general community. As a Tasmanian, I have experienced at first hand the political point-scoring that has characterised this Government's action in relation to access to our native resources. I have been told that Minister Griffiths, on the Judy Tierney show on the ABC in Hobart this week, had the audacity to call on Tasmanian senators to cross the floor and stop playing politics. We know who is playing politics in this particular fiasco. Our position is quite clear: we are supporting amendments put up by those people who are affected—the industry and the unions. They are the amendments we are supporting. Yet the Government sees fit to just sit back and try to denigrate this side of politics and blame us for its shonky legislation.

It has been pointed out by one of my colleagues—I think it was Senator Walters—that back in October 1991 the then Director of NAFI, Brian Gibson, wrote back to the then Prime Minister, after receiving a copy of the Bill, and pointed out all the defects in it. Nothing has changed since then. Another lesson I have learned from this is that I did not realise just how biased—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is Ray Groom going to say before the Senate Committee?

—Senator Sherry will have his turn in a minute. Another thing I have learnt in the last few days is just how biased our media has been in Tasmania. Even Senator Devereux gets a run in the press releases in the Advocate, the Examiner, and the Mercury. The Mercury is trying to drive a wedge between the Premier and his Federal colleagues. Even today, in the Mercury an article headed `Forests law delay yet again' speaks of squabbling between the Government and the Opposition, how the Opposition has vowed not to pass the Bill, that the Government will not move either, and all that sort of stuff. There is not one word in any of those press releases about the industry view, not one word that says that the industry wants these amendments and knows that the legislation will not work without them. There is not one word anywhere here that puts the other point of view. If I ever had any doubts about the media, they have been put to bed now.

PARA.TAB: At the end of the day the question for us remains: do we support defective legislation, legislation which has been denigrated by the National Association of Forest Industries, by other forestry organisations that make up the industry and by trade unions and will provide no real benefit for the industry? Or do we maintain our stand that what is needed is genuine resource security, the resource security that is not guaranteed in the legislation before the Senate today?

I shall quote one of the Government's own members about this Bill. We need to look no further than the Australian Financial Review of 12 November last year, when a former Minister, Senator Peter Walsh, had this to say about this resource security Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: If words mean what they say, this seems to permit closing down a project at any time by ministerial fiat. Resource security takes on a distinctly Orwellian flavour.

Let us make it quite clear right from the start that this is payback legislation—nothing more and nothing less. It has been introduced by the Government to pay back for the crimes that have been perpetrated on the forest industry by the former Minister for the environment, Senator Richardson. We do not need reminding, but in the lead-up to the last Federal election the former Minister prostrated the Labor Government at the feet of the radical Green movement in a frantic attempt to gain Green preferences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this?

—Senator Collins would know that, in doing so, Senator Richardson left a trail of destruction amongst the forest industries of our nation. From Queensland to central New South Wales, to Tasmania, and even to Western Australia he made it quite clear that forest industries were not the flavour of the month as far as he was concerned. All he could see was green in one eye and green in the other.

PARA.TAB: I remember a year or so ago, on one of my visits to north Queensland, going to Ravenshoe and having discussions with the families of the timber workers. I am pretty sure that Senator Richardson would remember his trips up there too. I talked to timber workers who had been thrown on the dole by the actions of Senator Richardson. Honourable senators may also remember the protest that occurred in September 1990 when 300 trucks surrounded this building, supported by almost 3,000 protesters who had travelled from all over Australia to express their concern about the manner in which they were being treated by this Labor Government.

There is no doubt that the former Minister's anti-forestry industry policy has had a number of consequences for Australia. First of all, it has lengthened considerably our dole queues. It has also worsened the dramatic recession we had to have. But perhaps the principal problem has been the total lack of confidence which is now apparent in the forest industry. Over the years, while Senator Richardson was grooming the Green preferences, he left those people who had a mind to invest in forestry in Australia thinking that it would be commercial suicide to do that sort of thing. Investors in those areas were left in no doubt that, no matter how thorough their investigations and no matter how sound their investment, there was always a chance that the Labor Party would put their project aside in a search for the Green preference votes.

Unfortunately, as we stand here today, the industry has been almost destroyed by this approach. It is certainly suffering from a lack of confidence. As a result, the Government has brought forward this legislation, not with a genuine desire to assist the industry but because the Green preferences are no longer the flavour of the month and the Government is trying to get back on an even footing with the forestry industry.

If we could trust the Government, we would not be here debating this legislation today. If we could believe that the Government's word was its bond, we would not need to have resource security legislation. Because its track record is so hopeless, we have this half-baked Bill before us today. Because previous Ministers have not been able to keep their promises, for whatever reason, unfortunately we must introduce legislation so that large wood processing projects which require a supply of natural resource over a period of time and which also require significant financial investment can proceed, knowing that their access to wood supply can be guaranteed. There certainly needs to be a requirement for State and Commonwealth governments to give undertakings that resources are available and the resultant products can be exported.

I think it goes without saying that we also have a very active and very radical Green movement in our country which seeks to stop altogether the logging of native forests. We have heard from Senator Coulter today and I note that, in a media release in Hobart, the leader of the Green Independents, Dr Bob Brown, said that the Bill would have a devastating effect on both the environment and the economy. He said:
It entrenches the appalling situation where some five million tonnes of Australia's native forests are being woodchipped and exported.

SPEECH.PARA: One can always guarantee that, whatever the Bill, whenever timber is mentioned, Dr Brown will come up with some new forest or some rare species or something that is going to suffer because someone in this country is trying to do something positive. My colleagues from Tasmania must get sick and tired of hearing the same old thing all the time. I do not know where he gets his figures from.

PARA.TAB: The essential point I would like to make is that resource security legislation should be unnecessary and it would be unnecessary if the Government had been genuine in its dealings with the industry. Those are not just my words; they are also the views of Simon Crean, Senator Button, John Kerin and Alan Griffiths, who put their own words together in a submission to Caucus. They said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a perception within industry, the trade union movement and the community, that the Government has no clear process to handle forest disputes and guarantee that certain forests are available for value adding activity.

That is correct. As evidence, I quote from a copy of a letter that I managed to get hold of today. A foreign timber investment company had been looking to invest in Australia. Writing to one of its associates in Australia, it said:

We have decided not to show any expression of interest at this time as we are not confident that the Australian government will continue to permit the cutting of natural hardwood forests in the longer term.
No-one has any confidence in putting their money into forestry in Australia—and why should they, having seen all the broken promises and the backsliding that this Government has been up to?

PARA.TAB: Because the legislation is related so closely to what is happening in Tasmania, I believe it is important that we review what has happened in my State over the years in which this Government has been meddling in our forest industry. Just for the record, over the last 15 years, we have had 11 separate inquiries into the forest industry in Tasmania. This has involved all sorts of things, including a huge number of memoranda of understanding which have been tossed aside by the Federal Government when it has been convenient for it to do so. I also remind the Senate of the decision by the Federal Government not to log the Lemonthyme, which saw another valuable resource locked away.

The most recent example of this Government's meddling in the Tasmanian forestry industry was in March 1989 when Senator Richardson made that great decision to block the Wesley Vale project. That cost many jobs in a sadly economically depleted area of the State, as Senator Sherry would know.

Forest industries are certainly a very vital part of the future of Australia. Around $4 billion of private investment is purported to be on hold because of this Government. At the same time, our external trade account for wood and wood products is in deficit, with imports exceeding exports by $1.6 billion in 1989-1990. This comprised total imports of $2,126m and exports of only $523m. The main categories of our imports were paper and paper board, which comprised $1,018m, sawn log of up to $463m and pulp and waste paper of $240m. Exports for the corresponding period were only $356m in woodchips and $1.8m in paper and paper board. This shows, without any shadow of doubt, that there certainly is a much needed opportunity for Australia to become further involved in the downstream processing of forest resources.

I referred earlier to the manner in which this Government has chosen to play cheap politics over the issue of resource security. I want to take this opportunity to place on record, once again, the coalition's strong commitment to supporting genuine resource security. We all know that the present legislation is defective and it will not provide adequate resource security for large and small forest industries. This is an issue which has been strongly endorsed by the industry.

Again and again, the coalition has indicated a preparedness to work with the Government in devising effective legislation, but at every opportunity the Government has chosen to ignore its efforts and to resolve this matter. We have heard from the Government, from the Minister and from honourable senators opposite regarding the so-called extensive consultation which preceded this Bill and the so-called support from within the industry, but I submit that this support is a sham and the industry's amendments drafted by—

TALK.START.PARA: —What, Ray Groom is a sham?

—I will get to Ray Groom in a minute. It is the industry's amendments drafted by the National Association of Forest Industries that should be supported. Now, if I can without too many more interruptions from Senator Sherry, I want to clear up his interjections about our Premier in Tasmania, Mr Groom.
—Be careful, as we are going to send him a copy of what you say.
—Right. For the record, I would like to read from a letter by Mr Groom to the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, dated 24 March—this week:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Association of Forest Industries has now proposed a number of amendments to the Forest Conservation and Development Bill. The Federal Opposition supports these amendments and I urge the Government to support them too in order to ensure that the industry gets the resource security it needs.

That is what Mr Groom said. He has called upon the Labor Government to support the amendments of the Federal Opposition and NAFI. Surely Senator Sherry has got no doubt in his mind of the position of NAFI. I guess that as a Tasmanian he has been getting all the press releases that it and all the forest companies throughout Australia have been putting out. They have been putting out their views; I just wonder how much notice the Government is going to take of the real people in the game—the ones who make their living from forest industries, the ones who represent the sawmillers and the hard-working forest industry people. Even if it has already been quoted, I will read from a facsimile sent to all Federal Cabinet Ministers on 1 March this year by Dr Robert Bain, the Executive Director of NAFI.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do the Tasmanian sawmillers say?
—Senator Sherry must have read my speech before I could make it. I am going to get around to that in a minute, if he will give me a chance. I am just trying to quote from Rob Bain's fax to Cabinet:

SPEECH.PARA: NAFI, the ACTU and timber unions and the Federal Opposition are agreed on the amendments that are required to make this legislation broadly workable. In essence, the eligibility criteria must be broadened so that this legislation can either apply to major projects or to regional forest assessments when these have been carried out to full Commonwealth requirements.
Senator Sherry would know as well as anybody else that this resource legislation does not do anything for the south of Tasmania. It does not do a damn thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the State legislation does. Read the State legislation.

—If Senator Sherry is going to talk about the State legislation, I have read some of it. I saw what Mr Lowe had to say about it in the upper House. He was not happy with the legislation and he said, `But it will all be fixed up later with a few amendments'. Those amendments have not happened and the honourable senator will not even make any amendments to the legislation here.

PARA.TAB: Once again—bringing this right up to date—we have the situation that as recently as 24 March, two days ago, NAFI again pleaded with the Government to take notice of the forest organisations around Australia. The Association pleaded with the Government again to stop playing politics:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the past 24 hours, the Federal Opposition and the Tasmanian Government had confirmed their support for a package of amendments presented to the Government last Friday.

PARA.TAB: `The amendments will make the legislation genuinely workable', he said. `They will enable State governments to put forward properly accredited forest management and development plans which, with Commonwealth legislation, will provide for the long term conservation and management of the forests'.

SPEECH.PARA: Hopefully, that will keep the greenies happy. NAFI continued:

`At the same time, they will provide a basis for investment in value adding, import replacement and providing sound, mature, long term employment. The amendments bring the legislation largely into line with an information paper on resource security issued by the Minister for Resources last year'.
I wonder whether Senator Sherry has ever read that. NAFI continued:

In that paper, Minister Griffiths clearly showed why genuine resource security could not be provided by non-legislative means and argued that resource security should be granted on the basis of wood production zones.
That is just like the Prime Minister's One Nation statement. And here we have this other shemozzle that we are supposed to be supporting.

PARA.TAB: In concluding my quotations from NAFI, in the five minutes left before lunch, I would like to read the final paragraph of the media release NAFI put out. I believe it states quite clearly the industry's view on the Government's response to the development so far:

SPEECH.PARA: The tragedy will be, if the Government rejects the amendments, a crisis of confidence in forest industries and other resource industries, leading to the loss of millions of dollars in investment and thousands of jobs.

PARA.TAB: The Association makes it clear where it stands in relation to the Government's position, but it is not alone. The list of industry groups which oppose this legislation is endless. They are all in there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prove it.

—All right. When I have finished, the honourable senator can come and have a look. Getting away from Tasmania, I thought one of the classic press releases was from Australian Paper Manufacturers yesterday:

PARA.TAB: `Forest Resource Security is achievable', Don Macfarlane . . . said today.
`Amendments endorsed by the Federal Opposition are supported by APM and would protect jobs in Gippsland now', he said.
`The Federal Government could accept these amendments without a major change to the intention of the Bill.
The passage of the Bill would ensure that the Victorian forest and timber strategy can be maintained.
We have asked Minister Griffiths to seek consultation with the Opposition so that effective amendments are considered'.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened? Why will the Government not sit down and accept these amendments?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why won't you support the Bill?

—Obviously, the honourable senator has not been listening. I have just tried to explain why we cannot support the Bill. No-one else wants to support it: the industry does not want to support it, the unions do not want to support it. They want a few amendments made, and I do not know why the Government will not do it.
—What about Tasmania?
—The Managing Director of APM turned around and said just the other day, 28 February:

SPEECH.PARA: I would urge you to consider appropriate amendments as suggested by NAFI.
Queensland Timber wrote to the former Prime Minister expressing its hopes that this would be supported.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry raised the question: what about Tasmania? I just point out to him that, in my State of Tasmania alone, this Bill ignores smaller sawmills and veneer mills which have been proposed for the south of the State, in the Huon region. Those proposals would gain nothing from this legislation. Recently, it was brought to my attention that the country sawmillers in Tasmania are suffering genuine need. That industry has been neglected but it is worth $64m to Tasmania alone. It processes around 170,000 cubic metres of sawn timber each year and employs up to 700 people. Yet it gets no consideration whatsoever from this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the State legislation takes care of that.

—I would not place any credence at all in the State legislation, from what I have read of it. In conclusion, I implore the Government to sit down and take note of the expressions of concern shown by the forestry industries throughout Australia. I hope that, when this matter goes to committee next week, those concerned bodies will be able to make their points of view known to everybody.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

—Yesterday during Question Time Senator Button embarked upon an outrageous distortion of and hypocritical attack on the Opposition's Fightback package. Senator Short, during Question Time and immediately prefacing his own question, sought leave to take note of the answer and to continue his remarks after Question Time. The President ignored that request. At the end of Question Time Senator Short again rose to seek leave to move a motion to take note of the answer and to make a short statement. There was then some confusion. He was—and I have read the Hansard—given leave to do what he asked and what he asked was to take note of the answer and to make a statement. Leave was granted.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button then rose and, without need to, sought leave and responded. I then sought also to make a short statement with regard to the answer and I was told by the President that in fact the request for leave was only to make a short statement. The Hansard shows that not to be correct and in fact it was quite proper that I should have been able to answer the nonsense that Senator Button was going on with yesterday afternoon then and there. I place it on notice, Mr Deputy President, that I hope we will not see repeated the exhibition that went on yesterday when this confusion arose—and the confusion seemed to be the Clerk's confusion as well. When I said, `Well, in that case I seek leave', Senator Button simply said, `No'. The whole thing was totally unsatisfactory and I hope we do not see a repeat of that.

Briefly, I am forced into the position today to make the statement that I would have made yesterday concerning the misstatements that Senator Button made about the Fightback package. I find it fascinating frequently as we sit here in Question Time to see that Senator Button seems to have no knowledge of the Government's own policies, but he seems to espouse the idea that he has knowledge of ours. I think it is important that we place on the record the correct statistics of the havoc that has been wreaked by this Government and its policies and the fact that the Fightback package offers hope.

The first statistics I want to put on the record are these: first of all, we now have 218,000 children who live in families where nobody has a job at all. There are almost 250,000 Australians who have been unemployed for a year; that is a staggering 88 per cent increase in a year. There are now 500,000 children who are living in poverty and there are 75,000 children who have no homes at all.

With that as a background, we look at the competing proposals to bring about recovery in the Australian economy and to see hope restored to the Australian people. The Fightback package promises to abolish seven taxes, which will lower the impost on business by $20 billion. It is a package that promises to give back to taxpayers $13 billion of their own money which is now collected by way of taxation. It is a package which, in fact, funds that restructuring of the tax system by the use of a goods and services tax.

The whole of the restructuring of the tax system is prompted by two fundamental principles—the principles of logic and equity. There is no equity at all in the present tax system. It has resulted in an all time low ratio of savings and we have been forced to go into international debt. Because we have not had enough savings here to finance what we have needed to do, we have gone overseas and borrowed other people's savings.

I think it is important to look at the way the current tax system affects the ordinary household and why the question of tariffs has become relevant and how that affects the ordinary household.If we take the figures and analyse the impact of the wholesale sales tax, the petrol tax excise and the tariff tax, otherwise known as customs duties, that are imposed on this society, we see that overall they cost Australian families about $45 a week. We can directly say that tariff tax—and that is what all customs duties are—costs an average family about $16 a week and is responsible for collecting about 3.6 per cent of total revenue.

To look at just how this impacts on families, I give the example of a pair of shoes that is imported into this country. That pair of shoes will be bought by a family at the bottom end of the financial spectrum—one of the 42 per cent who earn $20,000 or less who will get no tax relief under the so-called One Nation—better named the `No Nation'—statement. But these people are penalised by the way the tariff tax system works. A pair of shoes with leather uppers imported at a wholesale free-on-board price of $10 will attract a duty—under the base quota—of 50 per cent; that is, $5. If we then add in freight, insurance and handling costs of $1, a wholesale margin of, say, $3.20, and a retail margin of, say, $8.60, we find that the final consumer price is $27.80. In other words, the duty or the tariff tax that is imposed represents a consumer tax of 18 per cent.

If that same pair of shoes were imported outside base quota—under tender quota—we would find that the tax would be anything up to 23 per cent. The people who need to be able to have access to low priced goods, who need to be able to buy shoes, clothes, children's shirts and dresses for their youngsters at a reasonable price, are being penalised. This Government talks about equity and justice, yet it has imposed upon the Australian family a harsh and unconscionable tax regime whereby, since it has been in office, it has ripped off the taxpayer by increasing the tax take by 34 per cent. No wonder we got a surplus in early Budgets: we got it simply because we wreaked more tax on the individual taxpayer.

The wholesale sales tax has been put up three times. From that tax, the Government used to collect around $3 billion; now it collects $9 billion to $10 billion. Never once did the Government actually have the courage to go to the people at election time and say, `Our policy is to increase the wholesale sales tax and to increase the tax take and we would like you to judge us about that.' Oh, no, they were hidden. The Government has had its own GST for a long time. It has been the Government's secret tax.

When the Government came to power the fuel excise was 9c a litre. What is it now? It is 26c a litre. We are giving it back, so that every time people go to the petrol station to fill up the family car with petrol, they will be about $10 or $11 better off; in other words, that is how much less it will cost them. Of course, the people who are in business will get a deduction of 26c a litre, because it will be an inputs tax and they will be entitled to a refund.

The great lie that the Government puts around is that somehow the tax restructuring is merely to impose a new tax upon existing costs. Wrong! The restructured system will mean, once all those taxes we are abolishing are gone—and we are keeping the Prices Surveillance Authority to ensure that that occurs—the 15 per cent will be imposed at that much lower cost. Those who do their sums—some people are better at doing sums than the Government is—will see that the net result is 4.4 per cent. We can even read that down to 2.2 per cent, if we want to apply the implicit price deflator. But that is not something people readily understand, and so we take the conservative figure of 4.4 per cent. So that nobody is disadvantaged, the people who are getting refunds through the tax system will benefit by having more money in their pockets.

Under our system a taxpayer with an income of $30,000 will get $30 back by way of a reduction in tax, but under the Government's `No Nation' statement all he will get is $15. Of course, if he earns $20,000 or less, he gets sweet nothing. Indeed, our incentive package will allow 95 per cent of all taxpayers to earn double the income of $30,000 and pay no greater rate of tax—incentive is built back and so is the will to save. Those people who are outside the tax system—those who depend on pensions—will be compensated by an increase in the pension rate of 8 per cent; and for special benefits, 6 per cent.

The real point I want to make is about tariffs. We have said that we will reduce tariffs so that they have negligible effects by the year 2000. We have said that we will do it at the same time as we are reducing the costs of doing business—micro-economic reform—and that the reductions will be transparent and known about. I have said that the whole package is driven by logic and equity. Those are the reasons we want to see those people who need to have access to goods which are cheaper get access to those goods and not be penalised by the current tariff regime.

There is nothing fair about the current tax regime. It has led to an all time low savings ratio. It has led to an unfair burden on sectors of the economy, with the wholesale sales tax being applied only to goods—things that are made—as distinct from services that are applied. We could understand that being the case in the 1930s, because most people were employed making things. Of course, these days they are not. Most people are employed in the delivery of services. So there is no logical or equitable reason why that should continue. Fairness and sense are our guiding principles, and the Fightback package stands up to those two tests on every test. The `No Nation' statement fails on every indicator.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Denigration of the Irish Race--Australian Republicanism

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to use my full 15 minutes, but I rise in a sense of dismay over an article that was brought to my attention in recent days, from a New South Wales regional newspaper, the Parkes Champion Post of 23 March 1992. I refer to a regular column by the local Federal member of parliament, Mr Michael Cobb, the heading of which is `Keating's republic dividing the nation'. I am saddened to read the article because Mr Cobb uses in it some inflammatory language which is not becoming of him as a member of the Irish-Australia Parliamentary Friendship Association. The part that got to me when it was brought to my attention—and honourable senators will understand why it was brought to my attention—is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: A further motivation for the Prime Minister's outburst is his bog Irish streak, an unmaskable cultural imprint which has imprisoned him with certain prejudices and rendered him unable to rise above this irrational and paranoiac dislike of all things English.

I think it is very unfortunate that Mr Cobb would use emotive terminology such as that. He has fallen into the trap—an English trap, or a British trap—that was set some time ago to denigrate the Irish as a race of people.

PARA.TAB: It was a deliberate political tactic by the British during the last century to publicise the Irish people as a race of people who had no brains, who were dumb, who were silly, and who could not be given control of their own nation. It was done with very distinct political motives and, to a certain degree, it was very successful. It continues, to a certain degree, to be successful, because we would all have heard from time to time these sickening Irish jokes that abound in our community.

It is unfortunate that Mr Cobb should now seek to use those inflammatory words, as the British have done so successfully for a number years, in this present debate about whether Australia should become a republic. I do not have to stand up in this place and defend the Irish people, who have made enormous contributions in the world of arts, literature, politics, economics, education and so forth, not only to this country but right throughout the world. In the area of literature and drama I could give names such as Joyce, Wilde, Yeats, Kavanagh and O'Casey, all names which immediately trip off the tongue when we are talking about that form of the classics.

In the area of politics, the Irish in this country have made enormous contributions. In my political Party, which is now 101 years old, the first elected Labor member of parliament was an Irishman—born in Ireland—by the name of Thomas Glassey. That tradition has continued to this very day. The Irish national contribution has not been restricted to the Australian Labor Party. The first member for the Federal seat of Kalgoorlie was a John Kirwan, who was born in County Galway. He later went on to sit in the Senate of the University of Western Australia with the founder of that university, also an Irishman, named John Winthrop Hackett.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then there was Hugh Barnes, who was thrown out of Parliament for sedition.
—A good monarchist, too.

—He was very unfairly treated, but let us not dwell too much on the past. A number of Irish names continue to be represented in the Parliament of Australia. Senator Durack is a direct descendant of Patrick Durack, who was a pioneer and a pastoralist—a good name, and a man who made an enormous contribution to this country. His ancestors were born in County Galway.

PARA.TAB: It is with sadness that I record the fact that the denigration of the race is just not justified in this day and age. It was not justified at the time the British were doing it and it is certainly not justified now. I read all of Mr Cobb's article; I did not read just selected parts of it. However, I am not going to respond to each and every comment that he makes in his article. I welcome his article because he is contributing to the debate on whether Australia should be a republic or whether we ought to change our flag.

The question of becoming a republic is not a new thing in this country. I want to quote a short paragraph from an excellent publication, which I would recommend to all honourable senators, called The Light on the Hill, the story of the Australian Labor Party from 1891-1991, by Ross McMullin:

During the 1880s there was a heightened awareness of the distinguishing features of Australia and its people. This nationalism was most frequently felt by radical dreamers. Many of Labor's early leaders were born overseas, mostly in Britain, and they inevitably retain the measure of attachment to the land of their birth; however, nearly all were keenly aware that Britain denied them hope, dignity and opportunity. In their adopted country they could help build a new society without having to overcome centuries of tradition and class rigidities. Further nationalist impetus came from a discernible restlessness with the British government's handling of Australian affairs. Some wanted to sever links with Britain all together: there were a number of Republican groups like McDonald's association in Charters Towers. Both a product and a propagandist of this developing nationalism was the Bulletin, a lively independent, assertively Australian weekly which began in 1880 in Sydney and became extremely popular.
The Bulletin's masthead trumpeted `Australia for the Australians'.

It is not a new debate that we are having in Australia. It is, in my opinion, long overdue. Indeed, I look forward to the year 2001 and the earlier referendum, when I am confident the Australian people will determine that this country will become a republic in its own right. Mr Cobb's article went on:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Keating's vote of no confidence in the Australian flag is a sad indictment of his inability to transcend petty bigotry. His desire to have the Union Jack removed from our flag is less about the need for Australian independence than his own need to divert attention from the real issues affecting our nation. Our national symbol is distinctive, well loved and has served us well.
He is wrong on the first two counts.

It was designed and approved by the Australian people themselves in 1901 from over 30,000 entries. It was not thrust upon us by some anglophile bureaucrat or politician, and most Australians remain proud and protective of it.

He is wrong on that last part as well. Mr Cobb is wrong on a number of the assertions he makes in the article. The design of the flag, which has been altered since then, was the result of a competition that was run prior to 3 September 1901, when the designs of the winning flag were displayed in the Exhibition Building in Melbourne. It was a competition that was run by the Commonwealth, which donated #75 towards the prize; by a newspaper called The Review of Reviews, which also gave #75; and by the Havelock tobacco company, which donated #50. The prize was divided equally between five people, one of whom was from Perth, two from Melbourne, one from Sydney and one from Auckland.

PARA.TAB: I do not know who judged the competition. The winning design was announced by the then Prime Minister, Mr Barton, but it did not actually become official until February 1903, when it was announced in the Commonwealth Gazette that King Edward VII had approved the design of a flag for Australia—this is the British King—and also a flag for the Merchant Navy. In 1951 King George VI approved the recommendation by the Australian Government that the Commonwealth Blue Ensign be adopted as the Australian flag. It was not the people of Australia who made the decision at all.

The flag needs some analysis. Generally, when looking at flags, the distinguished people who can break them down and give advice on them divide a flag into four parts. They call them the canton, the second quarter, the third quarter and the fourth quarter. The canton is described thus:

SPEECH.PARA: The place of honour in a flag is the upper half of the hoist. It is also called the First Quarter and sometimes the Upper Hoist.

On the Australian flag, the thing that is displayed in the upper hoist or the canton of the flag is the Union Jack—the flag of the United Kingdom. That is not ours, and it is certainly the most dominant part of the Australian flag. On the third quarter, the lower half of the hoist, is depicted the seven-pointed star representative of the six States of Australia and the Territories. It is significant that the Union Jack is uppermost, and that the thing that depicts the country of Australia is actually resting below it. The other thing that is featured on the flag is the Southern Cross constellation, and that is actually broken up between the other two quarters of the flag.

PARA.TAB: I welcome, and have welcomed for quite some years, the debate on whether or not Australia should become a republic. I am firmly of the view that we ought to become a republic and that we ought to do it sooner rather than later. I welcome the healthy debate that is happening in our community at the moment and look forward to the debate leading to a referendum long before the year 2001.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Republicanism--Death of F.A. von Hayek

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment briefly on the contribution from Senator McKiernan before I go to the substance of the remarks I wish to make today. I was interested to note that he singled out Mr Cobb for his attack on the Irish. I have not read Mr Cobb's article. Senator McKiernan is entitled to criticise, but he must ask himself whether he is not applying dual standards in this matter. I recall that it was Mr Keating who opened up the debate, with guns blazing on the English. I suspect that, if Mr Keating wishes to play it that way, the community will respond in like manner. That is one aspect of the debate that I think is rather unfortunate and it got it off to a rather poor start. I was waiting to see whether the honourable senator was going to apply a single standard or whether he was going to apply dual standards in relation to the behaviour of Mr Keating and the attack on Mr Cobb.

PARA.TAB: One aspect that worries me a little is that we are bringing in a lot of the prejudices of the old world. I was interested to see whether Senator McKiernan could adduce any reason why we should change what is arguably one of the world's great constitutions. I listened carefully and all I heard was a fairly vigorous attack on the British, the English, and a bit of history. It was certainly interesting. I listened carefully to see whether he could adduce any reason, apart from any natural old world feelings he might have towards the British, why we should change what is by any standards a remarkably successful Constitution.

I was reminded some months ago by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, that Australia is arguably the world's oldest continuing democracy. We have worked with our Constitution for 100 years. When one views the countries around the world that are trying to establish what we established almost a century ago, one wonders whether our founding fathers did not get it pretty right. Like Mr Keating, I happen to take a great pride in the history of our country and its achievements. I suspect that one of our achievements is our Constitution and its role in maintaining the unity of our nation. When people, in a fairly flippant manner and for totally fallacious reasons, attack this achievement, of course people are going to respond. I note that Senator McKiernan welcomes the debate. The debate will certainly continue.

I wish to speak today about a matter that has some meaning to me. It concerns the death on Tuesday of F.A. von Hayek, who died at the age of 92. Hayek was an eminent economist, political philosopher and scientist. He was awarded the Nobel Prize for economics in 1974. Hayek was certainly one of the most influential thinkers of the twentieth century. He ranks with John Stuart Mill and Adam Smith as great liberal thinkers who have had a profound effect upon the development of the liberal democracies of the Western world.

One of the great intellectual battles of the twentieth century has been between liberalism and socialism, between freedom and totalitarianism. As Marx was the inspiration for the socialists, Hayek was the great liberal thinker who helped stop and ultimately turn back the onrush of socialism. In a sense, as Marx was the founder of the old socialist states of eastern Europe, Hayek is in many ways the founding father of the new democracies in Eastern Europe. When Hayek wrote The Road to Serfdom in 1944, socialism dominated the academic world. There was the view that capitalism had had its day. When one opens the covers of The Road to Serfdom, it is interesting to read that it is dedicated to the socialists of all parties.

In the two years I have been in this Parliament, I have heard no-one defend socialism. The dedication that Hayek made has clearly been heard. I have to say that, to the extent that the Labor Party has managed to rid itself of the dead-end of socialism, its members should be profoundly grateful to Hayek. The more they have absorbed the philosophy of Hayek, the more likely the Labor Party is to have a future. It is now almost 50 years since The Road to Serfdom appeared and attacked the basic principles of socialism. The book demonstrated that centralised economic and socialist types of policies were incompatible with democracy and led inexorably to the destruction of individual freedom.

One of Hayek's other great books, The Constitution of Liberty, published in 1960, is still quite widely read. Many of his statements seem particularly relevant to some of the problems we are facing in Australia. For example, on trade unions, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Public policy concerning labour unions has, in little more than a century, moved from one extreme to another. From a state in which little the unions could do was legal if they were not prohibited altogether, we have now reached a state where they have become uniquely privileged institutions to which general laws do not apply. They have become the only important instance in which governments singly fail in their prime function—the prevention of coercion and violence.

It cannot be stressed enough that the coercion that unions have been permitted to exercise contrary to all principles of freedom under the law has primarily been the coercion of fellow workers. Whatever true coercive power the unions may be able to wield over employers is a consequence of this primary power of coercing other workers; the coercion of employers would lose most of its objectionable character if unions were deprived of this power to exact unwilling support.
That is an extract from The Constitution of Liberty by Hayek. He made this quite prescient observation:
. . . .labour unions cannot in the long run substantially alter the real level of wages that all workers can earn and are, in fact, more likely to lower than to raise them. . .

It is interesting that one of the proudest boasts of the Labor Government under this accord is that it has been able to hold, and in a number of years cut, the level of real wages. Hayek was remarkable not only for the profound defence of the free society but also for his willingness to help organise to promote his views. In 1947 he formed the Mont Pelerin Society and he helped found an influential think-tank, the Institute of Economic Affairs, in London. I can well recall when I was at the university—and perhaps Senator Ray can recall it, too—how avidly the IEA pamphlets were read.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that Hayek had a very important influence on the thinking and work of free market think-tanks in this country. My father, who was one of the founders of the Institute of Public Affairs, wrote a tribute to Hayek that was published in the Australian yesterday. He recalled about The Road to Serfdom:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . immediately became the bible of those of us who clung to a belief in a liberal philosophy and a market economy in the face of mounting assaults from academic economists and socialist politicians.
He said that The Road to Serfdom was a beam of light on an otherwise dark and threatening horizon.

PARA.TAB: Hayek visited Australia in 1976. His visit was sponsored by the Institute of Public Affairs. Hayek and his wife stayed for a number of days at my father's home in Mount Macedon. He was at that time 77, still physically fit and intellectually vigorous. As an indication of Hayek's breadth of learning, my father recalls that he took a copy of Tolstoy's War and Peace from the bookshelves and commented, holding the book in his hand, that this was the best translation of Tolstoy's great work that he had read. He said that he had read War and Peace in a number of translations and was about to read it again. As my father commented, most of us would have been pleased that we had read War and Peace once.

Hayek also mentioned to my father that, soon after the publication of The Road to Serfdom, he encountered Winston Churchill at a function. Churchill told him that he had just read his book, The Road to Serfdom, and Churchill said to Hayek, `You need not worry, the British people will never travel down that road'. Churchill was wrong. The fact of the matter is that the British people did start to travel down that road. In Australia Chifley was determined to lead Australia down the socialist road which, Hayek warned us, would lead us to socialism and serfdom. Fortunately, there were individuals and governments prepared to resist this trend. Hayek's warnings were heeded.

Another organisation closely associated with von Hayek was the Centre for Independent Studies in Sydney. Hayek was a member of the centre's advisory board from 1977. Greg Lindsay, a friend of mine who is Director of the Centre for Independent Studies and who happens to be a prominent member of the Mont Pelerin Society, was able to organise for that society the Sydney conference in 1985 and the Christchurch conference in 1989.
