Greg Lindsay acknowledges the great impact that Hayek's thinking had on him personally and on the work of the Centre for Independent Studies.

The world today would probably be a very different place if it had not been for the work of F.A. von Hayek. It is therefore appropriate that his life's work be recognised in the Australian Senate today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the matters of public interest debate to bring to the attention of listeners some of the scaremongering tactics—
—You are not on radio.

—All right, not on radio. I will put it out in a press release and the honourable senator can listen to it because it will do him good. He would not be part of the scaremongering tactics in what is going on, would he? He has a little bit of honesty in him, so he will put out a press release too, and he will say that in fact they have got it wrong.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer to the scare tactics, the misinformation, being perpetuated in the Australian community at the present time. I will refer particularly to some of the Government's masters, or what I call the stooges of the Labor Party. First of all, I wish to refer to the Electrical Trades Union and what it has recently published in its magazine. In that magazine a Christmas basket of 26 items was selected, and it was said, quite correctly, that the bill for that would come to $2,168.58. Then it was claimed, quite incorrectly, that under Fightback it would cost $2,491.57. In doing so, the union made a fundamental flaw and attempted to mislead the Australian public.

Where did it mislead? It did not take into account that under Fightback the wholesale sales tax would be removed; nor did the Electrical Trades Union take into account the impact, or the cascading effect, of abolishing fuel excise and payroll tax and of our tax cuts when 95 per cent of taxpayers will pay 30c or less in the dollar. All taxpayers will benefit under our Fightback program.

TALK.START.PARA: —And so will pensioners.

—And pensioners, yes. That is quite different to the Government's proposal in the One Nation statement whereby low income earners get no relief. It is worth having a look at that, because we find that under Fightback the tax-free threshold will be raised from $5,400 to $7,000 but that under the Government's One Nation there is no increase in the tax-free threshold.

PARA.TAB: If we look a little further we see that, under Fightback, people earning between $7,000 and $20,700 will be paying income tax of 16.2 per cent in the dollar. We find that under the One Nation program, there is no tax relief. If we examine the ETU's proposals, we find that when we deduct the wholesale sales tax, which applies incidentally to 21 of the 26 items, we have to deduct $285.93. That is the Government's GST—the Government's own secret tax. The package without the wholesale sales tax comes to $1,880.65. Under Fightback, with the GST, it amounts to $2,162.75, which is $3.83 cheaper than it is with the wholesale sales tax items in. One has also to add to that the fact that fuel excise is removed and payroll tax is removed. The cascading impact on these items will mean that that package will be even cheaper than that straight analysis and, because of that, it will have the capacity to generate more jobs.

The other point that needs to be brought out, in terms of this misleading, incorrect article and the statements that are being made by the stooges of the Labor Party, is the comment made by Mr Peter Tighe, the secretary of the ETU. He said, `If Hewson is serious about 15 per cent tax, why does he not legislate?'. Let me inform Mr Tighe, and members on the other side of this chamber, that we are legislating for the 15 per cent. This says that we cannot trust the Electrical Trades Union to give a fair representation of the facts, in terms of the current economic packages before us, any more than we can trust the current Government.

I want to go a little further and refer to the scare tactics and the scaremongering that the Seamen's Union is involving itself in. I particularly want to refer to some material that was put around the electorate of Swan in Western Australia last week and also the Ashburton State electorate. It just shows that Mr Beazley, the honourable member for Swan, is running scared when he has to have stooges going around the electorate delivering the sort of material we are seeing. What we see here, and it is here for all to see, is a simulated $5 note, except that the $5 has been scratched out and $4.25 has been put in. A group of items has been selectively chosen on which they have misrepresented the price, in terms of the goods and services tax or our tax reform proposals.

Once again, like the Electrical Trades Union, the Government has chosen not to make any allowance for the changes in wholesale sales tax, the payroll tax, the training levy or any of the other secret Government taxes I have already mentioned. The shopping basket that has been chosen has no direct wholesale sales tax on it. The union has tried to be too smart for its own good. It has not taken into account—and I am sure that members of the Government are intelligent enough to know it—the fact that under our package the indirect impact of the wholesale sales tax on the manufacture of these goods—butter, sugar, potatoes, bread, et cetera—flows through in the price. In addition, the wrappings that go around these items, whether it be the butter, the sugar, the potatoes, the coffee, the bread—one could go on—all have wholesale sales tax applied to them at different rates. So there is another total misrepresentation of the facts with regard to this matter.

They then proceed with a further simulation of a $5 note and pretend that it will be worth only $4.25 when we come into government. How wrong they are. But worse than that, Mr Beazley's stooges make further misrepresentations. They say, `Alston—no security for social security', which is a lie; `Dr Woods—no Medicare', which is a lie; `McLachlan—multinationals before farmers', which is another lie. One could go on with what they say about Mr Howard, Mr Fischer and Mr Reith.

I want to make particular reference to Mr McLachlan because of my personal interest in farming and the close association I have with the mining industry. I point out very clearly that under our proposals, which are not included in the Government's One Nation program, we will be removing close to $2 billion of the input taxes from the farming and mining industries—the very people the Seamen's Union is talking about, the very industries that provide most of the wages that keep members of the Seamen's Union in their jobs. This five-dollar note is a total misrepresentation. In fact, it is quite bizarre.

If we do not create a climate in this country in which our miners, our farmers, our manufacturers and others in the community are profitable, if we do not take the input taxes away from them, these very people, the members of the Seamen's Union, will have fewer and fewer jobs. By removing the input taxes such as the fuel excise, the payroll tax and the wholesale sales tax, our manufacturers will become more internationally competitive, whether they are manufacturing through value adding or whether they are manufacturing through mining or producing wheat, wool, cauliflowers or whatever the agricultural product might be.

One other aspect I wish to raise is the international signal that this sends. There would be no Seamen's Union unless there were goods and services going across the wharves. Our exports particularly are what provide them with the opportunity for work. What they have done in this article is to send a false signal to investors into this country, saying that a coalition government would devalue the dollar and lower the value of any investment they might make in this country. That really is quite bizarre. It is quite unnecessary. It is the wrong signal to be sending out of this country. It is a totally irresponsible act. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation, Senator Collins, from the Northern Territory, who is at the table, has a very close interest in the capacity of the Northern Territory to export goods to get development investment into the Northern Territory and in a number of other matters. I hope he will dissociate himself from anybody who tried to present, incorrectly, to the Australian public or to the businesses of this country that there was an endeavour to erode the value of our currency and of our base.

I believe that in the lead-up to the next election we can expect to see many attempts to mislead the Australian public on a variety of issues. I would say to honourable senators on the other side that there is no doubt in my mind that the Electrical Trades Union and the Seaman's Union are the stooges of the Labor Party. I have no doubt that they, or a number of them, and Mr Beazley in Swan knew that this misinformation was going to be put around. They have a responsibility, as elected members of the Australian Parliament, at least to bring a little bit of honesty to the current debate in terms of the economic direction of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I think Senator Crane's wish to bring honesty to the political debate over the next 12 months is a forlorn hope which will not be fulfilled. One need look only to the track record of this Labor Government in terms of honesty. We all remember the promises that no child would live in poverty by the year 1990, that there would be no recession, that we would have a soft landing, and the promise made by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, about a year ago: ` Don't worry. The recession will be over. It will not be too bad. It is only a bit of a downturn; she'll be right'.

PARA.TAB: When it comes to honesty—which is, in politics, only a relative judgment of someone's credentials—certainly the Federal Government has proved to the Australian people over the last year that it would be very low down on a relative scale. This was reinforced for me on a visit to Karratha last week, when I picked up a copy of the Karratha Guardian, an august publication which serves some very important people in the north of Western Australia—a region, as Senator Crane said, that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation (Senator Collins), is very familiar with. I was horrified to read an analysis of the GST's impact on the north prepared by that well-known economic analyst, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Graeme Campbell, and a State candidate for the Australian Labor Party—although he is trying to hide the fact that he is a candidate for the Labor Party—a Mr Fred Riebeling.

They have done an analysis of the impact of the GST on a special little basket of groceries in a Karratha grocery store. They have the audacity, or the stupidity, to say,` Let us use the Commonwealth Treasury figures to show what the GST will do to prices'. They have got the price of a litre of milk. Have they applied Treasury's analysis of what the GST will do to a bottle of milk? That is what they said to the people of Karratha that they would do. What percentage did they choose to put on the price of a bottle of milk? They chose 15 per cent. What did they do to the price of 500 grams of butter? Did they use the Commonwealth Treasury analysis to say what the price of 500 grams of butter will be in Karratha after the GST policy is introduced? No. They added 15 per cent. And what did they do to bread, steak, fish and eggs? They did the same thing to all of them. The people of Karratha are being misled by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie and this would-be candidate for the Labor Party in the by-election in Ashburton—

TALK.START.PARA: —And on flavoured milk we will be taking their 10 per cent sales tax off.

—We will get to that. Of course, they do not talk about that sort of thing. They come up with all sorts of spurious claims. Clearly, we are not going to have a rational or sensible debate on taxation policy between now and the next election. There is no way that the Labor Party can allow that to occur because its very own Prime Minister, who was the greatest supporter of the consumption tax in the Australian political debate only four or five years ago, knows damned well that if we have a rational, sensible debate about taxation policy, then the Australian people will support the shifting of the tax emphasis away from income and onto consumption to encourage savings and to create a fairer system where people know what tax they are paying.

PARA.TAB: I heard of an example this morning concerning someone up north who was walking through a shopping centre in Karratha. One of my Liberal friends in Karratha, of whom there are many, went up to a lady in the supermarket and said, `Do you realise that the price of a toothbrush will come down once the GST comes in?' She said, `No, it will not. It will go up by 15 per cent'. The opportunity and the challenge that the Liberal Party has are to explain to people that prices will not go up by 15 per cent. Some prices will rise and some prices will fall.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get rid of the 20 per cent sales tax on soap, detergents, toilet paper.

—There are, as Senator Baume says, a number of items very important to many people which will come down quite considerably: for example, things such as soap, which is taxed at 20 per cent; shampoo, taxed at 20 per cent; a hair comb—probably something that Senator Baume does not use very often—taxed at 20 per cent; toilet paper, taxed at 20 per cent; toothpaste, taxed at 20 per cent; and deodorant, taxed at 20 per cent. All of those taxes come off. The people of Karratha do not even know that those things are taxed because this wholesale sales tax is a hidden tax. If this Government were dinkum, it would actually put the tax on the price tag to show the rip-off it is using. Of course, the Federal member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Campbell—my namesake, unfortunately—and the Labor Party candidate for the seat of Ashburton, Mr Riebeling, may not know what price effect the tax has on soap and shampoo and these other toiletries. Indeed, they may not even use these items, so they may not care. But the tax is the important thing.

PARA.TAB: The other very important thing for the people of Karratha to understand—and it is something I am sure that Mr Graeme Campbell would understand—is the impact of the coalition's taxation policies on the cost of transport to remote regions. It is something that does need close analysis. Indeed, the best people to go to for analysis of the costs are the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) or the Prime Minister. I asked Senator Button a question many months ago—in fact, on 19 December—and he gave me the response on Monday, which is about Senator Button's average track record at the moment. The question related to the impact of the wholesale sales tax on the transport sector. My own specific interest, and the interest of my Western Australian Senate colleagues, is in the impact of the tax on transport to remote areas, and I am sure that is a matter Senator Collins would have concern with.

I raised the question with Senator Button because I had had faxed to my office—incorrectly, I think—a paper prepared by a Caucus committee on transport policy which sought from the then Treasurer, Mr Kerin, some guidance on whether or not the Government would seek to change its policy on the impact of wholesale sales tax on the transport sector. That report, which quoted some figures from the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics, showed some indicative figures of the impact of wholesale sales tax on transport. It showed that wholesale sales tax adds approximately 2 per cent to the cost of operating a two-axle rigid truck. It also showed that there is about a 3.8 per cent impact on large articulated trucks and 4.5 per cent for a triple roadtrain. That cost—the impact of the wholesale sales tax on transport—cascades through the system of producing goods and delivering those goods to the end consumers; and, of course, the impact is increased as we move further and further away from the place of production.

In towns such as Karratha or Kununurra in north-western Australia, that wholesale sales tax has an enormous impact on the price of the goods when they reach the supermarket shelf, where the poor electors of Ashburton and the people who live in Karratha and north-western Australia generally—poor because of the impact of Labor Party policies over eight years—have actually to pay for the goods. More specifically, rather than talking in terms of percentages in relation to the impact of the tax on the price of food in the north-west, I spoke to one of the transport operators in Perth yesterday to ask what were the transport costs on food which travelled the route to Karratha. According to this transport operator, 22c per kilo of food is the transport component of getting that food up to Karratha.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on what it is.

—Of course it does, but in terms of a rate per kilo, which is an important measure—I am sure the Minister would agree—the rate was about 22c per kilo. The impact of the coalition's tax reform policies on that 22c, by reducing the cost of fuel alone from roughly 68c a litre to 42c a litre—that is, a reduction of 26c a litre for transport operators—will reduce the cost of transport per kilo of food by some 27 per cent, or over a quarter.

PARA.TAB: That does not take into account the impact of the cost of purchasing the rigs, or purchasing the major capital items such as batteries and tyres, and the other heavy capital costs of running a transport rig. That impact on the fuel cost will reduce the cost of delivering groceries to the supermarket in Karratha. Clearly, Mr Riebeling and Mr Campbell do not visit it very often.

I make these points because it is very hard to analyse the specific impacts of tax proposals in far north Australia. But bear in mind that the wholesale sales tax system, on the admission of the Prime Minister, on the admission of Senator Button, and on the admission of the Caucus committee that is responsible for this, cascades through the system and hurts people who live further away from the place of production. Under this Government, we have a tax system, an indirect tax system, a hidden tax system, which severely hurts the people living in remote areas. With the goods and services tax, reducing income tax rates and placing the taxation emphasis on indirect tax has enormous benefits for the north of Australia. They are benefits that the Minister at the table will not admit because it is politically not sensible to do so.

As I said at the beginning of this speech in supporting Senator Crane's calls for an honest and rational debate on the effects of the various taxation policies, it is indeed naive and stupid to suggest that this Labor Party and this Labor Government will allow any rational debate to take place. We must ensure that we fight fire with fire. If Ministers and Labor Party candidates in by-elections are going to go around to supermarkets and say, `This thing is going to go up by 15 per cent', then we as the proponents of the goods and services tax—the tax reform package—must go around to the supermarkets and say about cans of deodorant, toothbrushes and toothpaste, `These things will go down'.

In the long run, we must not only ensure that every Australian knows that the general inflation impact on the price of goods and services will not be in the order of 15 per cent—as these dubious characters from the other side of the chamber will go around Australia saying—but we must also support the Treasury's findings that the price impact will be somewhere in the region of 3.8 to 4 per cent. Of course, that is more than compensated for by the increases in welfare payments and the reductions in taxation.

We must ensure as an Opposition and as proponents of a radical tax reform policy that Australian citizens know that the prices of goods will not increase by the rate that the Labor Party is saying. They must look at the more serious issue—the issue of honesty in politics, an issue that should be very important. They must ask themselves whether they have been misled by this Government, misled by the Labor Government in Western Australia, misled by the candidate for Ashburton, and misled by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie over the past eight or nine years—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Prime Minister.

—The Prime Minister and the whole lot of them. They must then ask themselves whether all these people are going to mislead the people and tell little porkies to the people of Karratha, little porky pies to the people of Ashburton, little porky pies to the people in the electorate of Wills about what our tax policies will do. If they are going to tell them little porkies now, can the people ever trust them again? Of course, the answer to that question is no, we cannot trust these people. They will go around and they will lie and they will lie, and they will seek to win elections by telling these sorts of mistruths and porky pies, banning advertising because they do not want the truth to be told. I would love to be able to put some ads on television up in Karratha tonight and tell them the truth about Mr Riebeling and Mr Campbell, about their strange mathematics and their obvious aversion to using toiletries, but I cannot do that because of this Government's legislation.

PARA.TAB: The truth is that the people of Australia must face the reality, and that is that this Government and the Government of Western Australia are dishonest. They cannot be trusted and they should be forced from power. The first election where they should show this Government what to do is the by-election in Ashburton on 4 April. They should elect our candidate, Joy West, with a huge swing. Then a week later they should be electing the Liberal candidate in the seat of Wills, and sending a very strong message to Canberra that we have had enough of dishonesty; we have had enough of lies. We want a bit of truth, and we want a bit of sensible public policy. (Time expired)
Motion by (Senator Collins) agreed to:
(1)That discussion of Matters of Public Interest be not further proceeded with this day.

(2)That intervening business be postponed till after consideration of Government Business orders of the day No. 4 (Arts, Sport, Environment and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1992) and No. 5 (Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991).
(3)That this order have effect till 2.00 p.m. this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: ARTS, SPORT, ENVIRONMENT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 3 March, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Arts, Sport, Environment and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 is an omnibus Bill, and I intend to direct my attention to the part referring to the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988. The Legislative Assembly for the Australian Capital Territory, in the 1990 report by its Select Committee on Self-Government in the ACT, in part addressed the issue of planning. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Capital Development Commission (NCDC) has long expounded the view that the special planning, development, construction and administrative standards for Canberra cannot be separated in either functional or geographical terms. On this basis, the NCDC argued that it would be impossible to hand over complete control of these activities to a territorial government.

Because of the `duality of national and community interests', the Select Committee further stressed that, in the area of overall planning `there should also be involvement by elected community representation'. It said that it was therefore essential that there be adequate institutional arrangements for liaison and cooperation to closely coordinate and integrate the national community functions of the ACT.

PARA.TAB: As has been noted in another place, the purpose of the amendment is to introduce a ministerial power of direction in relation to the draft Territory plan, where the Territory Planning Authority continues to object to any aspect of the draft plan prepared by the National Capital Planning Authority, and to allow regulations to be made enabling the NCPA to charge fees for planning and related approvals. This power is to be limited to the recovery costs reasonably associated with planning approvals and not to be set at such levels as to amount to a taxation.

As this is a `housekeeping' piece of legislation which will improve ACT planning and land management, the Opposition does not dispute the Bill. In fact, it has set out to solve an impasse between the ACT Assembly and the National Capital Planning Authority. An amendment proposed by the Opposition in another place was successful and provided for the Minister, rather than just making a determination where there was an impasse, to consult with the ACT Assembly. We are pleased that that was approved.

As I understand it, the Democrats also intend to move an amendment in the committee stage. The Opposition has no difficulty with the proposed amendment by the Democrats, which ensures that, after consultation, written direction to the NCPA should be made available to the public through the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Arts, Sport, Environment and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, passed by the House of Representatives on 26 February and now in the Senate for its agreement, relates to seven Acts administered in the ASET portfolio. The Australian Democrats support this Bill. However, I am to speak only on the section that relates to the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988 and the proposed amendments to this section by the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: The ACT component of this Bill seeks to provide for notification and consultation in respect of objections received by the Minister to the draft National Capital Plan. In addition, an amendment to section 53 of the principal Act provides for the charging and recovery of fees in relation to expenses incurred by the National Capital Planning Authority in the granting of approvals under the Act.

The Australian Democrats will be supporting the amendments moved by the Government and the Opposition, which have been incorporated into the reprinted Bill before us today. An important factor that I think this Parliament needs to remember is that the ACT, having now been given self-government, must have some ongoing control of its planning activities. The Federal Minister cannot and must not act in splendid isolation from the ACT parliament. Therefore, it is vital that ministerial discretion be checked and balanced by the duly elected representatives of the Australian Capital Territory.

The Opposition's amendment to the proposed new subsection 20A(2) obliges the Minister to consult with the Executive of the ACT, and we support that consultation process. We also intend to add our own amendment to the proposed new section 20, with the addition of subsections (3) and (4), which will oblige the Minister to publish his direction to the executive in the Government Notices Gazette within seven days of his giving that direction and to table it in each House of Parliament within six sitting days after the Minister gives that direction. I commend the amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are several amendments dealt with in this Arts, Sport, Environment and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. The first one has been dealt with in this debate, that is, the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act amendment. Other amendments are to the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990, the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981, the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, the Norfolk Island Act 1979 and the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1986.

PARA.TAB: Very briefly, the Opposition has no objections to these amendments and will not be opposing them. However, there are some points which do concern us and which I should make. In the first place, the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990 is not an Act that has been around for a great deal of time and yet one notices, once again, drafting errors. Subsections 65A(1), (2) and (3) have to be inserted to provide the Agency with the standard taxation exemptions under Commonwealth, State and Territory law that were simply not given in the original legislation.

I just want to stress that we have been inundated at various times of the year, particularly towards the close of each session, with legislation that consistently requires fixing up because it has been made a mess of by this Government; and here we have yet another example of the need to correct quite new legislation simply because there is an error.

There is also a matter I should raise in passing: new paragraph 70(1)(c) empowers the Agency to delegate the Agency's powers to `any employee of the Agency', as is now able to be delegated to the chairperson or the chief executive. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has some views on that kind of delegation, and I just mention that in passing.

On the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act, new section 21B allows the Committee to approve a recommendation or report without the need to convene a meeting, and the new section requires all the members of the Committee, except those with a direct or indirect pecuniary interest, to sign the documents supporting the recommendation or report, with the recommendation or report to take effect on the date of the last signature. There is one problem about this: although the clear intention is that this should relate to those meetings of the Committee which take place on telephone link-ups, it does not specifically say so. In other words, there could be a situation, if this legislation is read as the words say, where people could agree in writing to a proposal, never having heard the case against it. That is simply intolerable and is not what is intended, as I understand, in the legislation.

It seems to me that it would have been better had the legislation clearly referred to such gatherings on the telephone, where the case for and against the Committee agreeing to something would of necessity be stated. We require, and I am certain that we will get, an assurance from the Government that that is the intention of the legislation. There are various other matters I would like to raise; I have not got time. The Opposition generally supports this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply rise to indicate that the Government supports the amendments the Democrats are moving to this Bill; and I do give Senator Baume, having discussed this matter with him privately, the assurance he is seeking that that situation will not occur as far as the Government is concerned.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind Senator Button that the now Prime Minister said in Parliament on 9 April last year that this Government's policy would see the tariff wall go to 5 per cent and then `see it abolished'. I ask the Minister whether that is still Government policy.

—This Government is the first government in Australian history since the Second World War which has been a low tariff government, and it is the first government since the Second World War which has done anything about tariffs.
—What about Gough Whitlam? You couldn't forget him, could you?
—I have not forgotten him. What I mean is that this Government has done something about tariffs as a comprehensive industry policy.
—Across the board is not comprehensive?

—No, it is not comprehensive and it is not planned or considered. Indeed, the results of that were seen at the time to the extent that they apparently frightened the Liberal Government from doing anything about tariffs over eight years. In so far as Government policy is concerned, the policy of the Government is articulated in terms of tariffs for TCF to the year 2000, for the passenger motor vehicle industry to the year 2000 and for other industry until 1996, reaching a level of 5 per cent for most industries at that time. There is no intention on the part of the Government to proceed beyond that point unless there is a dramatic change in circumstances in the international tariff regime.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of comments by the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia regarding the operation of monetary policy in this country? Does the Minister agree that an inflexible monetary policy is inappropriate in the real world?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Phillips, the soon to retire Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, yesterday confirmed the central bank's rejection of the coalition's monetary policy proposals. Mr Phillips, who is a man for whom I personally have great admiration, although he has not always been an unadorned admirer of this Government, or me, for that matter, has been seen as the Reserve Bank's chief anti-inflation hawk—the hardliner against inflation. I agree with that.

PARA.TAB: I recently described inflation at a metal trades industry forum as the worst enemy of Australian exporters. Inflation cannot be allowed to exceed that of our trading partners or we lose competitiveness. That is why the Government had an agreement with the ACTU to target wages to match the inflation rate of our major trading partners—a most important and historic agreement in terms of this country being able to face up to the challenges of the 1990s.

Sadly, the Opposition would never be in a position to negotiate such an agreement. It has no wages policy, and would be forced to use higher interest rates to control inflation, as the shadow Treasurer, Mr Reith, recently admitted. The coalition policy of an independent Reserve Bank with a charter to target inflation at nought to 2 per cent is on the lunatic fringe of flat earth economics. That is the message which can be distilled from the speech made by the Deputy Governor. His words were:

ANSWER.PARA: A country as exposed as Australia to the outrageous fortunes of external events needs a degree of flexibility in policy administration.

The Opposition's inflexible monetary policy fails to recognise that the real world economy does not costlessly adjust to external shocks. The Opposition makes the same mistake as it does with its tariff policy. It was not content with opposing every cut in interest rates in the last 18 months; it now wants to condemn Australians to a policy that will inescapably lead to higher interest rates. It remains the party of high interest rates in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce why Australia's real interest rates are higher than those of our major trading partners.
—The technical answer to that is that the difference between nominal interest rates and the inflation rate is a wider gap than in most other countries.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister explain the Government's record over recent years. For example, in his period as Minister the real interest rate difference in Australia was 7 per cent compared to 3 per cent during the Fraser years. Does this show the failure of the Government's economic policies?
—They do not show anything of the kind. The Fraser years were associated with a period of no structural adjustment in this country, no changes in tariff policy, high inflation, and they were all—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The gap was small because the Fraser Government's inflation rate was so high; that was the reason. Senator Tierney should look at the levels of investment, year by year, through the period of the Fraser Government and compare them with recent years and he will see the answer to the problem.
—Half your rate.

—There is a lot of noise on the other side about this issue, but that is true, that is what happened in those desultory Fraser years. Senator Tierney can pluck out one figure, one indicator, and put it up at Question Time, but it means nothing in terms of the total picture.

PARA.TAB: As I have already said in answer to an earlier question, the policy of those opposite throughout the last 18 months has been to condemn every cut in interest rates; that is what their Leader has done. Senator Tierney then gets up and asks, `Why is the real interest rate higher in Australia than in other countries?'. If those opposite had been in office, presumably nominal interest rates would have been higher. That is what his Leader has consistently said during the last 18 months. I suppose real interest rates would have been lower because their inflation rate would have been higher as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade been drawn to press reports indicating evidence that the Burmese authorities are planning to release and expel Aung San Suu Kyi from the country? Can the Minister confirm these reports and indicate the Government's attitude to this possibility and any action it intends to take?

—I have asked our Embassy in Rangoon to confirm those reports. We do not yet have confirmation of them. We would be concerned, of course, if they were found to be true. We would view this as a very clear attempt to isolate Aung San Suu Kyi from the political process in that country in an utterly unacceptable way.

PARA.TAB: We have repeatedly called for the Burmese authorities to free Aung San Suu Kyi, and all other political prisoners for that matter, in that country. She is still regarded as a crucially important political figure in the process of democratic reform by both the Burmese people and the international community as a whole, with that stature of course much reinforced by the recent awarding of a Nobel Peace Prize.

The stupid thing, I guess, about any such move by the Burmese authorities is that it would be utterly unproductive from their point of view. Expulsion of her would be utterly unlikely to diminish her stature as a democratic leader either within the country or internationally. Her expulsion would make an even greater nonsense of the Burmese regime's claims that it is still working towards the implementation of democratic processes in that country.

The situation in Burma in a number of different ways continues to deteriorate. It is a matter of great concern to our Government, to governments right around the world and, increasingly, of course, to governments in our own South East Asian region. One of the more encouraging features of recent times is the way in which the countries of South East Asia, the ASEAN group, are increasingly demonstrating an interest and concern in Burma and making clear that concern to the Burmese authorities.

I call again on the Burmese Government—as I have on innumerable occasions, with a conspicuous lack of success so far—to enter into discussions with all major political leaders in that country to bring about democratic reform and peaceful change. In the meantime, we will continue to consult with other interested governments on the most effective ways of bringing pressure to bear on that regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: does the Prime Minister intend to fully represent the concerns of the Australian community about human rights on his forthcoming visit to Indonesia; does he acknowledge that improved ties with the Indonesian Government cannot be achieved by playing down or ignoring fundamental differences; and, in particular, will he stress to President Suharto the fact that, under international law, peaceful campaigns for self-determination are legitimate forms of political expression for which charges of subversion, such as those laid against survivors of the Dili massacre, are totally inappropriate?

—The Prime Minister will be visiting Indonesia later next month. The prime purpose of his visit is to establish a firm base for a long term development of Australian-Indonesian relations, both in the bilateral domain and as partners in the Asia-Pacific region. The Prime Minister will find appropriate opportunities during his meetings with Indonesian leaders to discuss human rights issues, including the situation in East Timor.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister, of course, recognises that, while we have an extraordinary duality of interest with Indonesia, there are some differences which cannot be played down and have to be addressed in the context of such a visit. I just make the point that Australia and Indonesia share major political, economic and strategic interests, both in terms of trade and in terms of our cooperation in APEC—a process which Australia helped establish—and the Government is committed to the development of a long term cooperative relationship between the two countries.

In so far as the tragic events in Dili last year are concerned, as honourable senators know, Senator Evans made a visit to Indonesia in December where the Government's position was fully explained to the Indonesian authorities. I myself was there in December. I had discussions with a number of Indonesian Ministers about the issue. Senator Evans was there, I think a week later, and fully conveyed the Government's position.

Let me say that the Indonesian response has been far different, I believe, from what it might have been if those visits and other representations to the Indonesian Government had not taken place. The Indonesian response to events in Dili is infinitely more credible than it might have been or than was suggested in late November by some Indonesian spokesmen. Certainly, the Indonesian Government has indicated an acceptance of responsibility for what happened in Dili.

Australian policy towards East Timor is premised on both recognition of Indonesian sovereignty and concern for the welfare of the East Timorese people. I must say that in Jakarta, certainly in my own experience and I understand in Senator Evans's experience, there is a willingness to address some of those fundamental welfare problems which basically arise from the lack of economic viability of East Timor. There is probably a new willingness to address them that was not there before.

This Government has urged the Indonesian Government to pursue a policy of long term reconciliation with the people of East Timor, and we are continuing to monitor closely the response to the Dili killings, including the trials of the protesters against whom charges have been laid, and to whom Senator Bourne refers. The Government has called for those brought to court to be treated humanely, given access to proper legal representation and a fair trial. It is not appropriate for me or anybody else here to comment on the details of the particular cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation. I have had many questions directed to me regarding local ownership of aerodromes. Can the Minister give details of a Government decision in the One Nation statement which will provide additional funding to accelerate the aerodrome local ownership plan?
—Mr President, the Opposition might as well give up. It cannot do anything to hurt me today.
—Why not?
—Having watched Ian Botham getting caught behind for a duck last night, nothing can touch me for 24 hours.

PARA.TAB: In the One Nation statement the Government has decided to provide an additional $27.5m to accelerate the transfer of Commonwealth aerodromes and withdrawal of airports from the aerodrome local ownership plan, the ALOP. This funding provides grants for airport works and capitalised social benefits subsidies.

Since August 1990 the Government has embarked on a program of encouraging aerodromes that are receiving funding under the ALOP to accept full responsibility for managing and locating their airports. With the additional funding that has been granted by the Government in the One Nation statement, the transfer and withdrawal process is now scheduled to be completed in 1992-93; that is, one year ahead of the original scheduled date. Early completion of this program will also follow the phasing out of that component of the avgas excise, which is approximately $3m a year, and which is currently attributed to the Department of Transport and Communications.

I welcome the statement released in the last few days by the shadow Minister for aviation, Mr Jull, where he said that the coalition would continue the withdrawal program from the ALOP. At the same time he announced—and I noticed that Senator Macdonald put out a press release from north Queensland welcoming this extraordinary statement—that the coalition would establish a proposal whereby, if there were airports that could not be sustained under this withdrawal, the coalition `may provide them with financial assistance'.

In contrast, the Government's policy is not only to clearly define the community service obligations that we have to these remote communities and to provide a formula for applying for community assistance under them but we have funded them specifically to the tune of $63m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Minister aware that, during the life of this Labor Government between the years 1983-84 and 1991-92, the average annual rate of productivity growth has fallen from an eight-year annual average of 1.76 per cent to 0.7 per cent?
—What a record!

—It is a very poor record, Senator Kemp. Is the Minister also aware that Professor Barry Hughes, a former adviser to former Treasurer Keating, in a recent paper for the Committee for Economic Development of Australia, described the situation as `stagnant', and described union promises of costs offsets since 1987 as a `sham'? Does the Minister agree with Professor Hughes or does he believe that the productivity performance under Labor Government policies has been satisfactory?

—I do not know what measure of productivity the honourable senator is using in addressing this question to me—whether he is using multi-factor productivity or not, I do not know. There has always been a technical argument about the measure of productivity. I used to have it with Senator Chaney every week in here during the 1980s, and I do not want to recycle that argument.

PARA.TAB: Productivity is determined on a number of factors. It is measured differently in different countries and is particularly dependent on whether employment is rising or declining, and whether the economy is in growth or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all know that.
—Well, I will sit down. If I am not going to be able to answer the question the way I want to, I will sit down.
—I beg your pardon.

—That is right. As distinct from the late 1970s and early 1980s, when growing unemployment was developing in this country, the 1980s was a period of high growth and increasing employment until the 1990 recession commenced. That is true. As we come out of the recession, the productivity measure will be considerably increased—although not according to the Fightback! document, which has miserable productivity figures for the next decade. As the economy comes out of the recession, there will be a considerable improvement in productivity.

—Has the Minister for Industrial Relations noted the statement by the Australian Bureau of Statistics this morning that the annual growth rate in average weekly earnings is 4.2 per cent? Has the Minister noted that the Bureau has warned that the earnings growth was also influenced by compositional changes in the work force? Is it not necessary to acknowledge this and to indicate to the Senate that in a period of recession average weekly earnings tend to increase because of the fact that persons on low wages become unemployed? Finally, do actual award wages grow at the same rate as average weekly earnings or is it a fact, for example, that over the last seven years the tradesman's rate has declined in real terms by 14 per cent?

—I cannot verify that last statistic—whether or not the tradesman's rate has declined by about 14 per cent as a proportion of overall earnings. I am aware that the rate of the metal trades fitter, which for a long time has been the benchmark rate for other wage and salary earners, has declined but I am not in a position to confirm that as the accurate figure.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Bureau of Statistics average weekly earnings figures for November have been released in their final form. The summary of findings says in respect of employees' average weekly total earnings that the percentage change for all persons was 2.2 per cent for November 1991 from November 1990. It says that for full time adult average weekly ordinary time earnings the change was 4.2 per cent.

In his question, Senator Harradine referred to the compositional change factors that affect this outcome. It is true that the effect of a recession in the labour force creates two clear changes. The first one is usually a tendency for workers who are full time employed on ordinary standard hours to be made part time as a prelude often, unfortunately—but not always—to redundancy. That, of course, reduces the amount of earnings that they receive. But they are, nonetheless, counted as an unit in the work force.

The other compositional factor is that if there are retrenchments or redundancies in a workplace, the tendency universally seems to be to retrench those on the lowest pay first, meaning that the average income per employed person increases. They are compositional changes which affect the outcome of these figures.

The increase in the average award index for November was 2.9 per cent. So we cannot say that there is a direct correlation between average weekly earnings and average award increases. Average weekly earnings include all earnings, such as overtime, penalty rates and things of that nature. Average weekly award earnings reflect the base rate earnings at the award level. Traditionally, in the run-in to Christmas—and this is again represented in these figures this year—there is an increase as overtime picks up in terms of average weekly earnings over average award earnings.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to yesterday's lifting of the scales from the Prime Minister's eyes on his Government's tariff reduction policy and his conversion on the road to the Wills by-election. Does the Prime Minister's conversion extend to other industries which, like the Australian tyre industry, are also internationally competitive, such as the sugar industry, one of the most efficient in the world, and the dairy industry, which gives consumers the cheapest milk in the world? Will the Prime Minister give these industries an assurance that the tariff in the sugar industry will not fall on 1 July this year from $76 a tonne to $55 a tonne and allow a flood of subsidised sugar into Australia? Will the Prime Minister immediately reject any removal of the tariff quota on EC cheese until the present subsidy of $2,800 a tonne is removed? Will he give an assurance that there will be no further tariff cuts on primary industry products until the Uruguay Round is completed and other countries have reduced export subsidies, opened up market access for Australian products and reduced internal subsidies as required by the Dunkel proposal?

—Senator Boswell's question is, as usual, comprehensive. He has asked me about tariff regimes and reduction in tariff for sugar. The Government has a program in hand for that and that will not be changed. In so far as the dairy industry is concerned, as Senator Boswell knows, there has been an Industry Commission report on the dairy industry which the Government has to respond to. I cannot foreshadow or prejudge any response which the Government might make with respect to the dairy industry.

PARA.TAB: I do know, however, that there are some very significant players involved in the sugar industry in Queensland who find the legacy of the National Party Government in Queensland, with statutory marketing boards and so on—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true. They describe Senator Boswell as a likeable bloke, but a very hard nut to crack in terms of rationalising the sugar industry.
—Who are these people? Name them.

—Senator Boswell might be able to guess; I referred to some very big players in the industry. They see rationalisation of the sugar industry as—pardon the Latin expression, I cannot think of another at the moment—a sine qua non for the growth and development of the sugar industry into a much more efficient industry than it is now. As Senator Boswell knows, the sugar industry is characterised in certain areas by farms with below optimum scale and a number of changes need to be made. Senator MacGibbon, who knows a bit about it, is nodding his head—he understands all this. It is important that we adopt a flexible, sensible and not mindless approach to the future of the sugar industry.

PARA.TAB: In so far as the Prime Minister is concerned, he had no conversion on the road to the Coburg Town Hall but has been consistent about this.

TALK.START.PARA: —In an interview last year you said—

—No, that was in 1990, Senator Hill. That was a different issue altogether. As Senator Hill knows, that is politics. The fact of the matter is that there has been no conversion. The Government has a very consistent position on tariffs. We are the only government since the war to have articulated it and to have carried it into effect.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the progress of the rebuilding of Casey Station in Antarctica? What arrangements are in place for the disposal of the original station and the return of refuse to Australia? What efforts has Australia made to encourage other Antarctic Treaty countries to remove waste materials from the territories under their control?

—Senator Zakharov has had a longstanding interest in Antarctic matters which, of course, included her chairing of the Senate standing committee inquiry into the national resources of the Australian Antarctic Territory. I understand that she has actually visited Antarctica. The Minister has provided me with the following response.

PARA.TAB: The Government has a long term commitment to conducting high quality science programs in Antarctica and providing the necessary support facilities while ensuring the protection of the Antarctic environment. With the exception of the radio transmitter building, the rebuilding program at Casey was completed this year as part of a major program to upgrade Australia's Antarctic stations. The new facilities include the science building with its greatly improved laboratory facilities for biological studies, upper atmosphere physics, glaciology and geoscience.
Demolition of approximately half of the old Casey Station took place in the 1991-92 season. Is Senator Calvert listening to this?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes!

—I thought he would be. The Australian Construction Service on behalf of the Antarctic Division dismantled the old club, mess, kitchen, medical quarters and sleeping quarters. Some of the old buildings have already been returned to Australia and a further quantity of rubbish and materials is stockpiled for return in the 1992-93 season. The remainder of the old buildings, with the exception of one or two which may be retained for short term use, will be dismantled next summer and returned to Australia.In recent years, all waste generated at Australian stations has either been incinerated in double-burn incinerators or returned to Australia. The Antarctic Division is progressively cleaning up all the old rubbish sites.

PARA.TAB: Since 1989, the Government has worked very hard to obtain the agreement of other Antarctic Treaty nations to establish a comprehensive environment protection regime for Antarctica. This culminated in October 1991 when Treaty parties adopted the Protocol and Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty. Annexe 3 to the protocol prescribes environmentally acceptable disposal and waste management practices for all Treaty parties. The Government is very pleased to have played such a significant role in ensuring the future protection of the Antarctic environment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Is the Minister aware that the Australian Hospital Association and the Australian Private Hospitals Association, which together represent 80 per cent of Australia's hospitals both public and private, have joined forces in an attempt to save Australia's ailing hospital system from financial ruin? Those are their words, not mine. Their joint statement today entitled `Operation: Hospital Survival' states:

QUESTION.PARA: The last two years had seen a decline in Australia's hospital system which could no longer be tolerated.
Is the Minister aware of that statement? If so, what is the Government's response? Is it time to act?

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware of the joint statement made this morning by the Hospital Association and the Private Hospitals Association with respect to this matter. But I am pleased to see that Senator Patterson did not adopt their terminology. It indicates a very prudent approach on her part not to employ scaremongering language which would portray the Australian hospital system in the terms which they have obviously chosen to use in their press release. That was a very wise precautionary move on Senator Patterson's part not to become too closely identified with them, although she has taken up their cause to some extent in her question.

PARA.TAB: I find it quite extraordinary that this sort of question should come from the Opposition which, of course, in cutting funds to the States, would put enormous pressure on the States in respect of their financing of the public hospitals. I believe it would lead to a situation where, quite obviously, if the Opposition does come into government, the combined effect of cutting public funds to public hospitals—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I did not ask the Minister about our policy. I asked the Minister what was the Government's response to the time to act package.
—There is no point of order. The Minister is answering the question.

—I am absolutely on track, on point and very relevant. Very recently, the Australian Private Hospitals Association put out a proposal for health insurance. It is meant to fill the gap which would be created by the Opposition's failure to fund the States in a way which would enable them to run the public hospital system efficiently and provide the services which are required.
—I take a point of order. This is misrepresentation of the coalition's policy. We are injecting $63m more into health care than the Government.
—Order! There is no point of order. I cannot judge the truth or otherwise of statements.

—The fact is that the Australian Private Hospitals Association has put forward a proposal in relation to hospital treatment. It states that the costings in relation to that proposal include a reduction in Commonwealth payments to the States to leave the States in a budget neutral position. That is the relevance of my point. The extra revenue from bare day charges is offset by the cut in the grant, leaving public hospitals no better off. The Australian Private Hospitals Association's alternative proposal—the people the honourable senator has quoted—does nothing to actually increase the services that will be provided in the public hospital sector. There will be the combined effect of a reduction in revenue to the States, so they cannot help public hospitals the way they do now, and patients who need treatment will be required to pay very high insurance premiums. That is what the coalition will achieve.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations, and I ask: has the Minister seen reports in today's Australian Financial Review that 1991 was one of the worst years for strikes during the era of the accord? Can he explain why work days lost per 1,000 workers in 1991 were at their highest level in three years? In particular, can he explain why the level of disputation should have been almost as high in the recessed conditions of 1991 as it was in the boom conditions of 1988?

—When one looks at strike statistics in Australia and compares the performance during the whole of the Fraser years with the whole of the Labor years, it is basically true that on average there has been a reduction in industrial disputes by 61 per cent. This reduction demonstrates beyond any reasonable doubt that Labor governments handle industrial relations vastly better than the conflict prone and ridden attitude of confrontation from the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that the Australian Financial Review has been remarkable in its reporting of the latest strike statistics. All other newspapers in Australia got it right when they said that on a working days lost measure this is the lowest for three decades; the lowest since 1962. As far as the total number of disputes is concerned, the figures are the lowest since 1961. Those are the December figures.

This is the second time the Australian Financial Review has got is wrong. That paper got it wrong when it reported the October figures, and today's headline is entirely misleading. The headline today that there is discord under the accord is entirely misleading and is not in any way reflective of what has been the objective truth of the matter in this case.

The 1991 figures are higher because of one particular distortion. That one distortion is called Premier Nick Greiner. The distortion arises because of the continuing confrontation of the Greiner Government which has pushed the number of industrial disputes in New South Wales well above the national average and well above that of the other most populous State, Victoria.

In October there was a one-day union stoppage in New South Wales in protest against the repressive industrial legislation that the Greiner Government was trying to enact. The continuing confrontation of the Greiner Liberal Government created that type of social division and industrial upheaval in New South Wales. That is the solitary reason why the 1991 figures are higher. Therefore, it is not a reason that I, as the responsible Minister in a Labor government, regard as reflecting on the accord at all. In fact, it reflects on anti-accord behaviour and not on pro-accord behaviour.

If that one-off blip in the figures is taken out, the outcome for 1991 will have trended down and will still be below 1990. It will show that, since coming into office, even in the years of very high economic growth and high employment—1984, 1985, 1986, 1987 and 1988—industrial disputes under Labor in this country consistently fell.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. Why is it that the effective annual rate for interest paid on contributions to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme through the Retirement Benefits Office during 1990-91 was only 2.84 per cent? How does the Government explain such a poor return, given the enormous funds available for investment and the fact that most large superannuation funds outside the Government earned between 9 and 18 per cent over the same period?
—That question is too hard for me. I will direct it to the Minister for Finance and get an answer as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: North Queensland: Search and Rescue Services

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation aware of ongoing media reports which suggest that the Federal Government cannot guarantee the future of search and rescue services in north Queensland? Is this not in direct contradiction to his absolute commitment given to the Senate in answer to my question on Tuesday? Can the Minister again clarify the situation and, in doing so, reassure the people of north Queensland that search and rescue responsibilities will continue to be fully met by the Federal Government?

—I am aware of these reports—they emanated from Senator O'Chee. The statement made by Senator O'Chee yesterday to the Queensland media was in fact utterly false. Senator O'Chee has developed a very nasty habit in recent times of issuing press statements that have absolutely no foundation in fact at all, and it is about time he stopped. That is, of course, ignoring the particularly stupid ones, such as complaining about being served with Canadian bacon on Qantas aircraft flying to Australia from London.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The Minister should answer the question, and he might also do it by not reflecting on another honourable senator.
—Order! Senator Collins, answer the question.

—Mr President, to continue: Senator O'Chee stated yesterday to the Queensland media that the Government `could not answer the question'—they were his words—as to what was going to happen to the emergency services group.

—Mr President, on the point of order: the question was whether the Minister could give certain assurances to people in north Queensland. I cannot see why that question cannot be answered, rather than having a debate about Senator O'Chee.
—Order! I think Senator Collins has been in order so far, but I would remind him to answer the question.
—In response to the question, I was advising the Senate why the good people of north Queensland need this reassurance because of the pernicious activities of Senator O'Chee.

PARA.TAB: What I said in the Senate yesterday I reiterate today: the operations of this emergency unit are entirely the responsibility of the Queensland State Government. I have been assured by the Minister, Mr Warburton, that because of the financial difficulties of this organisation, the Queensland State Government is going to fund the continuing operations of the organisation straight off the Queensland State Budget. For the further advice of the Senate, an officer of the Queensland emergency services department is liaising with the unit this week—spending three days with it—to ensure the continuation of this service without a break between now and the awarding of the tender to the successful applicant.

As I said yesterday, there will be no break whatsoever in the provision of these important services to north Queensland. The Queensland Government will ensure that they continue. Further to what I said yesterday, I now understand that written advice is being provided to all employees of the service that their employment will continue to this date. Tenders will be called for prior to the expiration of the current service in June, and a successful tenderer will be appointed to ensure, as I said yesterday, that there is no break in this service.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. I remind the Minister of the Opposition's policy to provide Medicare benefits for densitometry—that is, bone density measurement for osteoporosis. I also refer to a question asked by my colleague Senator Patterson of Senator Reynolds in December 1989, when the then Minister advised the Senate that the matter was then under consideration. I now ask the Minister: when the annual cost of osteoporosis to the health budget is between $200m and $500m a year, why is the Federal Labor Government, after all this long time, still not prepared to extend Medicare benefits to menopausal women for densitometry as a preventive health measure?

—I have been trying to see whether there is anything specific in the brief provided to me by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services in relation to this particular matter. Whilst some women's health issues are outlined in the brief, I cannot see anything at the moment to do with osteoporosis. I will seek further information from the Minister and provide it to Senator Newman as soon as possible.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation. I refer to reports about new `active packaging' which extends the shelf life of Australia's horticultural exports. Can the Minister advise how the shipping industry can be encouraged to promote this process, which obviously has the potential to significantly improve the handling of seagoing cargo and expand our export markets?

—I am extremely pleased to advise that the Australian shipping industry is taking an active interest in the development of this new packaging technology, which has great potential for Australian shippers of this kind of produce overseas. The Australian National Line is one of a group of organisations that are cooperating in the commercial development of this packaging which was developed by the Australian research organisation, CSIRO. It is another piece of invaluable, practical research that has been conducted by the CSIRO which will contribute extensively to the future well-being of this country.

PARA.TAB: The new packaging that has been developed by CSIRO controls the atmosphere surrounding farm produce and considerably delays its ripening and eventual decay. A recent trial shipment conducted by ANL to Japan proved that the packaging was highly successful in keeping a consignment of freshly cut flowers in excellent condition after five weeks at sea. This advance in packaging technology has the potential significantly to increase exports of perishable produce to Asian and European markets from Australia by sea and to overcome the cost and space limitations that are associated with these perishable cargoes carried by air freight.

The Australian National Line is providing financial, marketing and technical support for the promotion of this important product. The project is also being supported directly by the Federal Government through a $500,000 two-year grant from the Industry Research and Development Board. The Australian National Line is to be commended on its foresight in participating in this project. It is well placed to take advantage of the significant commercial opportunities that will be available in Australia to our exporters with the further development of this product.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Administrative Services.
—First for the year.

—We do not run dorothy dixers over here, Senator. I refer the Minister to remarks made by the Prime Minister in which he stated that he intends to amend the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Act 1991 to allow political advertisements on radio and television during election campaigns. If this is correct, what amendments are proposed and what are the reasons for those amendments?

—I think what Senator Parer has said is right. Both the Prime Minister and I have said that the legislation which went through this place was not in the form that it was when it entered this place, and I think everyone knows that. As a consequence, we are reviewing how it operates in the light of by-elections and we are monitoring the effects of it during that process.

PARA.TAB: At this stage, I can say for both the Prime Minister and myself that nothing that we have experienced so far would lead us to repeal the legislation, although, as he has said and I have said, amendments to it are under consideration. In terms of the actual content of those amendments, they will be presented to the Senate, if necessary, at the appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister a direct question: was the Prime Minister correct in stating that he intended to amend the legislation to permit broadcasts on radio and television during election campaigns because he believed it would benefit the Labor Party?

—I will answer one part of that question very quickly. The Prime Minister has not said that he will do away with the ban. Any interpretation that one puts on whatever statement the Prime Minister has made would not lead one to that conclusion. As I said in my first answer in response to Senator Parer, the Government is considering what amendments can be made to the legislation, given the fact that it did not go through this place in the way that it was first proposed.

PARA.TAB: I also stated for Senator Parer's interest that nothing that we have experienced so far would lead us to repeal the legislation. Both the Prime Minister and I have also said that what we are looking at—what is basically on the agenda at the moment—is minor technical amendments, minor technical refinements, to improve the legislation.
Senator Parer comes in here again, having had a long history of opposition to this legislation. But I ask him and the Opposition—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: it is not for the Minister to start asking questions. He has answered the question and he should now be told to sit down.
—Order! I do not think Senator Bolkus is asking a question.

—Mr President, I have been waiting for a long time to get a question from the other side. The point I make to the other side is that we have had some experience with this legislation over recent months. It has had application in Tasmania, in the Australian Capital Territory and in a by-election. I think the universal opinion of the voters out there on the legislation is that it has been successful.

PARA.TAB: One of the major objectives of the legislation is to reduce the costs of campaigning. I point out to Senator Newman that we even have the new Premier of Tasmania on the record as saying that it was quite successful in that respect. I think his words were that the effect of the legislation was that total expenditure would be half the average amount spent by a successful single candidate at the last Federal election.

The honourable senator's party in Tasmania recognises that the legislation was successful in attaining that objective. As well as that, the Liberal Party's eminent Speaker down there at the moment, Mr Hodgman, also made the point in response to the newspapers that he thought—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I would suggest to you that this is now clearly a debate. The Minister was asked whether certain amendments were going to be put. He answered that question and now he wants to enter into a debate on the merits of his original legislation. I put it to you that that is out of order and I ask you to sit him down.

—I was asked a question about the legislation. Implicit and explicit in that question was criticism of that legislation. If Senator Parer and Senator Hill cannot handle an answer, then they should not be asking questions. They should get a full answer, and that is what they are getting.
—Order! I do not think that Senator Bolkus's original answer was too long but the answer to the supplementary is becoming a bit long.
—The point I was making in the supplementary was that they ought to listen to the people out there. The people find no problem with it, nor do we.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The importance of the Asia-Pacific region to our economic future is now clearly recognised, as is the need for skills in business and management to negotiate between countries and in trade. Has the Government taken any initiatives to assist companies to develop these skills and, if so, can the Minister elaborate?

—There have been several recent reports, both private sector and government in origin, which have indicated that the key elements for business success in Asia include familiarity with local business practices and national culture and, very importantly of course, language skills.

PARA.TAB: One of the key government initiatives in this area is the Asia-Pacific fellowship program, which is managed by Austrade and which was launched by my colleagues the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and the then Minister for Trade and Overseas Development in September last year. That Asia-Pacific fellowship program does provide financial assistance to companies to enable them to place managers or graduate employees in key Asian markets for six- to 12-month periods. Fifteen fellowships have recently been awarded, enabling participants to work and study in Indonesia, China, Malaysia, Japan and Taiwan.

Fellowship recipients include engineers, scientists, export managers and individuals working in the legal and financial sectors. These young graduates and more experienced managers as well, working with companies which are committed to success in the region, will be adding vital market skills to their business and technical backgrounds. Over $10m has been set aside to provide 50 fellowship placements a year for the next three years. The second round of these fellowships will be awarded over the next month. With Asian markets now representing seven of our top 10 export destinations, the importance of these markets and these fellowships in relation to them cannot be underestimated.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am fascinated to note the indifference and hostility with which this very important initiative is being greeted by the Opposition. It is yet another demonstration of the gap between its rhetoric and its commitment—its understanding of the issues involved in the real world in which we are trying to deliver results and succeeding.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the Minister's response to a question asked by Senator Coates on Tuesday about changes to APPM's workers' conditions, particularly his comments that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . APPM gave. . . notice that it would unilaterally withdraw from all over-award agreements . . . covering employees of its company in Tasmania.

Given that APPM spoke to the staff of the Minister informing them that APPM's employees, after the changes and conditions are made, will still receive benefits and salaries which are 25 per cent over the award payment, a shorter working week of 35 hours and an over-award superannuation contribution, I ask whether the Minister concedes that his statement on Tuesday was incorrect. Will the Minister also apologise to the Senate and to the company?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that question is no.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to a report in yesterday's Australian Financial Review, where it was foreshadowed that the Government is set to launch a major overhaul of the wholesale sales tax system. Will the Minister confirm these reports? If so, does this mean that the One Nation statement was wrong when it said on page 12 that Labor's previous decisions on taxation `have also restored the confidence of the average Australian worker in the integrity of the taxation system'?

—I can confirm that the Treasurer does intend to make a statement about the wholesale sales tax regime; he has announced that himself. There is nothing new about that.
