It is a statement relating to simplification of the legislation. He will do that shortly. There is no inconsistency between what the Treasurer said and the second part of the question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question relating to material we gained in the Estimates committee hearings, in the light of the findings contained in reports that were commissioned by the Australian Tax Office. I quote one such report as follows:

QUESTION.PARA: The ultimate solution (is) the introduction of a consumption tax rather than a modification of the current system.
Will the Minister tell the Senate why the Australian Tax Office spent $750,000 commissioning surveys and reports when the Government clearly intends to ignore the information that was provided?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. There is no way in which that question can be interpreted either as supplementary to the first question or arising from the answer to the first question, and it does not accord with any of the precedents established by previous presidents as to what constitutes a supplementary question.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I am interested to see that Senator Button needs the protection of Senator McMullan. I am sure he can actually look after himself, if he tries hard. The Australian Tax Office surveys and reports are very relevant to the initial question that I asked, and I would ask Senator Button if he could manage an answer all on his own.
—Order! It is usual for a fair degree of flexibility to be allowed with supplementaries, and I will allow the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not familiar with the view expressed to the Estimates committee. I am aware that there are some supporters of the replacement of the wholesale sales tax regime by a goods and services tax. They did constitute about 40 per cent of the community; I think it is now about 25 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Patterson asked a question last year concerning marketing expenditures to which I now provide some further information. She asked the question on 19 December. I had other things on my mind that day and did not follow it up. I apologise for being late.

PARA.TAB: Senator Patterson would be aware that a publicity and marketing strategy was always going to be a part of the disability reform proposal. It was recognised that it would be necessary to start planning the dissemination of information about the reforms well in advance of the implementation date—and the Senate will recall that the implementation date was very close to the time it got through the Parliament. That is why funding for this initiative was identified as far back as the 1990-91 Budget.

The disability legislation to which Senator Patterson refers gave effect to changes to the income security system only. Since this was the case, it was appropriate to advance funds to the winning tenderer so that work could commence on the marketing strategy to ensure that the disability community would have adequate information on the general nature of the reforms before they were implemented. I am advised by the Department of Social Security that all due processes were followed in the letting of this tender. As far as the question of any conflict of personal interest is concerned, this matter is being looked at by the Minister for the Environment who is responsible for the workings of the ministerial council, and I shall report back as soon as I have an answer from her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Patterson on 19 December 1991, relating to disability reform marketing strategy contract.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add to an answer I gave a moment ago to Senator Watson during Question Time.
—You have saved a censure.

—Oh, no. The comments I made were taken from my brief which says that the companies gave the union 30 days notice of withdrawal from all agreements that were outside terms and conditions of awards. That is what I am advised by my Department.
—That is not what you said.
—That is what I did say. I table my brief accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement, Mr President.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement that Senator Cook made appears to be at variance with the answer that he gave to the Senate on 24 March. Could Senator Cook clarify the position that he now finds himself in?
—Read out what he said.
—He said:

SPEECH.PARA: On 3 March this year APPM gave 30 days notice that it would unilaterally withdraw from all over-award agreements with unions covering employees of its company in Tasmania.
That statement is not correct and Senator Cook, from advice from his office, knows it is not correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have answered this question by tabling the brief that is in front of me from my Department.
—That is not what the Minister said. He has misled the Senate.

—Through you, Mr President, let me reply to that interjection. Here we have Senator Watson alleging a certain thing. We have my Department saying that certain facts are true. No offence is directed to Senator Watson in this, but I intend to take the brief of my Department as being the authoritative document in this case.
— We have to take Hansard. We did not get your brief.
—The honourable senator may have to take Hansard; that is entirely understandable. But I do not see anything inconsistent at all—
—At the very least, you should recheck your facts.

—If you will just allow me to answer the question. I do not see anything inconsistent between the words used in Hansard and the words in this brief. If the honourable senator tries to pretend that there is, then that will be an extraordinary feat of verbal acrobatics, even beyond his ken, I am sure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move to take note of the answers that Senator Cook has just given, and seek leave to make a few remarks.
—Those are two different things. You must seek leave to make a statement first. Is leave granted?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion to take note of the answers.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of Senator Cook's answers.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook has attempted to compound his felony by misleading the Senate further. Senator Watson has very ably and accurately—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. Senator Bishop has made an allegation that I proposed to mislead the Senate. That is not true and it should be withdrawn.
—Order! The use of the word `felony' is unparliamentary and I ask that it be withdrawn.
—Which particular word was unparliamentary, Mr President?
—`Felony'.
—Thank you. The Minister has compounded the offence against this chamber—
—Will you withdraw the use of the word `felony'?

—I withdraw the use of the word `felony' and replace it with the use of these words: he has, in fact, compounded the action against the Senate's interest whereby he misled the Senate—and Senator Watson has read out the Hansard passage—and he has stood up and attempted to say that because the brief that he received said something different from what he said, we somehow impute the words of his brief to his own mouth. Wrong! The fact of the matter is that if he cannot read his own brief or if he wishes to reinterpret it, that is his problem.

PARA.TAB: He misled the Senate on matters of fact. Senator Watson outlined the position very accurately, and asked the Minister whether he would apologise both to the Senate and the company concerned. That was a very reasonable request. I would echo the words of my colleague Senator Watson, and say to the Minister, `Will you kindly undo some of the damage you have done and apologise to the Senate and to the company?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to this motion, Mr President, in circumstances that remind one of Senator Cook's contribution last year in relation to Robe River where clearly he defamed the Robe River companies. A moment ago he was deeply offended by the suggestion that he had acted improperly, but last year he defamed Robe River. Evidence to that effect was put before the Senate by Senator Crane. The Minister has said for months that he will investigate that matter and come back with a full report. He knows that he has now defamed APPM, but he is not prepared to come in here and admit it and apologise to the company and to the Senate. What seems to have occurred in the last two days is the same thing in relation to another company.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, the Minister has said today that his answer yesterday was in accordance with a brief given to him by his Department. What Senator Watson has said today is that his Department has now been provided with evidence that demonstrates that that brief was incorrect. At the very least, I would have thought that Senator Cook would get up—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans can yawn about that if he likes, but it simply reflects his attitude to defaming Australian companies, which are doing a pretty good job in desperate circumstances, thanks to the Government's economic policies.

PARA.TAB: At the very least, Senator Cook should have come in here today and said, `I will investigate the matter further and if my brief was incorrect I will then come in and correct the situation, apologise to the company and apologise to the Senate'. That is the very least that we should expect from him. He ought to have the guts to get up now and say that is exactly what he will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support what my colleagues have said—in particular, what the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) has said—and make reference to the similarities between what we have heard today and what occurred with Robe River. I remind the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) that it is now many months since he said that he would make a statement to this chamber during the adjournment debate to clear up the position which existed in relation to Robe River. We have still not had that statement.

PARA.TAB: I also remind the Minister that he was forced to release a table of the facts which I put down in this chamber relating to Robe River. I further remind the Minister that examination of the table that his Department put out confirms exactly what I claimed in this chamber. I urge the Minister to address not only the matters that have been raised by Senator Watson in this place today but also that outstanding matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had an incident in this chamber last year that I was prepared to forget about, but today reminds me of it.
—You forget about everything that ever happens in this chamber.

—If Senator Faulkner would listen instead of keeping his mouth open catching flies all the time he might find out what I am talking about. Some time last year I brought up a matter concerning the Moora pulp and paper mill. One of the unions was trying to stop it from getting off the ground because it thought it might be in danger of losing some jobs in the city. I asked Senator Cook what he was doing about the matter. He said he would go away and find out. I asked him about it when I ran into him in the dining room one night. He said, `I will find out and get back to you'. He came in here with a brief and gave a union-type reply to my concern. At the end of his speech he said, `Perhaps you should have told the Senate'—these are his words—`how many shares you had in that company'.

PARA.TAB: During the adjournment debate that evening I denied that I had shares in the company and asked him to come forward with evidence that I, my family or my company had any shares. He never returned. I was prepared to forget about it, but when a Minister continues to do that I think it is time to raise it again because it is something that he is continually doing. There is still a shadow over me, in that it was said that I asked the question because of my supposed pecuniary interest in that company. One day I would like the Minister to answer. If the Minister has found that I own shares he should tell everyone; he should tell the world, tell the Senate. But if he finds that I, my company, my children or anyone connected with me has no shares I would like him to tell the Senate also, just as he accused me the first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that Senator Cook's colleague Senator Devereux from Tasmania has had the opportunity to brief the Minister for Industrial Relations on this matter in the interim, I ask the Minister whether he is he now aware that APPM is not withdrawing the 25 per cent over-award payments, the 35-hour working week, the present employer contributions participating in the APPM-ACTU superannuation fund and the redundancy payment plan.

PARA.TAB: In the light of information from Senator Devereux and other sources, can the Minister now apologise? It seems incredible to me and to my colleagues that the company which made the effort to contact the Minister's office on a matter of such concern and such controversy should have got it so blatantly wrong, as the Minister has obviously inferred in his answer. I believe that his answer is not good enough. It is not only disrespectful to the company and to the Senate but it is also blatantly untrue. I give the Minister a further opportunity to apologise to the staff, the company and the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an extraordinary debate and one in which a lot is trying to be made out of a little.
—Unprecedented in this place!

—Unfortunately, it is not unprecedented in this place. This debate has ranged from the APPM issue to the Robe River issue—they are not unrelated issues, I might say; after all, the same company is involved. It has also aerated Senator Panizza. On 24 March I said in the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: On 3 March this year APPM gave 30 days notice that it would unilaterally withdraw from all over-award agreements with unions covering employees of its company in Tasmania . . .
The brief that I quoted from said:
The companies gave the union 30 days notice of withdrawal from all agreements that were outside the terms and conditions of awards.

I think it is a fair proposition that what I said was consistent with what my brief disclosed was the case. If the claim is that I have misled the Senate, I would like to know how those opposite can squeak a `misleading' between what seems to be two very similar sets of words. However, Senator Watson has come forward and said, in essence, not that my brief is wrong but that I am wrong and that I should therefore apologise to the company because what I have said is not entirely true.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson said that Senator Devereux—the prominent Labor senator from Tasmania—provided me with some information informally. That is true. I have sought Senator Devereux's permission to quote from the documents that he has provided me with. Those documents contain a set of letters to Mr John Cahill of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union, Surry Hills, New South Wales, from Mr John Guest, on behalf of North Broken Hill Peko, trading as APPM, Associated Forest Holdings Pty Ltd, Tasmanian Pulp and Forest Holdings Pty Ltd. In the first letter, what does Mr Guest say to Mr Cahill of the PKIU, New South Wales? The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir,

PARA.TAB: Enclosed is a letter which was sent today to all employees within APPM and posted on all work notice boards.

For the same reasons as are explained in the letter to employees, we wish to advise you that APPM no longer wishes to be a party to any agreement or arrangement entered into with your union which is outside the relevant Award or registered industrial agreement and hereby retires from all such agreements and/or arrangements with effect from 2 April 1992.
Please also be advised that site access for union officials will be granted by the company strictly in accordance with the Award effective from 3/3/1992.

SPEECH.PARA: Yours faithfully
John Guest

That is the letter from the company to the union. It is my understanding, based on advice obtained, that similar letters were received by other unions covering employees at APPM. In order to see what was in fact the notice, one must turn to the attachment which is signed by Mr W.D. Paisley, Director, Forestry and Paper of APPM. Part of that attachment states:
To this end—
referring to the company's decision—

it is no longer prepared to be party to extraneous arrangements that inhibit management's effectiveness in running its operations. Accordingly, you are hereby given 30 days notice of the cancellation of all non-award "agreements" or other "arrangements" with the exception of certain benefits which relate directly to your conditions of employment. The arrangements retained are:

PARA.TAB: -the 25% over award payment;
-shorter working week where it currently applies;
-APPM/ACTU Superannuation Fund;
-redundancy payment.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the basis on which the allegation that I have misled the Senate rests. That is the actual evidence. This is the documentary evidence. It is upon that documentary evidence that Senator Bishop makes an allegation of misleading.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what you said.
—What I said is:

SPEECH.PARA: On 3 March this year APPM gave 30 days notice that it would unilaterally withdraw from all over-award agreements with unions covering employees of its company. . .

TALK.START.PARA: —But they still maintained 25 per cent.

—I will investigate that position further since Senator Watson is so persistent in raising it and since—I must say this, Mr President—I have regard for his honesty as a senator in this place. I cannot say that that would be true of all senators opposite, but in his case it is true and I will investigate it further.

PARA.TAB: I am advised by inquiries initiated by my ministerial office to APPM that it refuses to enter into talks or negotiations with any of the unions covering the workers protected by the agreements from which they have now withdrawn. My action as the responsible Minister—in the face of those terms being withdrawn unilaterally on 30 days notice, the agitation created by that in the work force and the apparent likelihood of an industrial dispute—was to refer both parties to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission so that they would be in a forum in which disputes could be settled. That is a responsible action of government. I make no apology to anyone for that.

Whether it be the unions or the employers who refuse to talk to the other—on this occasion it was the employers—I would still refer both parties to the umpire for their differences to be sorted out. That may not be the Opposition's intention. It may wish to see the dispute. I wish to preside over this issue in order to prevent industrial disputes and create industrial harmony. That at least means, in a powder-keg industrial situation, that both parties should be talking to one another about resolutions to the dispute.

I am further informed that on transcript and before the Commission—these are matters that I have been unable to check but I have it on reasonably good authority—the company indicated that it would be prepared to observe some of those over-award conditions for current employees but unilaterally cancel them for future employees. So one does not pretend that here there is not the basis of a very serious dispute which has the potential of paralysing this major company in Australia.

I would have to say that on the record what I have done, I believe by any objective measure, is the correct and proper actions of a responsible government. For the Opposition now to try to find some nitpicking diversion in the words which, in terms of the brief and what I have uttered in this place, are so closely related as to see no crack of daylight between them, is in the first place a travesty and in the second place a reflection on the Opposition's political intent. Senator Bishop requires me to apologise. I am sorry, but I do not apologise for the responsible actions of a government aimed at bringing about an end to an industrial matter as potentially threatening as this one.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I can only say, after listening to that so-called defence by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), that the remarks I have to make now come out of sadness. The man has clearly no shame at all. The man has no concept of what it is to be truthful. At the very best, he is careless with the truth. In other words, as he read out letters that he obtained from a colleague, he simply proved that he misled the Senate on the previous occasion. He said quite clearly in his answer that all over-award provisions had been—
—Mr President, on a point of order.
—Sit down. You have had your go.

—Is Senator Kemp saying that I should not uphold the Standing Orders? The point of order, Mr President, is that Senator Bishop has made a direct allegation that I have misled the Senate. That is not true and I ask that that offensive term be withdrawn.
—Order! I do not think Senator Bishop said that the Minister deliberately misled the Senate. I think she used `misled' as a debating term and I will allow her to continue.

—We were not having a debate on the relative merits of the policies of the Labor Party or the Opposition. We were not entering into philosophical discourse, which was the main structure of the Minister's debate. What we were debating is what the Minister in fact said. The Minister in fact said that APPM gave 30 days notice that it would unilaterally withdraw from all over-award agreements with unions. We note that in fact that is not so; that there were four instances outlined by Senator Watson where they remain. The Minister got it wrong on the facts and he was simply asked to inform the Senate that he got it wrong and apologise to the Senate and the company concerned.

PARA.TAB: Once the debate got going the ire of other honourable senators was raised. Senator Crane again raised the way in which the Minister has treated the Robe River companies—with a disdain for the truth. Then Senator Panizza stood up and in all decency the Minister should have come back and apologised to the honourable senator a long time ago for defaming him in this chamber. The Minister has no courage to come back and say to a fellow senator that he did him a mischief. If the Minister has any shame within him; if he has any sense of decency—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no sense of shame within me.
—Take that interjection.
—Yes, that is a good point. The Minister has admitted that he has no sense of shame and that has become quite apparent in this chamber today.

PARA.TAB: The point of this debate was to point out that on the facts the Minister misled this place on this occasion. The Minister heard Senator Crane reiterate where the Minister has misled the Senate on another occasion and the Minister has further misled the Senate by defaming Senator Panizza. Not once does the Minister have the courage to stand up like a man and say that he did it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! During the Matters of Public Interest debate earlier today Senator Bishop referred to an incident yesterday after Question Time when she was refused leave to make a statement. She suggested that this was due to confusion on the part of the Chair and that Senator Short had sought leave to move a motion and should have been allowed to speak to the motion. In fact, there was no confusion on my part. As I stated yesterday, Senator Short—having been granted leave after he requested leave to make a brief statement—in fact did not move any motion. The Hansard report confirms that no motion was moved. Senator Short made a statement by leave. Senator Button then sought and was granted leave to make a statement. There was no motion for Senator Bishop to speak to, and therefore she required leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question I wish to ask arising from your statement, Mr President. I read from page 1064 of yesterday's Hansard where Senator Short said:

SPEECH.PARA: During Question Time I asked for leave to take note of Senator Button's answer to a question from Senator Childs and to make a brief statement about it.

I did a similar thing today. I formally used the words, `I move that' and, indeed, Mr President, at first you attempted to say that I was seeking leave to make a statement. I made it clear to you that I was in fact not doing so, but was moving a motion. When Senator Short rose to ask if he might take leave to note Senator Button's answer, I asked you how it was possible to take note of an answer without moving a motion to so do? Although the honourable senator may not have used the words `I move', that was implicit in the statement he made. I would ask you, Mr President, to give me some guidance as to how one can take note of a question without moving to so do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Short did not move a motion. I will have another look at the Hansard. I am 100 per cent sure that he did not move a motion.
—You are a halfwit.
—Order! Senator Evans, withdraw that.
—And apologise!
—I do so apologise. I just hope that Senator Bishop will have the grace to apologise for her misbehaviour.
—I did not ask for an apology; Senator Evans was asked to withdraw the comment.
—I ask Senator Evans to withdraw it.
—I withdraw it. It comes with an apology as well. It is about time Senator Bishop had the grace to utter one herself.

—Mr President, I am pleased that you are going to look again at the Hansard, because I just read to you the words in the Hansard, which were not in accordance with your statement. I ask you how it is that you can take note of an answer without moving to do so.
—Order! I am not going to continue this debate. Senator Short was totally confused. He did not know whether he was moving—
—You are casting aspersions.
—Order! On reading the Hansard, my impression was that he was confused as to whether he was seeking leave to move a motion or to make a statement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was present and sitting next to Senator Short yesterday when he raised that point during Question Time. He certainly was not confused in any way other than about the answer. I certainly recall, Mr President, that you chose not to proceed with the matter. I think your statement just now was a reflection on Senator Short.
—Order! If it is taken as a reflection on Senator Short, I will withdraw it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation on the grounds that I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a few other grounds.

—We give Senator Evans a lot of leave in this place. During Question Time today, Minister Collins made a statement in which he alleged, first, that I was dishonest and, secondly, that I had issued a press release in which I had stated that there would be no search and rescue facilities in north Queensland after the end of June. I wish to answer both those points, answering the second one first.

PARA.TAB: My press release yesterday said:

SPEECH.PARA: MINISTER ALL AT SEA ON SEARCH AND RESCUE
The Federal Government can offer no glee that search and rescue facilities would be available in North Queensland after the end of June, National Party Senator Bill O'Chee said today.

Asked in the Senate at Question Time who would take over search and rescue operations if the North Queensland Emergency Response Group ceased operations at the end of June, the Minister, Senator Collins, replied:

TAB.EMPHASIS: ". . . .. the CAA contracts with whoever can provide these facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator O'Chee pointed out however that no other group in North Queensland had the facilities to do the job.
"The North Queensland Emergency Response Group is simply unparalleled in the area. There is simply no-one else who can feasibly do the job," Senator O'Chee said.
"I asked the Minister twice who would take the North Queensland Emergency Response Group's place and he just couldn't answer the question. That is because there is nobody else who can do the job.

Equipped with a helicopter, decompression chamber and Infra-Red search equipment, the North Queensland Emergency Response Group is one of the most sophisticated rescue teams in the State. Senator O'Chee said these facilities would be lost if the Government continued to do nothing.
"Senator Collins wants us to rely on his promise that somebody will take the place of the North Queensland Emergency Response Group, but he can't say whom," Senator O'Chee said.
"If you are at sea in a dinghy, as three people were last week, a promise is not good enough—you want a rescue helicopter.
"Senator Collins' lack of answers as to who will do the job clearly shows he is all at sea when it comes to search and rescue," Senator O'Chee said.

That is the end of the press release. Nowhere in there have I said there will be no search and rescue facilities. In fact, I distinctly raise the possibility that there will be a service if the Government has the decency to keep the North Queensland Emergency Response Group going. So Senator Collins is clearly misrepresenting me in that respect.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, I am concerned that Senator Collins should claim in the Senate in Question Time, when he knows that I have no opportunity to reply, that I was dishonest. A reading of the fact shows that that is not the case. If anybody is dishonest, it is Senator Collins.

Senator Collins was informed at the end of Question Time that I intended to raise this matter by way of personal explanation. He left the chamber and showed no regard for the courtesies of this place. The courteous and decent thing would have been to stay in his place while I answered the foul and scurrilous accusations which he hurled across the chamber in Question Time.

If anybody is dishonest, it is Senator Collins. His only opportunity to show that he is honest is to name the group that will take the place of the North Queensland Emergency Response Group if it ceases operations at the end of June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Tierney on 26 March 1992 relating to interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tierney's question was very straightforward. The question was: `Why does Australia have relatively high real interest rates compared with all other industrial countries?'. That is a very important question. A major factor behind this recession—the recession we had to have—was the very high level of real interest rates which absolutely devastated Australian industry. When one reads studies of the 1980s it is interesting to see that the interest rate levels in Australia were far higher than in other industrial countries.

PARA.TAB: The problem, which goes to the nub of the recession at the moment, is that interest rates in Australia are still very high relative to other countries. The Parliamentary Library pulled out some figures for me today which show, for example, in relation to corporate bond yields—and these are the latest figures—that interest rates in Australia are far higher than the 12 to 14 other industrial countries listed in the table. It is a very important question because it is one of the major reasons that it is so difficult to get industry to invest again.

What did we get from Senator Button? We got a very trivial, silly answer to this very important question. In broad terms, Senator Button said that real interest rates are derived by adjusting nominal interest rates for inflation. We all know that. But the question he was asked was, `Why are interest rates so high?' That question was put again by way of a supplementary, and Senator Button answered by launching into an attack on the Fraser Government. But the question remains unanswered. Why is it that in Australia we have corporate bond rates at the level of over 9 per cent, whereas in countries like Japan the rates are around 3.6 per cent, Switzerland 2.1 per cent, and Germany 3.6 per cent? Why is it that the level of real interest rates in Australia is so high? Senator Button did not give us the answer to that question today.

The cheek of the matter is that Senator Button has come in here on a number of occasions and alleged that under the coalition's Fightback package interest rates will rise. We know that the Labor Government's record is one of high interest rates over a very long period. The Australian people are entitled to know why that is the case. We know that Senator Button, his colleague Senator Tate and others are in possession of advice from Treasury which says that under the coalition Fightback package, interest rates will fall. Scare tactics were again used in Question Time today.

I will put forward a couple of reasons why interest rates in Australia are at record high levels. First, there is the record foreign debt. The reality is that foreign borrowers are simply not convinced that this Labor Government has any strategy at all to deal with the massive and continually mounting foreign debt in this country. Secondly, I believe that real interest rates are so high in this country because of what economists refer to as `inflationary expectations'. In other words, people are assuming that inflation will get off the ground again, that it will start to rise, and therefore adjustments are being made to the level of interest rates at which lenders are prepared to offer funds.

Perhaps a third reason for the record high interest rates is the uncertainty about the Government's fiscal stance. There are concerns around that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) will do anything to try to ratchet up the opinion polls and that he will expand spending. Of course, we are already seeing the Budget deficit blowing out. So the point I wish to make is that the question from Senator Tierney was very serious and very important. It was a question which Senator Button, as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, should have been effectively addressing. What he gave us was a silly and trivial answer.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Patterson on 26 March 1992 relating to hospitals.

SPEECH.PARA: The significance of Senator Patterson's question completely escaped the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) today.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true.

—He admits that that is true, and I can understand that because he obviously was not briefed. The significance of the action today was that the Australian Hospital Association, which represents all the public hospitals in Australia, joined with the Australian Private Hospitals Association in a joint statement slamming hospital Medicare. The public and private hospital sectors have joined in this unprecedented move in an attempt to save Australia's ailing hospital system from financial ruin. They have banded together and have called on the Federal Government to rectify the serious flaws in hospital Medicare.

PARA.TAB: These two organisations officially represent over 80 per cent of the hospitals of Australia, and the 20 per cent which they do not represent are unrepresented by them merely because of the affiliation fees and the fact that the other 20 per cent are quite small hospitals with small numbers of beds, although large in number. I am sure that they completely support the thrust of what these two organisations are doing.

The influence of the public and private hospital sectors working together should not be underestimated by the Government. The Australian Hospital Association's National Director, Mr Peter Baulderstone, said today:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that we have got together should indicate to all that Hospital Medicare is under very serious threat and that changes need to be made.

I might mention that Mr Baulderstone was a member of Dr Blewett's staff when he was Minister for Community Services and Health. In a joint statement, the two major hospital groups said that the last two years have seen a decline in Australia's hospital system which can no longer be tolerated. Public hospitals are being asked to provide more services with fewer resources, and the demand for the public hospital services is increasing dramatically.

PARA.TAB: The private hospital system, now of the highest quality, is able to access only about one-third of the population. The situation is becoming worse day by day as Australians are forced to give up private health insurance or not take it up as the cost of private cover spirals in a time of economic recession. Only 41.9 per cent of Australians now carry private hospital insurance—down from 44.4 per cent only 12 months ago. This effectively means that another half a million Australians have been forced to rely on the public hospital system in the last 12 months, adding another $128m to the States' hospital bills.

What was the Federal Government's reply to these undeniable facts? The Federal Government appointed a committee; it appointed the Macklin review. What has resulted since the Macklin review was appointed? Nothing. The review has not resulted in any change to public hospital funding. The National Health Strategy paper Hospital Services in Australia. Access and Financing. Issues paper No. 2 states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the burden of the large increases in health insurance premiums falls inequitably on those high-risk groups who retain private health insurance, including the elderly and chronically ill. The burden is also borne by a significant number in the lower income groups in that 40.3% of the population holding private health insurance have incomes less than average weekly earnings (under $31,000 per year). This is contrary to Medicare's principle that the costs of hospital care should be `funded by all according to means'.
The review has been a convenient vehicle for the Federal Government to refer all complaints, concerns and criticisms of its Medicare policy, and it has achieved nothing.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Private Hospitals Association and the Australian Hospital Association believe that Medicare's two main objectives—access for all Australians to high quality care on the basis of need, and funding of health services on the basis of people's financial means—are under serious threat.

There are three fundamental concerns which are shared by the Australian Hospital Association and the Australian Private Hospitals Association. They are that public hospitals are under excessive pressure, private health funds are in a perilous financial position, and the rising cost burden of private health insurance falls unfairly on pensioners and people on lower incomes. They both believe that the Federal Government must radically alter the hospital financing system to ensure that pensioners and low income earners remain fully covered by Medicare whilst other Australians meet the full cost of hospital care through private insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is outrageous.
—Senator Faulkner should note that I was quoting from the press release of the APHA and the AHA; this is not entirely mine.
—Is it partly yours?

—It is not entirely the coalition's health policy, but the thrust of our policy is the answer to the problems that have been enunciated by the Australian Hospital Association and the Australian Private Hospitals Association. Through our policy there will be a shift back from the public sector into the private sector. The private sector is underutilised at the moment and the public sector cannot cope with the demand.

PARA.TAB: The Government has no answer. This is a perilous situation. These two organisations have joined together and put out a press statement entitled `TIME TO ACT Operation: Hospital Survival'. The hospitals are in a crisis situation in this country. Otherwise we would not have had the unprecedented move by the Australian Hospital Association representing the public hospitals banding together with the Australian Private Hospitals Association in taking this quite dramatic position at this point of time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: 5 March 1992
Senator A O Zakharov
Chairperson
Senate Standing Committee on
Community Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Zakharov

I refer to the Committee's recommendations contained in its Report on the Examination of Annual Reports of September 1991. Those recommendations are reproduced below together with the Government's response on each.
Departments
Recommendation 1
Social Justice

That Departments undertake a more integrated evaluation of the operation and effectiveness of social justice in their programs, ensure that performance indicators are established and that performance measurement is undertaken and reported on.

The Government notes the recommendation and will consider its implications in the light of departments' experience in complying with the current guidelines whose introduction coincided with the preparation of the 1990-91 annual reports. Those guidelines provide for more extensive and consistent reporting on social justice.
Recommendation 2
Consultancies—inter-departmental resource use

That government Departments should establish an inter-departmental register of staff with specific qualifications and experience and develop a strategy to utilise such staff in suitable projects in order to maximise use of government resources.
Recommendation 3
Consultancies—Intra-departmental resource use
That each Department should establish consultancy teams drawn from current staff to be brought together for a specific task or tasks which might otherwise be let as an external consultancy.
The Government notes recommendations 2 and 3 but does not accept that it would be cost effective to establish an inter-departmental register of staff for the purposes contemplated.

It is often difficult to predict the need for special projects but, as a matter of course, Departments assess the availability of staff expertise from within their own resources and, in some cases, from other departments before engaging outside consultants to undertake such tasks.

The current guidelines require specific information on the engagement of consultants including, at guideline 55 (d), a justification in concise terms for the decision to have recourse to consultancy arrangements.
Statutory Authorities
Recommendation 4
Delineation of Objectives
That statutory authorities demonstrate more clearly what their objectives are and how these have been met. Such demonstration is to include a critical evaluation of performance against objectives.

In revising the annual report guidelines for statutory authorities, one of the key requirements likely to be included is a statement of objectives and the basis for assessing achievements against those objectives, along the lines contained in the departmental annual report guidelines.
Non-Statutory Bodies
Recommendation 5
Provision of adequate information
That Non-statutory bodies pay particular attention in their reports to providing sufficient detail to enable a proper evaluation to be made of their operation.

The Government notes the recommendation and will endeavour to ensure, through dissemination of the guidelines, that NSBs are reminded of their obligations, whether their reports are included in those of their parent bodies or they produce reports of their own.
Recommendation 6
NH&MRC to develop proper recording procedures

That the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&MRC) pay greater attention to reporting requirements, develop a mission statement, establish objectives and relate their performance to these objectives.

The Government notes the recommendation and the Council's response of 22 November 1991 that, pending establishment of the NH&MRC under legislation, it will endeavour in its annual report to meet the guidelines for non-statutory bodies.
Yours sincerely
SIGNED
LAURIE BRERETON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts on the examination of annual reports, June 1991. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: 5 March 1992
Senator R A Crowley
Chair
Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Crowley

I refer to the Committee's Report on the Examination of Annual Reports of June 1991 in which four recommendations were made. Those recommendations are reproduced below together with the Government's response on each.
Recommendation 1

That the guidelines for both statutory and non-statutory authority annual reports be amended so as to require a section showing the pages of the report that conform with each requirement of the relevant guidelines.

As the Committee noted in its report, the revised Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports contain a requirement that departmental annual reports are to demonstrate their compliance with the guidelines. At paragraph 1.12 the Guidelines also invite statutory authorities to comply where appropriate.

The Government notes the recommendation and will take it into account in revising the reporting guidelines for statutory authorities. To the extent that non-statutory bodies (NSBs) produce reports of their own, rather than forming part of the parent body report, consideration will be given to incorporating a similar requirement.
Recommendation 2
That the practice of printing the letter of transmittal
(containing an inaccurate date) within the annual report, be discontinued.
Recommendation 3
That, on the occasion of tabling the annual report, the Minister provide a copy of the letter of transmittal.

The Government agrees that agencies and Ministers should be able to demonstrate their compliance with the statutory requirement that reports be furnished to Ministers by a certain date and tabled within a certain period after the date on which reports are received by Ministers. Agencies, in furnishing reports to Ministers, may, if they wish, do so under cover of separate (dated) letters. As the Committee report noted, the current departmental annual report guidelines include a requirement at paragraph 3.4 that Ministers indicate the dates on which their annual report was furnished to and received by them.
When the current guidelines for annual reporting by statutory authorities are revised, consideration will be given to incorporating a similar requirement.

It is not feasible, however, to discontinue the practice of printing the letter of transmittal within the annual report. Whether or not reports are furnished to Ministers with separate covering letters, there remains a need for each report to incorporate a statement by the agency head certifying its compliance with (eg) section 25 of the Public Service Act. That statement should be signed and dated.

An agency cannot accurately predict how long the interval will be between the date when the text of its report (including any letter of transmittal incorporated in it) is finalised and the date when printed copies are available to be furnished to the Minister. Nor can it be assumed that the date of furnishing will be the same as the date on which the Minister receives a report.
Recommendation 4

That non-statutory authorities comply with the guidelines for such bodies and only conform with the requirements for statutory authorities as an extra; their reasons for doing so should be made clear in each report.

The Government notes the recommendation, acknowledging that the current guidelines for departmental annual reports include specific requirements in relation to non-statutory bodies. These were set out in the Government response to recommendations of the then Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in its report, Non-Statutory Bodies. The response was incorporated in the Senate Hansard for 8 December 1987, pp2645-7.

The effect of that response is that information of certain kinds, which is set out in the guidelines, is to be made available either in annual reports of NSBs, if they produce annual reports of their own, or in those of their parent bodies. It is for the Minister to decide whether an NSB should produce separate annual reports of its own containing

required information, or whether that information should be contained in the parent body's annual reports. These requirements can be readily incorporated into the revised annual report guidelines for statutory authorities, imposing core obligations on NSBs.

As there is no impediment to NSBs exercising a discretion to expand on the core requirements, the Government considers that any such additional information would be self-explanatory and would not require justification.
Yours sincerely
SIGNED
LAURIE BRERETON

SPEECH.PARA: The document that we are now discussing relates to three reports—the reports of the Sugar Research and Development Corporation from 1 October 1990 to 30 June 1991, the Sugar Research Council from 1 July 1990 to 30 September 1990 and the Sugar Research and Development Corporation Selection Committee. Much of the detail in this document concerns some very scientific aspects of the industry, especially the section dealing with the Sugar Research Council. In spite of that, it is interesting to read all three reports as they relate to an industry which is of vital and essential interest to my State of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: From Mossman in the north, the sugar industry is one of the vital industries to Queensland towns along the long coastal stretch. Like most other rural industries, this industry has been under severe pressure not only from the elements—all rural workers know that this is of vital concern—but also from the vagaries of the international market. What makes things worse for people in the sugar industry now is that, compounded with these problems, over which they have no control, we see the constant bombardment from Federal Labor government policies, which are slowly choking to death one of Australia's major industries.

Currently we have a situation where the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Research Economics—ABARE—has estimated that the value of the 1990-91 Australian crop was $752m. That represents a decline of 13 per cent from the previous season. This decline was caused by a 9 per cent decrease in crop production and a decline in the average value of the crop.

What is of most interest to those studying the industry is that this decline is despite an increase in assigned land area of 13 per cent over the past two seasons. Part of the decrease in production has been attributed to the dry and unfavourable seasonal conditions for cane growth in most regions. In 1990-91 there was a production of 25.2 million tonnes of cane from which 3.5 million tonnes of sugar was produced. Furthermore, a strong increase in world sugar production in 1990-91 and the build-up in stocks has led ABARE to conclude that world sugar prices will remain depressed in 1991-92.

On the international scene, we have seen world sugar production rise by five million tonnes to 114.2 million tonnes in 1990-91. This is the second year in succession in which world production growth has exceeded 4 per cent. This increase was far in excess of the increase in consumption, which grew at less than 2 per cent, causing stocks to increase and prices to fall.
l notice that the situation of the industry during the period is described at page 8 of the report. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: International agricultural support policies especially in the EEC, USA and Japan continue to cause distortion of world agricultural commodity prices including sugar.

Distortion is an understatement. What it is doing, together with the blind faith this Government places on the fictitious level playing field, is not only distorting world markets, but also destroying Australian industries. Last month the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) spoke in the other place about the plight of the rural sector. He said:

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt, though, that some farmers have lost their equity. Many farmers are trying to hang on. It is tough. We have to make sure that we get the broader economic position right and try to minimise the effect of a world recession. It has often been said by those on the other side that we have been blamed for the world recession. If Australia, with its 18 million people, created the world recession in the United States and Europe, it has much more power and influence in Zurich and Europe than I know of. The fact is that we are in a world recession. Commodity prices are bad because of corrupted trade markets. The world does not owe us a living. The world is a tough place. Aussies are good fighters and I think that agriculture in Australia is going to take on a bigger and better role.

SPEECH.PARA: It is pertinent that he said that the world does not owe us a living. That is correct, but it also follows that we—and I stress `we'—do not owe the world a living. And that I regret is what we are currently doing. While agricultural producers throughout the world are being subsidised by their governments, being able to dump their goods at cheaper prices on our domestic markets, we are in fact supporting the world's farmers.

PARA.TAB: No-one can ignore the impact of all the arguments and evidence about the effects of this tariff war on Australian farmers put to the President of the United States when he was here last January. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: The year in question saw the passing of the individual grains research funding body set up in 1986 and the birth of a new corporation to cover the activities of 14 councils and committees. It is interesting to note what the report has to say about the allocation of funds through the year. In reading the report, two items came to my attention. First, a subcommittee of the Wheat Research Council was appointed to monitor farm risk management projects being progressed in South Australia and Western Australia. This is vital in the present circumstances of the grain industries.

PARA.TAB: The second item that came to my attention was the Grains 2000 Conference put on by the Grains Council of Australia. Funding for this project was provided and a Council representative was appointed to the steering committee overseeing it. I would like to make one point about that. The conference was given very good and well researched material and it achieved a lot for grain growers. However, it was very expensive to attend. It was limited to those who had the money or who were given entree to it by being sponsored by the councils.

If we are to have functions such as Grains 2000, ordinary farmers should be able to afford to attend. It is a little like the Outlook Conference that ABARE put on at the beginning of the year. Unless the people in the community who produce the products can attend these functions, the message will not get through to them. They have to be affordable so that people can attend and learn. The bureaucrats stationed here in Canberra can also learn. People from around the world can then have the chance to meet ordinary Australian farmers.

The report states that the committee reviewed the projects being funded in research institutions in Tamworth and Wagga Wagga. Tamworth is very close to where I live. A magnificent job is done for the grain industry in that area. Wagga Wagga also does a great job. I commend the people who research and apply themselves to trying to make things better for farmers.

I noticed also that the committee accepted greater responsibility for the wheat and barley research programs in Queensland. That was done as a result of committee initiatives. More research organisations submitted projects for funding. Points were also made about wheat research. The report talks about consultation with farmers in the community and that is of paramount importance. I noticed that a lot more research into chickpeas and faba beans will be done. These two legume crops are part of cropping rotations that put nitrogen back into the soil. They keep the rotation going well. The soil is looked after. As custodians of our resources for future generations, most farmers want this.

In general, I commend the members of the committee—Mr Don Blesing, the Chairman; Trevor Flugge; Michael Furzer; Tony Gregson; Professor John Lovett; Professor Donald Marshall and Dr Barry White—for the job they do in spending the research dollar. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Higher Education Funding for the 1992-94 Triennium

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Aulich:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment briefly on the report from the Department of Employment, Education and Training entitled `Higher Education Funding for the 1992-94 Triennium'. The report outlines funding decisions for this period and states that the Government's policies will enhance quality in the system and diversity in higher education. That is, of course, a very broad and sweeping statement by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) and his Department and it is blatantly incorrect.

PARA.TAB: The education policies of this Labor Government are destructive, and the report clearly overlooks the chaos that has become the lot of the higher education system since the creation of Mr Dawkins's national unified system. As one would expect from DEET, this report claims that the enforced amalgamations within Australia's higher education system are a success. That is despite the continuing opposition from many institutions, such as the University of New England, and the intolerable overcrowding and overenrolment that exists in my own university at Newcastle.

In this report the Minister felt it necessary to make a statement on overcrowding and overenrolment problems. He is like Pontius Pilate; he wipes his hands of this matter, lays most of the blame at the feet of the institutions themselves and throws them inadequate funding to then deal with the problem. In his statement the Minister says that the Government will simply not provide additional funding for institutions which are above their target load, but will provide some assistance where the problems that have arisen are beyond the control of the university.

Firstly, the report states that almost all institutions are overenrolled. Secondly, I would have thought that the recession we had to have was definitely beyond the control of the universities. The universities could not have foreseen that this recession would have hit so hard and that, in a bid to avoid joining the 30 per cent of the rest of Australia's youth who are on the dole at the moment, so many people would have actually sought to continue studying. Here again, the Keating Government has let them down. A record number of 50,000 eligible students were turned away from university places this year. Surely the despair that would have been generated by this figure would be enough for the Minister and the Labor Government to see that their policies simply just are not working.

With overenrolment in 1991 the institutions were forced to lower the number of offers. This report states that in 1992 overenrolments are now averaging 6.6 per cent. NBEET states that the problem is so severe that it is detrimental to the creation of a proper learning environment.

The Labor Government will not give the universities the flexibility they need to deal with these problems. If the Government is incapable of providing adequate funding, why should students suffer because of outdated ideology which discourages universities from seeking funding from other sources. The Government wishes to increase places in universities but the institutions are not receiving the funding that would allow them to expand to meet the increased demand.

Under the Labor Government the funding of our higher education system has slowly been reduced as a percentage of GDP. Due to the Government's recession and the pressure that has been placed on universities to take more enrolments, the Government is not giving out the money that is urgently needed for capital works. Universities around the country are starved of facilities and resources whilst bursting at the seams, yet the Government clearly does not seem to care.

The Opposition's Fightback policies for higher education will give the universities the flexibility and freedom they need to meet the demand placed upon them as society attempts to pursue a better education system. This freedom is essential for world class universities to develop. Under a Liberal government the imposed uniformity of the national unified system will disappear.

Unfortunately, the Government continues to ignore the sound policies of the Opposition, and continues its interference with our higher education institutions. We see that this has left the universities near collapse. The Dawkins legacy to higher education will not create `the clever country'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The report that is being considered by the Senate today is the seventh annual report by the National Crime Authority since it commenced operations in 1984. Quite early in the report it makes the comment that there is very little, if any, contribution from the Intergovernmental Committee. I think this is a relevant factor. I will comment a little later on the fact that the recommendations which were made by the Parliamentary Committee in its report Who is to Guard the Guards? have been held up, at least to some extent, because consultation with the IGC is not proceeding as fast as it possibly could.

PARA.TAB: With respect to the report, there is a number of matters I would like to raise briefly. One is the introduction of performance indicators for the National Crime Authority. This was one of the innovations introduced by its former Chairman, Mr Justice Phillips, who has just resigned. I believe it is a useful development. However, as this report indicates, we will have to wait and see whether the performance indicators which are being suggested—for an activity which is very difficult to measure—to establish efficiency and effectiveness are adequate. All we can say at this stage is that a start has been made in the development of a corporate plan and the setting down of some performance indicators.

I think it is also worth mentioning that the statistics published in the report which the Committee comments on indicate that the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 is working very well. Some $29m has been secured or frozen by the Authority since this strategy was developed. Clearly, this is a strategy which should be continued in the future and which holds out a lot of promise in the fight against organised crime.

Paragraph 23 of the report, on page 7, deals with some of the Committees's recommendations for amendments. The Committee notes a press report in which the `obsessive secrecy' of the Authority is slated. There are three chairmen mentioned—Mr Justice Stewart, Mr Faris, QC, and Mr Justice John Phillips. It is fair to draw attention to the qualification made by the Committee in that report—excluding the period during which Mr Justice John Phillips was chairperson of the NCA when a great deal of cooperation was experienced by the Parliamentary Committee. Notwithstanding that, recommendations were made for amendments to ensure that the Committee—the parliamentary watchdog—can carry out its duties effectively. The Government's delay in coming to grips with the necessary amendments must be a matter of some concern. As I mentioned earlier, the consultation with the IGC appears to be dragging a little. That is at least one of the factors that are holding it back.

To summarise, it was the view of the Committee that its members must be able to obtain information from the NCA to enable them to make a proper judgment on the work of the NCA. It is also conceded by the Committee that there must be certain safeguards, which have been identified. In other words, information which identifies persons in a matter which could be prejudicial to the safety or legal rights of those persons, information which could prejudice legal proceedings, and information which discloses the operational methods of the authority must be viewed as material that is confidential to the extent that members of the Parliamentary Committee may not disclose it. To the extent that the majority report and my recommendations coincide on these matters, I trust that the Government will see fit to introduce these amendments.

There was some divergence of view as to how a conflict of opinion could be resolved between the NCA and the Parliamentary Committee on whether certain factual pieces of information fall within one or other of these three exclusions. As I have set out in my dissenting report, I believe that a judge sitting outside the court system is the proper adjudicator in such a situation. I cannot see that the alternative put forward in the report—the suggestion that the Minister responsible for this area, the Attorney-General, should make the final judgment—is adequate since once again it brings the political sphere into the area of the judgment that needs to be made.

Since I have referred to the report Who is to Guard the Guards?, I wish to commend the secretariat, in particular, Mr Andrew Snedden, Mr Steve Curran and Tony Anderton who have done an excellent job both in that particular evaluation report as well as in assisting the Committee in putting forward these comments which examine the National Crime Authority's annual report for 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Like Senator Spindler, I want to make a few brief observations on the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority on the NCA's annual report. I begin by commending Justice Phillips, who did an outstanding job as the Chairman of the National Crime Authority. His period of office undoubtedly represents a turning point for the Authority as one of Australia's principal law enforcement agencies. I am sure everyone on the Committee—and, indeed, in the Senate—is pleased to wish him well as the incoming Chief Justice for the State of Victoria. I also welcome Mr Sherman as the new Chairman of the NCA.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Spindler said a few moments ago, Justice Phillips introduced many innovations in his period as Chairman of the Authority. Well do I remember the outlining of the program of the electronic courtroom which he oversaw a few months ago in Melbourne. Not only was the innovation valuable, but the electronic courtroom program was opened to the public and showed at first hand what the NCA was capable of doing as an agency that looked across the board in matters of law enforcement in Australia.

I thoroughly endorse the recommendations in the Joint Committee's report, Who is to Guard the Guards?, about the proper role of the Joint Committee as against the role of the Intergovernmental Committee, the IGC. There is no doubt in my mind that the appropriate body for monitoring the National Crime Authority is the Joint Committee rather than the IGC. I think that is demonstrated by the quality of the observations drafted in the report before the Senate this afternoon by the Committee secretariat. I join Senator Spindler in paying tribute to the staff of the secretariat, particularly Mr Andrew Snedden, the Committee Secretary.

The IGC does not seem to have the inclination that the Committee has to work effectively as the monitoring body upon the NCA. There is no doubt that the relationship which currently exists between the Authority and the Joint Committee has not been better. I am sure that Senator Jones, who has served on the Committee longer than I, would endorse those remarks. Primarily that is a result of the NCA now being a much more open and accountable body. Much of that has to do with Mr Justice Phillips in a personal sense. As Chairman of the NCA he certainly made himself available to the media in the broad, responded to inquiries and questions, and was prepared not only to defend the Authority but to argue its case as a law enforcement agency.

There is no doubt that the new corporate ethos of the Authority, as demonstrated by its performance indicators and performance plan referred to in the body of the report, has been impressed by the period Mr Justice Phillips acted as the Chairman. There is no doubt, as outlined in paragraphs 12 and 13 of the report before the Senate this afternoon dealing with performance indicators, that the NCA has now set a mission statement and nine clear objectives. There are now also criteria by which the Authority may be judged as a law enforcement agency. That takes into consideration the difficulties that exist in judging any law enforcement agency as against any private or government business enterprise.

In the report for 1993 the Joint Committee will be able to make a judgment of the performance of the NCA. There is no doubt that its role is changing in the current climate. There is no doubt that the NCA has a role to play as a law enforcement agency dealing with the dilemmas of the 1980s and with the excesses of that period. I refer to the white-collar crime that is only too readily apparent and the corporate abuses that took place in some sectors of business, industry and commerce during the 1980s. It is not only the Australian Securities Commission that has an increased role to play; the NCA also has a very definite role to play in that process.

I make one observation about a problem area which the Committee is in the process of identifying—an area of which the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) are only too well aware. I refer to the witness protection program. There was the murder of Mr Mick O'Brien in Sydney recently. I pass no comment on that, other than to say that it highlighted the need for the witness protection program to be the subject of increased scrutiny at both Federal and State levels. There is no question either that we need a greater degree of cooperation between the Federal and respective State and Territorial governments in making certain that the witness protection program is of the highest order, not only in terms of the protection it affords people within it but also in terms of its aims and objectives.

There is no question that major breakthroughs have occurred in law enforcement matters in the United States as a result of the success of the American witness protection program. There is no question either that we can achieve results at least as beneficial to the community and as effective in terms of matters of law enforcement as the Americans have done through their various programs.
I conclude by drawing the attention of the Senate to paragraph 30 of the Committee's report. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if the auditing function is to be removed from the Ombudsman, the function should be given the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security.

To my mind, if a step is taken to remove the auditing function from the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the proper place for it is the office of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. There is no question that the Committee agrees with that assessment. That is the most practical step that might be taken in the light of the removal of that power from the office of the Ombudsman. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This afternoon we are discussing the examination of the annual report of the National Crime Authority and the report Who is to Guard the Guards?. I endorse the remarks of Senator Spindler and Senator Loosley. In dealing with the examination of the annual report, there is only one area on which I wish to comment, and that is on paragraph 23. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee notes that the same press report stated—
it is the same press report referred to in paragraphs 21 and 22—

`For much of its life under three chairmen—Mr Justice Donald Stewart, Mr Peter Faris QC and Mr Justice John Phillips—it has operated beneath a veil of obsessive secrecy'. There might be some merit in this criticism in relation to the early years of the Authority's existence. However, the criticism is both inaccurate and unfair in relation to the more recent past, especially the period when Justice Phillips was chairman.

Justice Phillips, during his chairmanship, laid down very careful guidelines for the way in which the Authority would open up its activities to the public. He created a position between the NCA and the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority that would allow greater examination of the activities of the NCA by the parliamentary Committee.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the newly appointed Chairman, Mr Sherman, will not only continue in the same vein that Justice Phillips started during his period of office but will continue during his chairmanship to extend the public role of the NCA so that the public can be more aware of the activities of the NCA. I believe that the cooperation that has already been shown by Mr Sherman will continue to be shown to the parliamentary Committee. The parliamentary Committee will also be able to examine the activities of the NCA much more easily as a result of the way in which Mr Sherman has laid down the way in which matters should be dealt with.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Office of Film and Literature Classification and Film and Literature Board of Review

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Calvert:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is evident that guidelines now being used by the Film Censorship Board for the classification of video film material enable the classification for sale or hire of videos with far more violent content than was the case some three or four years ago.

PARA.TAB: I have a great deal of concern about this particular issue because it affects the whole of the community. Indeed, a recent article printed in Time magazine by Robert Manne, entitled `Pornography and Mass Murder', brought to the attention of the general public his concern—and here we are talking about a person with previously rather liberal views—that:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a widespread refusal to acknowledge what is before our noses: that depicted violence and pornography constitute one of the most important causes of psychopathology in contemporary life.

PARA.TAB: From the reports of both last year and this year that have come before the Parliament, I have noted the observations made by the Film Board of Review. My examination of the observations made reinforces my view that more violence is coming through R-rated material and M-rated material than ever before. I shall give the Senate an example of some of the words that have been used in decisions by the Film Board of Review on appeals from producers of various films. For example, the Film Board of Review describes one such video as being `an orgy of violence with a grisly procession of blows, kicks, stabbings, shootings and graphic bone breakings' and having `no mitigating qualities'. That film was given an R-rated classification. The Board of Review said that some of the Film Censorship Board members thought it should have been in the M-rated category.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they failed Skippy.

—Yes, they did. The M-rated category is for children of 15 and above. The Film Board of Review described another film as having `a prevailing tone of ruthlessness and savagery'. This is the type of material that is now being classified for legal hire and sale by the Film Censorship Board. It is most disconcerting.

PARA.TAB: The current paper, which we are considering here, also gives a description by the Film Board of Review of a film which was given an `R' classification by the Film Censorship Board. It indicates that the film was a spectacularly gruesome film and that it struck members of the Board of Review as profoundly objectionable.

These are the types of films that are now able to be hired legally throughout the Commonwealth by courtesy of the Film Censorship Board. I must express my concern because, in a recent letter to a public authority, the Board said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Board notes the recent report of the authoritative National Committee on Violence and found no direct causal link between media violence and violent crime.
That is grossly misleading. The fact is that the Committee spent only an hour and a half on that particular question. (Time expired)
