DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the two papers released by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and listed as the first item. This Committee has published a paper in the series on the cost of legal services and litigation as part of the cost of justice inquiry. It is Discussion Paper No. 5 and it is on legal ethics. I wish to comment on three of the matters that are raised by Dr Parker in that particular discussion paper.

PARA.TAB: This report is an extremely valuable one, bearing in mind the wide-ranging and searching inquiry that is being undertaken by the Cooney Committee on this matter. It is important that we try to illuminate every aspect of the legal system that contributes to the costs that litigants are faced with. A review of legal ethics is, I believe, a particularly appropriate exercise, bearing in mind that the area of legal ethics has grown over the years, starting almost from the Middle Ages. Certainly, some of the practices that are currently being followed by the legal profession could well do with some review.

Dr Parker raises in his report a whole lot of particular duties which, under the code of legal ethics, are intended to be observed by legal practitioners. I only wish to comment on those few in which I am aware some shortcomings exist. I refer in particular to the first item under the general heading of `Duties of Fairness'—the duty not to pursue hopeless cases, to enter hopeless defences or to cause unreasonable expense or delay.

I refer to a case that was recently brought to me by a constituent. The constituent had a legal dispute over an amount not exceeding $2,000, but the ultimate legal costs faced by her were of the order of $60,000. I believe that very much comes under the heading of `a duty not to cause unreasonable expense or delay'.

There is another aspect involved in that which is relevant and that is the aspect of remedy. What does that particular solicitor's client now do, having been faced with this sort of a bill over a dispute involving an amount not exceeding $2,000? I might say that the case is in Victoria and the exact circumstances may differ from State to State. She has three options. First, she can accept what she would consider—and I would agree—an unreasonable offer of settlement. Secondly, she can apply to the Solicitors Board. But even if the Solicitors Board found that the solicitor was at fault or negligent, the limit of the remedy she could achieve would be $2,500, when she is faced with legal costs of $60,000. The third remedy she has is to engage yet another legal practitioner and go to court, charging her former solicitor with negligence or unsatisfactory execution of his or her duties.

Clearly, these are not satisfactory options. I believe that the review of the legal profession's ethics needs to include an examination of whether self-regulation in that instance is really working. In my view it is not. Clearly, we need to look at establishing an independent tribunal that can judge when clients of solicitors or barristers have a complaint and whether that particular complaint can be dealt with in an impartial way.

I turn to another duty that Dr Parker lists; that is, the duty to be loyal. That, on the face of it, of course, is a very admirable quality. It is also the basis of our adversarial system that a solicitor, a legal representative, pursues his or her client's case, right or wrong, particularly in, say, the industrial relations area or the area of family law. Another inquiry which is currently in progress has a lot to consider in terms of the costs that have to be faced by people who go through the Family Law Court system at a very traumatic time of their lives. So I think it is perhaps useful to look at whether our adversarial system works to the benefit of the clients of legal practitioners.

Very often it may be possible—without making the whole change towards the inquisitorial system which is in place in Europe—to consider whether a mitigation of that duty to be loyal come what may could perhaps result in a legal practitioner acting for both parties in a mediator's role, trying to find a solution which overcomes the problems.

The third item I wish to address is the suggestion that we should look for a code of settlement; for a legal culture which tries all possible means of ensuring that the dispute is settled before it takes the time of the court and before it fixes the client with considerable expense. It was instructive to be told that, while on a national basis 5 per cent of all divorces finish up as a dispute that has to be adjudicated in the Family Court, in Tasmania the proportion is of the order of 1.5 per cent. We inquired into the reasons for that disparity and very clearly the small community contributes—lawyers can meet on a fairly regular basis. They can address the difficulties in a constructive manner by simply discussing how the problem cam be solved, rather than how the other side can be trounced.

The thoughts and suggestions that Dr Parker puts forward in this paper on legal ethics warrant the consideration of a much wider audience than just the Committee that is dealing with the cost of justice problems. It should be considered not only by the Senate, but also by the public in general and I am glad that the Committee has published this paper so that it may be circulated to a much wider audience.

The other paper I wish to comment on briefly is a background paper prepared by Dr Ian McEwen from the Research School of Social Sciences and Pacific Studies at the Australian National University which deals with access to legal services and the role of market forces. Also, Dr McEwen lists a number of areas where the legal profession can or should review its practices. For instance, amongst those areas he lists the desirability to reduce the extent to which certain legal services are monopolised by lawyers, and recommends that one should give greater access to paralegals in many areas which are currently being dealt with by the legal profession. Obviously, conveyancing and uncontested divorce cases would fall into that category. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991. I strongly support the remarks of my colleagues and urge the Government to accept the amendments proposed by the National Association of Forest Industries.

PARA.TAB: Senator Archer said that he was interested to see that people were opposing these amendments. When I came into my office this morning my fax machine was thick with material from a very wide range of companies and individuals urging senators to allow this Bill to pass with the amendments proposed by the National Association of Forest Industries.

I thought that I would briefly bring to the attention of the Senate just two of the statements that I received today. One was from Slater Contracting Company. I understand that this logging and earthmoving contractor has written to everyone in the Senate. It says that it is a small logging business in the Eden area of New South Wales employing 14 people. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: We urge you to accept the amendments to the above legislation as supported by the timber industry and unions so that we can once again employ trainees, increase our staff and also replace our ageing equipment which will give a much needed boost to our town and country and help get the economy going.
Hardys of Tumbarumba has put out a press release saying that it is:

. . . a softwood/hardwood sawmilling complex providing decentralised rural employment for 160 direct employees plus approximately 60 contract employees. . . .Hardys urge all sides of Federal Parliament to adopt the industry/Union amendments to the Federal Resources Security Legislation, which seek to protect existing jobs and investment, and encourage future investment in the sawmilling sector.

They are just two of the large number of representations and press releases which I have received. They sum up very nicely what this issue is about. It is an issue about combining a balanced conservation-forestry development program with jobs.

PARA.TAB: As my colleagues have pointed out, we in the coalition will support the amendments proposed by NAFI. As Bruce Lloyd, our shadow Minister for primary industry, and Fred Chaney, the shadow Minister for the environment, have pointed out, these amendments will make bad legislation more acceptable and provide some degree of security for this important national industry to invest up to $8 billion in timber as well as pulp and paper products.

This Bill reflect one major problem—factionalism in the Australian Labor Party and all that that has caused. One only has to look at the developments which have been held up in this country over the last eight or nine years; the jobs which have been lost in the mining and forest industries; and the jobs that have been lost in the tourist industry as a result of the mishandling of the pilots dispute. The list goes on and on. In a sense, we are now facing the symbol of the problems that this Labor Party has in managing the economy.

The Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, has said on the one hand that he is anxious to fast-track developments, including, of course, the development of a major new pulp mill in Tasmania. On the other hand, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, is charged by the Labor Party with keeping the extreme greenies on side. She is determined to ensure that any jobs can be sacrificed for Green votes.

All relevant parties want these amendments. I point out to Senator Sherry that the timber unions and the ACTU want these amendments as do industry associations and companies. I would have thought that is a unity ticket. We can add the State governments to the list of those that are prepared to support these amendments. If we can believe what Minister Griffiths has said and written on this topic, he should certainly be supporting these amendments to the legislation.

Why is the Government so intransigent? Why are we having this refusal to accept the amendments which virtually all parties involved in the industry agree are important? As I said, it is a simple answer: when Australia's national interests conflict with influential interest groups in the Labor Party, narrow Labor Party interests win every time.

As a Victorian senator, I have been able to witness first-hand in my State how the anti-development policies of the Labor Party have destroyed jobs and prevented new developments in the timber industry. Over the last 20 years in my home State of Victoria we have had detailed land use studies to determine appropriate land use classifications. Indeed, the Land Conservation Council, which played a key role in these studies, was an initiative of the former Liberal Hamer Government.

There has been comprehensive public consultation. The Victorian Government developed a timber industry strategy. But the intervention of the Federal Government in State land issues, notably in East Gippsland prior to the last Federal election, renewed uncertainty and undermined the State Government's own timber industry strategy.

The history of the forest industry in Victoria under Labor is a history of lost opportunities, lost jobs and political hypocrisy on a grand scale. Let me give an instance of this. As a result of the policies of the Cain and Kirner Governments to burn residue wood rather than sell it for woodchips, Victoria has lost export revenue in the order of $100m a year. If this wood could be used in pulp mills, the value of these residue chips would be even greater. Royalties for the Victorian Government would have been in the order of $12m a year. A lot of education and community services can be financed from $12m a year, particularly in a State which has been bankrupted by the Labor Government. Yet, in order to appease the extreme environmentalists within its ranks, the Government has prevented the use of much of this valuable material.

There is the other irony that while good pulpable material is burnt in Victoria, Australia is importing eucalyptus pulp from Brazil. It is interesting that after eight wasted years, Steve Crabb, the Victorian Minister for Conservation and Environment, reversed the policy of the Cain and Kirner governments. But by then, as Senator Brownhill would have guessed, the market had moved on, it had found other suppliers. The world economy changes and markets become soft. It will take some time to convince buyers that, based on our past performance, Victoria can be a reliable supplier.

It is worth noting that APM has been woodchipping for about 50 years to supply feed stocks to its Maryvale pulp and paper mill. It is interesting that the timber industry inquiry, chaired by Professor Ian Ferguson, found that the regeneration of forest from which pulp wood was taken was superior to that from forest where it was left.

We in Victoria can recall the Victorian Labor Government's attempt to look at the possibility of establishing a new greenfield pulp mill in East Gippsland. This plant would be worth in the order of $1.2 billion. A report found that both the Maryvale expansion and the new greenfield pulp mill could be supplied from existing sources. Indeed, major companies, including APM and APPM, were encouraged to prepare proposals at some cost to themselves. An office was established in Orbost.

In 1989-90 the process was halted by the Labor Party after these companies had spent substantial sums. In summary, this great proposal to develop a major new greenfield pulp and paper mill had fallen through because of factional difficulties in the ALP. While the Labor Party dithered on the proposal for a new greenfield plant in East Gippsland, five or six new plants were built elsewhere in the world, including two in Alberta, Canada. Market position and the opportunities to create Australian jobs had been lost, and we continue to import more wood and wood products from other countries in the world.

I am pleased to report that the amendments proposed by the Opposition are fully supported by the Victorian Association of Forest Industries. The Director of that association, Mr Norman Houn, put out a press release to that effect yesterday. Australian paper manufacturers have written to Mr Alan Griffiths urging him to accept the Opposition amendments. In a letter, APM announced last month that some $154m would be spent over the next four years to increase the capacity of its Maryvale plant. But had the Victorian Government shown the enthusiasm it now shows for enabling the expansion of Maryvale in the 1980s—in other words, it has done an about-turn again—we may well have had this major expansion up and running, creating import placement worth hundreds of millions of dollars a year. The Managing Director of APM, Mr McFarlane, said:

SPEECH.PARA: This expenditure to improve our position in import replacement for the domestic market is dependent on resource security at the State and Federal level. We therefore request you to find a `bankable solution' to the dilemma to resource security.
Our Maryvale operation is solely dependent upon residues from integrated sawlog operations in the Central Highlands of Victoria and we believe regional security is essential.
Mr McFarlane concluded this letter by supporting the amendments which are now before this chamber. He stated:
I would urge you to consider appropriate amendments as suggested by NAFI.
It was pleasing to note some foreshadowing of regional security in the economic statement in the CALM/AHC proposals.

Let us not forget that even if there is agreement by all parties for the northern Tasmanian pulp mill to go ahead, it will take anything up to two years for the environmental assessments that this Government demands to be prepared. But there may be a happy end to all this; by that time, a new government will be in office, and we will make sure the mill goes ahead.

PARA.TAB: The people standing in the way of these amendments are Mr Richardson and Mrs Kelly who are prepared to push an extreme Green line at the expense of jobs. We know that Alan Griffiths supports the thrust of these amendments. We have only to read his information paper on resource security, which he released on 19 February last year. What we do not know is whether Alan Griffiths has the courage and political clout to ensure that the legislation to encourage jobs will be passed in this chamber and to ensure that the intransigent position that elements in the Government are adopting do not destroy jobs.

In conclusion, I would like to say that public attitudes towards the industry versus the environment issue are changing. The survey carried out by Brian Sweeny and Associates, which was sent to the Prime Minister just the other day, showed a remarkable shift in attitudes by voters on the vexing question of industry activity-resource versus the environment. A great majority—over 60 per cent—have now come to the balanced view that both can coexist equitably.

I put it to honourable senators that this Bill seeks to ensure just what the public are now saying that they strongly support. We support the amendments which are proposed by NAFI. As I pointed out earlier in my remarks, a very comprehensive unity ticket supports these amendments, including Senator Sherry's mates in the union movement, and I will be interested to hear what Senator Sherry has to say. I urge the Senate to ensure that the amendments to the legislation are passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this country, $1 in every $10 of our overseas debt is in forestry and forestry-related products. We continue to be one of the largest exporters of woodchips in the world and we continue to be one of the most significant importers of processed pulp and paper in the world. That, simply put, is economic lunacy. In terms of value added, the value of woodchips is approximately $80 a tonne; the value of paper is $800 a tonne; and if we go that one step further in the forest industries, the value of timber in the building and furniture industry can be up to $8,000 a tonne.

PARA.TAB: I have chosen to speak in this debate on the Forest Conservation and Development Bill because I am a member of the Caucus resource security committee and also, as I am a senator representing the State of Tasmania where forest issues, particularly over the last 15 years, have been a very major source of public debate. Forest industries in Tasmania are a very significant contributor to the Tasmanian economy. To those honourable senators who are not aware of this, Tasmania has approximately 50 per cent of Australia's eucalypt hardwood available for processing into sawlogs.

In this debate I intend to cover a number of topics. Firstly, I intend to give a brief overview of the legislation that we are considering. Secondly, I intend to relate that to the Tasmanian State resource security legislation. I then intend to make some comments about the approach of the Democrats-Greens to the issue of the forest industries, particularly resource security legislation. I then intend to make some comments about the attitude of the Federal Liberal Party. I will then be making some comments about a current industrial dispute in Tasmania with APPM, the proponents of a pulp mill in northern Tasmania, before making some concluding remarks.

The legislation is entitled the Forest Conservation and Development Bill, but is more commonly known as resource security legislation. As a member of the Labor Party Caucus resource security committee, I was involved in a consultation process in the drafting of this legislation. I note with interest that the speaker's list on this legislation is growing daily; we now have some 25 persons speaking, nine of them from Tasmania. I certainly do not believe that is any coincidence, given the controversy of forestry issues in that State.

The legislation that is before us has one dominant purpose and that is to ensure new investment of at least $100m to produce goods for export and/or import replacement. The legislation is not designed to protect the industrial status quo by providing security to any use of wood for any purpose from any region. It is designed to shift the industry towards export-oriented, value adding activities and to facilitate large projects of that kind. World-scale pulp mills are, of course, the paradigm case, and we want to see such developments at the earliest opportunity.

In order for this legislation to be met, there is a set of integrated activities. This does not mean that we should countenance a mere collection of sawmills as being eligible for resource security. I will return to that issue later when I deal with the objections of the Opposition. In the legislation we have also recognised that significant large scale investments of the type we are endeavouring to encourage can and do arise when companies expand or extend their existing facilities, perhaps through modernising or upgrading their plants.

The Government is determined to focus on investments of this size, that is, over $100m, in the context of this legislation because what the Government is offering to industry is not being done lightly. The Government is saying to industry, `We, as the Government of Australia, after conducting a comprehensive integrated assessment and satisfying ourselves that certain obligations have been entered into by the enterprise and the State Government, will tie ourselves by legislation not to use our statutory powers, except in exceptional circumstances'.

This legislation will also encourage a significant increase in the area of commercial plantations in Australia. It provides for an up-front assessment. The real antecedents of this legislation can be found in the forest industry's feelings of uncertainty. That uncertainty has been engendered by fear of the Commonwealth using its powers to remove significant tracts of forest from productive investments.

As part of the legislation, and part of the process, a thorough and comprehensive integrated assessment of any proposed project is required. The legislation carefully spells out the nature of that assessment. I do not intend in this speech to go into the detailed nature of that assessment, except to comment that it is a very comprehensive assessment that will cover all the values likely to be affected—environmental, cultural, heritage, social and economic.

The Australian Heritage Commission must have a reasonable opportunity to consider and comment on matters that are within its ambit. The processes under the Commonwealth's Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act have also to be complied with. This legislation does not water down the Government's environmental policies or its legislation. On the contrary, it ensures that environmental issues are taken into account, as they should be, up front, not after the process has begun.

Agreements between the Commonwealth, the State and the enterprise will be entered into. When the Commonwealth issues a declaration that a project has resource security, it will do so on the basis of formal written agreements between it and the State in which the project is to be conducted and between the State and the enterprise. These agreements will be public and they will be legally binding. These agreements, together with the integrated up-front assessment, are the foundation of resource security.

There are five potential circumstances set out in the Bill under which Ministers might need to reactivate their dormant powers. Again, I do not intend to go into detail about the five areas in which those dormant powers can be activated.

It is important to examine this Federal legislation in the context of the recent legislation that was passed in Tasmania. Before I do that, I point out that the Federal legislation has the capacity to pave the way for a pulp mill in northern Tasmania, for the existing mill in Maryvale in Victoria to be upgraded and, over the next decade, for significant major projects in Western Australia and east Gippsland in Victoria. The legislation encourages strong development in a sectoral way by setting the parameters for investment in a particular section—a very important section of our economy—by encouraging export-oriented growth.

In Tasmania last year a Bill called the Forest Reform Bill was passed; it is more commonly known in that State as resource security legislation. This legislation followed a two-year examination of every conceivable aspect of the forest industry in Tasmania, certainly the most comprehensive examination of the way in which the forest industry in Tasmania is conducted and probably the most comprehensive examination of a forest industry anywhere in the world.

It is very important to bear in mind that the aim of this State legislation was to create an integrated approach to economic and environmental decision making, so that sustainable—I emphasise that word `sustainable', particularly for the Democrats' purposes—management of our multiple-use forests can be achieved.

There was general agreement that changes to the present systems in Tasmania were needed if Tasmanians were to gain the maximum benefit from their forest, land, labour and investment resources. The legislation was ultimately passed last year after considerable political wheeling and dealing by the then Liberal Opposition, which attempted to enter into a marriage of convenience with the Greens to defeat that legislation—albeit for reasons different from those given by those who adopt a somewhat similar approach in this chamber.

That Bill is the first part of changes in legislation that will include resource security as the method for defining how different forest lands should be managed in the State of Tasmania. It is necessary to improve security of employment and stimulate investment in our forest-based industries and to make the best use of a public asset in a way that would benefit all Tasmanians.

Very briefly, the process that was followed examined every conceivable aspect of the forest industries in Tasmania, including the traditional concessions system. In the past in Tasmania vast areas of the State have been concessioned off to companies like APPM and ANM and they had a monopoly hold over those lands. It also examined industrial relations practices in the forest industry. It set aside further lands for protection in the form of World Heritage areas, national parks and State reserve, so that 27 per cent of the land area of Tasmania is now made up of State reserves, World Heritage areas and national parks. I emphasise that figure—27 per cent of the land area of Tasmania.

That process also provided for multiple-use forests. Those multiple-use forests will take up approximately 15 per cent of Tasmania. Not all of that 15 per cent of Tasmania, which is categorised as multiple-use forests, will be logged. Significant areas of that 15 per cent of Tasmania will not be logged because, if there is to be minimal damage to the environment as part of this process of resource security in Tasmania, it must be carried out in a much more environmentally sensitive way through the preservation of significant tracts of forest around stream areas and on steep slopes, et cetera.

It also looked at the way in which forest practices in the forest industry could be improved. The more intensive management of forests would increase productivity by the more efficient use of technology, scientific research and development, and by downstreaming or value adding. Again, this Federal Government's commitment is clearly illustrated by the developments that have taken place in the last eight years in the Furniture Research and Design Centre in Tasmania. I recommend that members of the Senate visit the Furniture Research and Design Centre in Hobart which produces magnificent furniture, again value adding for export.

Also, the Tasmanian legislation provided for a new system of sawmilling licences. This issue is particularly important in the context of the demand being made by those opposite to reduce this $100m threshold, but I will return to that a little later.It was a comprehensive attempt to develop a forest industry based on a broad consensus with the unions, the larger companies, the small sawmilling operators, the private landholders and the environment movement. All of the major players in Tasmania were involved in the consultative process but, at the last minute, the environment movement decided not to support the process, although it participated in that process over a period of some two years.

The environment movement clearly showed by that approach that it was not prepared to compromise.There is a significant strain in the environment movement in Tasmania that holds to the principle that there should be no logging of native forests whatsoever. I will return to the principle that they espouse a little later when I deal with the Democrats-Greens and some of the arguments that they advance.

We have in Tasmania a thorough, comprehensive forest industry package that has been passed through State Parliament and has been legislated on. Connecting with that is the very important next step of the Federal legislation that is before the Senate today.

I would like now to turn to some of the objections that have been raised by what I term the Democrats-Greens in this place and in public debate on this issue over the last few years. The Democrats-Greens adopt a number of themes. Their first proposition is that there are declining jobs in the forest industry and that, therefore, we should not support this industry any more; we should not have it. I agree with their first factual analysis that the employment opportunities in this industry are declining, except in the furniture sector where there is a real increase in job numbers. But I do not agree with their conclusion that we do not have an industry. If we followed the Green economic lunacy—and that is what it is, economic lunacy—then we could come to the conclusion that because jobs are declining in almost every manufacturing industry in this country, on their logic we do not have manufacturing industry, which is absolute nonsense.

The Greens-Democrats also advance another theme that we should say no to world scale pulp mills and instead go for the smaller, presumably more environmentally friendly, pulp mills. There is just one snag with that argument, and that is that no-one wants to build small pulp mills. The trend around the world is towards large world scale pulp mills that are technology rich and are not big employers of labour.

The Greens also advance the argument that there should be no logging of old growth forests. The consequence of that argument is, in Tasmanian terms—and I speak of Tasmania because of my own knowledge of this industry in Australia and in that State—that no logging of old growth forests and a switch to plantations would be catastrophic. It would mean that the logging of most of the forests in Tasmania would cease. Whilst some persons within their own moral code, within their own ethos, might believe that that is a good thing, I put it to the Senate that 27 per cent of the land area of Tasmania cannot be logged, and that really represents a very adequate proportion of the State and a very adequate representation of the biodiversity that is contained within the State of Tasmania.

To advocate no logging of areas outside those areas that have been preserved and reserved is quite a disastrous policy.It also ignores the fact that logging is an integrated activity. In Tasmania, when logging the old growth forests—hopefully, primarily, for sawlog—the inevitable fact is that there is quite a significant amount of waste because logs are round. The Democrats-Greens might have a problem with accepting the fact that logs are round. If one goes into a forest and recovers 30 per cent of that forest for sawlogging, at least 70 per cent of what is left is waste. On the logic of the Greens-Democrats that waste would lie on the ground and they would just burn it or leave it there to rot.

This would be absolutely ridiculous for two reasons: first, it is a waste of a valuable economic resource that can hopefully be converted into pulp and paper; and, second, if they leave that resource—the waste—on the ground, then that waste will ensure, if it is left where it is, that the regrowth forest is an absolute shambles and mess. The waste has to be cleared away. The approach in Tasmania is to maximise from logging the high value-adding yields and the sawlog activity, and what is left is chipped for pulp and paper and, hopefully, processed in this country and not exported.

The Greens-Democrats advance another argument, and that is that this logging activity in Tasmania is terrible because it discourages tourism. The tourism industry in Tasmania has gone through unprecedented growth over the last 20 years, even with significant logging activity. I put it to the Senate and to the Greens-Democrats that we can successfully have both activities. We can have the development of a comprehensive, sensitive, tourism industry and we can have the development of a comprehensive and environmentally sensitive forest industry, including the use of old growth forests.

The reality of the approach of the Greens-Democrats was well summed up by a journalist last week. In fact, the Democrats were a bit sensitive about the description, but I am going to use it today—it is the moonbeam approach. That is the best way to describe the approach of the Democrats and the Greens. Little light and no substance—the moonbeam approach. If we are to stop logging and we are to stop integrated forestry in this country, that is a recipe for mounting debt, it is a recipe for not adding value to our raw resources and it is a recipe for increasing unemployment. I have to concede that when I talk to some of the Greens and Democrats about this issue some of them do put the view that we should not have economic growth, and some of them truly believe in that approach. I suppose, logically, if they believe that, then they are quite happy to put up with a situation of declining value adding and increasing unemployment.

But significant sections of the Greens and the Democrats are not honest about that approach and they are not willing to admit that their approach will mean an end to forestry in this country; it will mean increasing unemployment and it will mean declining value adding. Because of our increasing debt, of which 10 per cent is in forest and forestry products, it will mean that all the things the Democrats want to do—and presumably fund through a much expanded public sector—will not be possible, because if we cannot have sustained economic growth, how can we have growth in the public sector and all the sorts of things that they advocate, many of which I share?

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish you'd use those arguments in other places.
—I do. It is very important that we have significant downstreaming with sustainable development, protection of the environment and an appropriate level of employment.

PARA.TAB: I would now like to turn to the approach of the Opposition. I suppose it is much less honest than the Democrats-Greens, because at least the Democrats-Greens have been consistent. Even though I do not agree with much of their philosophy, it certainly has always been clearly and consistently put. They oppose this legislation in principle. Whilst I do not agree with the theories they are advancing, certainly I can respect their view. Those opposite have raised a plethora of arguments and amendments so as not to support this legislation. Dr Hewson, unfortunately, charged into this debate with little knowledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual.

—As usual, that is right. The Opposition is caught with a consumption tax it does not want; and it is now caught with a fundamentally flawed approach to resource security. Dr Hewson got conned by his shadow Cabinet and, unfortunately, those opposite have been conned by Dr Hewson—particularly the Tasmanian Liberals, and I will say a little more about them later.

PARA.TAB: But the Opposition has advanced a number of concerns about this legislation. I do not want to deal with the amendments one by one; I will just deal with the themes that have been raised. There are a number of amendments relating to the eligibility of State forest industry investment programs. The Government fully appreciates the important role which the sawmilling sector plays in the industry and its concern to have secure access to forest resources. The Commonwealth will provide a legislative level of resource security for the sawmilling sector. Indeed, in Tasmania, through the State resource security, we have considerable protection for small sawmillers. I will return to that later in the context of the Tasmanian Liberal senators' approach, because they know that this is the case.

In addition to the legislation for the sawmilling sector, the Government intends to provide non-legislative resource security for investments which do not meet the $100m threshold. So the argument about the $100m threshold is a nonsense. Indeed, it is interesting and somewhat ironic that those opposite are suggesting that the Federal Government should become involved in the assessment of every forest project and sawmilling project in this country. The growth needed in the Federal bureaucracy to ensure a proper examination of every conceivable project in this country is a novel approach for the Opposition—indeed, a very new approach. I just wish it would consider the consequences if we remove the $100m threshold.

The other issue that has been raised by those opposite in the context of this debate is compensation. I believe that if there had been some commonsense shown by the Opposition on this issue, that issue could have been dealt with.

I would like to turn now to the conduct of my Liberal colleagues from Tasmania. Last week in the other place during a debate which was not very illuminating, an absurd series of propositions were put forward by some honourable members. For example, Mr Miles, the honourable member for Braddon, stated two reasons for opposing this legislation. The first was that a company such as APPM does not have sufficient incentive through the depreciation schedules to provide for investment. All I can say about the comments of Mr Miles is that he obviously did not read the One Nation package in which we have put forward a series of new and comprehensive depreciation schedules, which have been welcomed by the industry. So he cannot use that argument. Indeed, Mr Miles's State Leader, Ray Groom, welcomed the improvements in depreciation schedules. So Mr Miles obviously does not listen to his own State Liberal Leader in Tasmania.

In the media over the last week in Tasmania—and we saw it last night as well—the new Premier of Tasmania, Mr Groom, urged Tasmanian Liberal senators to support the legislation. We often hear Opposition senators from Tasmania say that they are here representing Tasmania; that they will fight for Tasmania. They are being advised by their State colleagues, and particularly the State Premier, Mr Ray Groom, to support this legislation. What are they doing? They are ignoring their State Liberal colleagues and they are ignoring the principles by which they often come in here and espouse States rights. They are full of rhetoric, but their rhetoric does not match their action on this issue. For example, in early March this year, Mr Ray Groom said that he was:

SPEECH.PARA: sick of the politicking on the fate of this important legislation. I do not mind saying I want the coalition in Canberra to support the legislation.
Obviously, members of the coalition here are not listening to what Mr Ray Groom has to say. He went on to say:
I think they were wrong in taking the stand they are taking. Obviously you need good arguments to reject that legislation if a pulp mill depends on it.
We then had some of the most ridiculous comments I have ever heard in politics from Mr Smith, the honourable member for Bass in the other place. He said that he could not support the legislation:
. . . because it was being supported by the ALP's extreme Left and the dark Greens, a piece of legislation they had long sought.

Well, I have some information for Mr Smith. The Left within the labour movement generally has opposed this legislation, not supported it. If that is the best Mr Smith can do, the Opposition's position on this legislation really is a joke.

PARA.TAB: So they are the sorts of arguments that we have had particularly from Tasmanian Opposition members of this place and the other chamber. The fact of life for those opposite is that Dr Hewson made a mistake. It is interesting to note that he will never admit he makes a mistake. His problem is that he cannot back down and admit that he is wrong.

Before I conclude, I want to make a comment about APPM's recent approach to industrial relations. Whilst I support resource security legislation—and I think I have worked fairly hard and vigorously to ensure at State and Federal levels that that legislation is supported and passed—I condemn the industrial relations approach of APPM. There was a debate on that issue in the Senate after Question Time today. I condemn APPM for unilaterally attempting to cancel many of the over-award conditions of its employees in Tasmania and consistently refusing to meet with the union movement and its work force in order to discuss and resolve that issue. It has unilaterally cancelled industrial agreements. That sort of behaviour—

TALK.START.PARA: —You're not going to mislead us too, are you? We were misled at lunchtime.

—I have read the letters. Many of the members of the work force at APPM in Tasmania have come to me and shown me the letters that were sent to them unilaterally withdrawing some of their industrial conditions. That sort of approach is to be condemned. That sort of approach does not, unfortunately, help this debate.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, one in every $10 of this country's debt is in forest industry products. We need downstreaming. We need value adding. We need to ensure that our balance of payments is corrected because we need employment and we need jobs. This legislation is a positive aid, a positive sectoral development, to ensure through some parameters the development of the forest industries in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has rightly been pointed out by earlier speakers, the concept of resource security legislation or, as it is curiously termed, the Forest Conservation and Development Bill, is anathema to the Green movement. In the context of this Bill, resource security is designed to provide guaranteed access to precious assets at low cost for the benefit of large corporations and to the detriment of the global eco-system and to those employed in the timber industry.

PARA.TAB: In Tasmania, for example, the major reason for resource security legislation was to provide industry with short term legislative guarantees to enable the forest industry to maximise its profit. As many are aware, native forest woodchipping will become uneconomic in less than 15 years when the large number of eucalypt plantations around the world will reach maturity.

Neither the Government nor the Opposition is truly interested in building a viable and sustainable forest industry which would provide real security of employment and lifestyle for workers in the industry; where the profits derived from forest operations benefited the whole of the community, instead of being shipped offshore with our trees. Neither the Government nor the Opposition realises the full extent to which they are being played off by the timber industry interests in this current debate.

I can scarcely blame business and industry. Why should they not test the limits and push to get all they can? If the Government or Opposition is prepared to give away a cash crop and put no pressure on the development of sustainable agricultural feed stocks and environmentally safe downstreaming, why should they not take advantage of that?

As other senators are aware, the recent agreement between the Conservation and Land Management Department of Western Australia and the Australian Heritage Commission has been proposed as the model for providing non-legislative resource security. The agreement was poorly conceived and confirms the conservation movement's fears that State and Federal governments are still willing to lock in unsustainable logging regimes around Australia. This will lead to the conversion of almost all of Australia's remaining ecologically diverse native forests into immature regrowth, which is of questionable environmental value. I regret that neither this Government nor previous governments took the opportunity to shift all sectors of the timber industry to a sustainable and secure footing, but rather they perpetuated the short term, profit-driven approach to resource development. All governments for the past 20 years have been willing to facilitate the unsustainable mining of our old-growth forests as a cash export crop, primarily for the profit of Japanese paper mills. No government has seriously facilitated any move to downstream process the trees that are cut down, despite this being a condition of woodchip licences since 1970.

Along with the increasing power of the woodchipping sector as the driving force behind the industry, there has been a coincident loss in jobs within the industry. The Green movement could potentially be the greatest ally of the timber industry and its workers, since grown trees are the most environmentally friendly supply of packaging, furniture, writing and building materials. However, the Green movement cannot honestly support an industry while it actively supports the destruction of natural areas and the species they contain.

Many statements have been made in the debate to the effect that `the Greens do not want this Bill because they do not want development', and that the Government is aiming for Green preferences by being lenient in relation to the conditions that this particular resource security legislation imposes. Those sorts of statements are not correct. In fact, the Green movement has genuine concern about the way in which this Bill is presented because it does not meet the true needs of the workers or the industry in the provision of jobs.

People have been heavily emotionally blackmailed by the threat that unless the timber industry is provided with all this free, old-growth native forest material, there will be no investment later on in downstreaming. There has been no investment for 20 years, so why should we believe that there will be now? Once our precious resources are gone, they are gone forever. Regrowth cannot compare with the thousands of years of native forests that we are sacrificing in the vain hope that industry will have the integrity to do something that it has been promising to do for 20 years.

In the 200 years since Europeans colonised this country over 45 per cent of forest land has been cleared. Native forests are precious, safe houses for a diverse range of ecosystems and they must be protected at all costs. It is ironic that in the months leading up to the Earth Summit in Brazil, where many world leaders are set to sign a biodiversity convention, the Federal Government has felt obliged to introduce this archaic legislation which harks back to the golden years of exploitation of this country's resources. It also seems incongruous, in a year when the Government is moving closer to finally introducing legislation to protect endangered species, that it has introduced a Bill which seeks to destroy the forest habitats of many of those endangered species.

Resource security seems to be entirely a flag-flying exercise on the part of the Federal Government. It arose largely because the timber industry decided that it was time to flex its muscles and show its international bankers that it does have the political power to force government to respond to its wishes. However, it is unlikely that any of the promised pulp mills will ever be built in Australia. The world pulp and paper market will continue to be flooded by cheap woodchips and pulp from Third World nations. Australia has lost the race to build any pulp mills based on a native forest resource. As a consequence, the major aim of this legislation will not be fulfilled. In other words, no investment and no jobs.

By persisting with this Bill the Government has chosen to ignore the findings of the Resource Assessment Commission's report on forestry industry, the work done during the ecologically sustainable development process, and the report of the National Plantation Advisory Committee. These reports all found that the forestry industry is currently unsustainable. The cost to our community of resource security over publicly owned forests will be the total obliteration of our old-growth and native forests—all done for the scant hope that some transnational companies might make an investment in Australia by building a highly automated, low-labour pulp mill.

The Wilderness Society, the Australian Conservation Foundation and Greenpeace, among others, have clearly outlined the employment opportunities in ecologically sustainable industry, and in particular through a realignment of the timber industry to a plantation base, as well as jobs involving the development of renewable energy and energy efficiency. I would like to stress that the Greens would support the development of a niche market in quality recycled paper. We do support downstream processing and incentive being given for the development of it.

Clean process pulp and paper mills for plantation or agriculturally based feed stocks would be much more acceptable because they would not be damaging to our environment and they would not be depriving us of our precious native old-growth forests. People may not be aware that using native old-growth forests absolutely necessitates the most damaging pulp mills. We would be prepared to look at non-kraft, non-chlorine processing mills. However, as I have already mentioned, the race has been lost. The persistent use of our native growth forests also means the persistent use of outdated, dangerous, environmentally damaging pulp mills.

True resource security for industry comes from growing timber crops on our own land. We have plenty of land. We do not need to make inroads into the precious little native forest we have left. However, the opportunity does exist for Australia to become a world leader in making high quality recycled paper. Governments should be making every effort to encourage investment in this area.

Industry deserves to have a secure source of feed stock, but governments should not be in the business of providing legislative guarantees that limit their powers to protect the environment. They certainly should not be tying themselves to something on which they cannot change their mind when other factors arise.

I urge honourable senators to reject this inappropriate and unwarranted legislation. Instead, I urge the Government to investigate mechanisms which will encourage the establishment of a truly sustainable timber industry based on plantations, and a high quality, export-oriented recycled paper industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I take the opportunity to congratulate Senator Chamarette on her maiden speech yesterday and on her first contribution to a Bill relating to the environment. Many senators were aware that her predecessor—who stood originally on a peace movement ticket and later for the Greens—was absent from the chamber on many occasions when important Bills came up for debate, although she maintained to the people of Western Australia that she was representing them in those matters. I congratulate Senator Chamarette on her maiden speech. She is a colleague of mine from that great State of Western Australia, with great forests and a great environment—no thanks to the Government of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: We are here today not so much to discuss resource security or to discuss a Bill with a dubious title, but because of the crass political manipulation of the environment debate, specifically by this Labor Government, but to a certain extent by Labor governments throughout Australia—Labor governments that have burdened Australians for the past eight or nine years. We are here because the old ways of protecting the environment, the old ways of centralised control and government control of vast tracts of land, and centralised control through planning authorities and environment protection authorities, have not worked. They have not worked for a good many reasons, but the main reason is that, when we want to protect a resource or an environment, the last person we would want to give that responsibility to is a politician or bureaucrat, because the forces that go to work on politicians and bureaucrats are not necessarily the forces that best protect the environmental values that all of us hold dear.

We all put different emphasis on how we would seek to protect the environment, but I think at the heart of most of the people in this chamber there is a genuine commitment to protecting our environment and to rehabilitating some of the problems that have been created by bad management of the environment and our natural heritage in the past.

We have been faced with this dilemma in Australia, particularly in the last eight years—although some of the decisions of previous governments were in the same vein, so it has not been limited to the last eight years. Whenever we come up with a problem—be it in the environment, industry or taxation policy—this Government does not face the important questions of public policy, the best interests of the nation and the best interests of the individuals within this nation. Instead, in its corporatist style, it approaches its mates in either the union movement, the environmental movement or even in big business and seeks to do a deal that acts in the interests of the politicians, the bureaucrats, the Australian Labor Party and the trade union movement.

During the last couple of years we witnessed the blatant political manipulation of the environment agenda by the former Minister for the Environment, Senator Richardson. We witnessed his crass manipulation of the preferences of the Greens and the Democrats in the last Federal election. Indeed, any analysis of the results of that election will show that Senator Richardson's manipulation of that vote and the issues was the reason that my colleagues and I are sitting on this side of the chamber and not on the other side. Of course, the important thing to understand is that the environment has not been better protected by the corporatist big government regulatory interventionist approach that has been pursued by this Labor Government and, indeed, by many governments of different political persuasions in the past.

We are discussing the concept of resource security. I put it to the Senate that we cannot have any proper resource security without property rights. Senator Chamarette supported that contention when she said that the real resource security we get is from privately owned plantations. I am suggesting to the Senate that until we have private ownership of forests—whether plantations or natural eucalypt forests—we will not have resource security.

The problem with this legislation is that it is a crass reaction to a problem caused by the Federal Labor Government. We never used to discuss resource security eight or nine years ago because there were proper State agreements in place and resource security was granted on a State by State, project by project, basis by the relevant authorities. It is only the crass manipulation of the politics of the environment that has seen resource security come under threat. All of a sudden we have this reaction in a fatally flawed piece of legislation to protect the resource required by the forestry based industries.

We must look at the serious public policy goals of the environment and, of course, of protecting the forests and all of the values that lie within those forests. We need to look at the value of the wilderness, the value of maintaining a habitat and the very important value of natural forests as a sink for greenhouse gases. We also need to look at their value as a renewable resource for the timber industry. We need to look at their value for recreation purposes and we also need to look at their value as a buffer zone between the growing metropolises around Australia. We need some natural heritage to surround our concrete jungles and our ever sprawling metropolitan areas and metropolitan suburbs.

It comes down to an issue of management. In Australia we have seen an enormous concentration on public sector management and public sector ownership of these forest resources. The alternative is to move totally to private sector management or ownership. I do not think the Australian people would cop all of the national parks and the forests being owned by the private sector. The obvious solution is to have a balanced mix. That is what is missing at the moment; there is no balanced mix between public ownership and private ownership. I want to put to the Senate a more radical solution to this problem, probably outside the ambit of this Bill, but clearly a matter that is raised by the important issues of principle.

I want to refer briefly to one of the fundamental weaknesses of this Bill. It relates to a matter that Senator Sherry referred to earlier concerning the $100m cut-off and the fact that this legislation is designed to encourage the development of big—as Senator Sherry said—internationally competitive pulp mills. The real fact of this legislation is that in specifying projects of over $100m and providing only those projects with so-called resource security, we are actually picking industrial winners. The Government has made the decision that Australia's future in forest and timber products is related only to these massive $100m projects. It says that this is where all the employment will occur and this is where the future lies for Australia's forest industries.

I put it to the Senate that members of the Government are the last people who should be able to decide where the winners are going to be in forest industries. I am sure most people around this chamber—and the Greens and the Democrats—would agree with me when I say that it is probably better for Australia's future if the Government gets out of picking winners and ensures that we have some genuine resource security for all industries related to forest and timber products. Indeed, why pick on $100m projects when we could just allow the market to decide on whether we have one $100m project or ten $1m projects?

The reality in the forest industries at the moment—I know this from my own personal experience in the south-west of Western Australia—is that the people who use the forest resource most effectively, the people who get the real value out of each log and who extract the most timber from each log, are the very small operators who provide niche markets. Why can we not have a forest industry that has hundreds of little forest operators in the forests all around Australia, some based on plantations, some based on original natural forests, supplying niche markets and coming up with systems and new techniques to extract the maximum value from the forest resource? One of the reasons why that does not happen is because the forest resource is, by and large, owned by the public sector. It does not price the value of either the logs, the forests, the other timber products or the other important values from forests—that is, recreational uses and habitat value and so forth—because the State Government sets the value of the forest resource. I put it to the Senate that we are not ending up with the proper, effective or efficient economic use of our forest resource. That is one of the reasons.

One of the other fatal flaws of the argument of the Democrats and the Greens is this idea of closing down all native forests and ensuring that all of our future forest products are provided by plantations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let the trees die of old age.

—That is right, we should let them all die of old age, like old politicians. One of the problems is that if we do not have a properly based economic set of incentives because the value of State-owned native forest is underpriced by public ownership, there is no incentive to develop proper plantations. If the value of the timber is underpriced, the value of plantation timber is underpriced so we do not have a proper incentive to plant plantations.

PARA.TAB: The other problem with basing our industry on plantations is that we destroy one of the important aspects that the Greens talk about—that is, biodiversity. That is a complicated word which I do not really understand but which I thought I would slip in. More seriously, biodiversity is the intricate ecosystem that operates within forests. If we have plantations of softwood or hardwood all over the place and we do not have a balanced ecosystem which takes place within a native forest, we cannot achieve our aim of ensuring that biodiversity is maintained.

There is a real alternative. It is, of course, increasing private ownership of native eucalypt forests. It is a concept which was very ably put on the Australian political agenda by the Tasman Institute last year in its submission to the Resource Assessment Commission inquiry into the use of forests in Australia.

There are a number of examples around the world where private ownership of native forests has achieved all the aims of the environmental movement as well as the aims of the private sector, which seeks to derive profit and create jobs from native forests. I think Australia and this Government should look at the private management of national parks—indeed, the Opposition will look at this. At the moment, national parks are managed by rangers and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. In many cases the national parks are very badly managed. I put it to the Senate that the management of many national parks and State forests around Australia could be contracted out to the private sector. Many of the objectives we have sought would be achieved more cost effectively.

As I have said, the approach of the Federal Labor Government, and of many governments in the past, to environment policy is to convert the public concern about the environment into a catalyst or a Trojan horse to centralise more power and control over all aspects of the environment into the hands of government. Putting power and control into the hands of a few politicians and bureaucrats has dangerous consequences for the economy, for individual liberty and, very importantly, for the future of our natural environment. It is simply not possible for a centralised group of so-called experts to manage and control the extraordinarily diverse resources, decision-making processes and events that are crucial to the environment. Yet this Government is trying to do just hat.

I will cite a few brief examples from around the world of where private management and ownership of forests have been quite successful. Forests and other wilderness areas have a large range of uses and values. The current debate concentrates only on the value of the timber resource. I suggest that control of the land by a government controlled agency is perhaps the last way a rational person would seek to maximise or even place value on many of these other amenities that a forest can have.

TALK.START.PARA: —The trouble with you is you believe it.
—I do believe it and I believe it very vehemently.
—That's the problem.

—One day I will be proved right—the Government has already been proved wrong. Government ownership and control of native forests have proved to be a failure. That is why we are here debating this resource security legislation today.
—Is that right?

—That is exactly right. There is a very good example of private ownership of wilderness areas in Senator Bolkus's home State. I refer to Dr Walmsley who is doing a very good job of protecting native species, endangered species and the bush in South Australia on a limited scale. He is a very good example of how private management can manage national parks and wilderness values.
—It's a very simplistic assessment.

—Yes, it is, but it is made simplistic so that even Senator Bolkus can understand it. If we analyse what we have in our forests—with their innate beauty, their value as a natural resource of timber and paper, their wilderness value as a store for genetic diversity, as a wildlife habitat and for recreational uses, with their global value as a sponge for greenhouse gases—we must ask the following question. Could they not be better protected, enhanced and expanded by being privately managed and, in some cases, privately owned? As I have said, the indisputable fact is that private management of timber, recreation uses and so forth has been proved right around the world.

PARA.TAB: Independent assessments of government management of forests in both the United States and Australia have resulted in the conclusion that the resources are underpriced and, therefore, that too much logging takes place. I refer to two recent examples from the United States. I quote from the Tasman Institute report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The International Paper Company's wildlife program in the south of the United States is a prime example of how a firm can benefit from using forest resources to non-wood services. The International Paper Company employs specialists to oversee wildlife and recreation on its lands, including some 16 000 acres in the Southlands Experiment Forest located near Bainbridge, Georgia. There, research is carried out to develop forest management practices that enhance wildlife population as well as profits. White-tailed deer, turkeys, rabbits, bobwhite quail, mourning doves and other species are beginning to reap the benefits of new management techniques. Habitat is improved by controlling burning, buffer zones along streams and tree cutting practices that leave wild cover and plenty of forage.
The report also cites another very good American example. It states:
A non profit organisation formed by 20 landowners, North Maine Woods Inc., manages recreation on 2.8 million acres. . .
To put that into an Australia context, it is an area approximately half the size of Tasmania or, even closer to home, 10 times the size of the Australian Capital Territory. It continues:

The organisation was initiated by the land owners when they began to experience problems from recreational use. These problems included soil erosion and safety on private roads, overcrowding and overuse of camping areas, littering and the ever-present problem of forest fires.
These are things which are all quite relevant to Australian forests. The report continued:

PARA.TAB: North Maine Woods Inc. controls access to the area through 17 checkpoints and access roads, where visitors were required to register, pay fees for different types of use, and obtain permits for campsites. In 1984, the fees ranged from $2 per day to $17 for an all season permit and were used by the association to construct and improve campsites, run a rubbish collection system and run public education programmes on use of the woods. Though the initial efforts were restricted by those who were accustomed to free, unrestricted access, the less crowded, clean, well organised system of recreation management is promoting cooperation between landowners and recreationalists.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another quite beautiful example of the use of free market forces in trying to protect very valuable forest resources.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the Amazon Basin. This was referred to in an issue of Fortune magazine last year in an article entitled `Using Market Forces to Save Nature'. The article describes the efforts of Mr Jason Clay from a group called Cultural Survival Enterprises, based in Massachusetts. It was designed to help natives in the Amazon Basin form into cooperatives to harvest and sell rainforest products. The aim is to make the forest more valuable alive than dead. It shows every sign of success with orders worth millions of dollars for products such as the rainforest crunch peanut brittle, resins, oil pigments and brazil nuts.

I think all of these examples, including the example as close to home as Dr Walmsley's project in South Australia, show that there is a real alternative to government ownership and control of forest resources. The alternative to the very centralised process we have at the moment is to encourage private ownership, to move towards—on a trial basis—the privatisation of natural eucalypt forests and the contracting out of management of national parks. We need to have property rights; the resource should be owned by the people who want to use them. Groups such as the Australian Conservation Foundation could, instead of chopping down trees and spending millions of dollars on propaganda to push its preservationist anti-development views, actually spend that money buying tracts of natural forest and managing them for the conservation of the values that I have referred to previously.
I conclude by quoting Professor Richard B. Stewart, a Harvard law professor, who said in 1988:

SPEECH.PARA: Our current environment regulatory system was an understandable response to a perceived need for immediate controls to prevent a pollution crisis. But the system has gone to the point where it amounts to nothing less than a massive effort at Soviet-style

central planning of the economy to achieve environmental goals. It strangles investment and innovation. It encourages costly and divisive litigation and delay. It unduly limits private initiative and choice. The centralised command system is simply unacceptable as a long term environmental protection strategy for a large and diverse nation committed to the market and decentralised ordering.

I put it to the Senate that this legislation is a classic example of a government imposing a centralised, bureaucratic system to solve a problem that really should be handed back in the States, back in the local communities, back in the forests, forest by forest, project by project. The amendments that the Opposition has moved in the Senate today make what is a terrible piece of legislation, a disastrous piece of legislation, into something slightly more acceptable. I commend the Opposition's amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —About time we had a good speech.

—If brevity is quality, we will have quality. To me, it is a tragedy that the Forest Conservation and Development Bill is being debated. It is tragic that this legislation is in the Parliament. It is a reflection of the level of corruption of this Government in the mind of the corporate sector.

PARA.TAB: The reason we have the legislation is that business will no longer take the word of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). No longer will business believe a resolution of Cabinet; no longer will business accept the administrative decision or determination made by a Cabinet Minister. It will proceed henceforth only if the commitment is enshrined in legislation.

This legislation comes from a litany of lies, a litany of broken promises and failed commitments. This Government has, for instance, used the Register of the National Estate as an instrument of capitulation, an instrument of compromise, and a crude instrument of wheeling and dealing and deal fixing.

We need not look past Coronation Hill to find a classic example of the kind of commitment given by the Government. The then Prime Minister of this country made a commitment in writing to the Chairman of the Board of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd that mining would be allowed to proceed on Coronation Hill. There was a time, cute as it might have been, when the written word of a Prime Minister meant something. I take it that it meant something to Arvi Parbo, because BHP Gold Mines invested something in the order of $15m—a sheer bagatelle to this Government—of shareholders' money to explore, investigate, and examine the resource potential of the Coronation Hill area. Then it had a very extensive, very sophisticated environmental impact statement prepared which ran into hundreds of pages. It actually believed that the decision as to whether or not the mine would proceed would be based on the integrity and the resolution of that document.

When the Government was confronted with it, it was forced to concede that on environmental grounds the project was entitled, within the guidelines and within the legislation, to proceed. It then had to find another way of putting it off the agenda. We all remember the hour and a half that Phillip Toyne spent on the telephone, tortuous as it might have been for him, with the then Prime Minister, Bob Hawke. We all remember, of course, that Arvi Parbo could not even get through to him. That shows the relevant political clout in this country, much as it might have waned since that time. When the Government was confronted with the crude, brutal, political tactics of the conservation movement headed by Toyne—

TALK.START.PARA: —Phillip Toyne, that is.

—Phillip Toyne, the man whose reputation was built more on being anti-development than pro-environment. When the Government was confronted with threats, pathetic as they were, that preferences would not necessarily go to the ALP, Bob Hawke the atheist—not agnostic; I think he is an atheist—decided that there was something intrinsically principled about the spiritual beliefs of a minority of the Jawoyn community. Notwithstanding that the overwhelming majority of the Jawoyn community, all bar one of the leaders of the Jawoyn community—
—That is not true.
—They have told me personally that they supported mining on Coronation Hill. But once the ratbag element got amongst them and terrorised, intimidated and frightened them—

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: is it in order for Senator Crichton-Browne to refer to people such as Mr Phillip Toyne, whom he has just been talking about, as a ratbag element? I do not think that is in order at all and he should be asked to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—I do not understand, Senator Bolkus, how that can be taken as unparliamentary. It does not refer to a present or former member of parliament or a member of a parliament other than this one. I think there is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that we protect members of parliament but not individuals outside?

—I am simply telling you, Senator Bolkus, that according to the Standing Orders I do not regard it as unparliamentary. If you think I am wrong, you can move to dissent from my ruling; if you think the Standing Orders should be changed in that respect, you could refer the matter to the Standing Committee on Procedure. I remind you that there are suitable procedures available to persons who feel that they have been wronged by remarks made in this place; they can take up those procedures on their own behalf if they wish to.

—It is not without significance to note that Senator Bolkus has now elevated Mr Toyne to the same category as the Governor-General, a member of the Federal or State parliaments, or a member of the judiciary. Perhaps that says something about the perception of who pulls the levers in this country. The bottom line is that when Toyne picked up his telephone, Bob would click his heels.
—And tug the forelock.

—Yes, and tug the forelock. As a result of that, the Coronation Hill project did not proceed. Coronation Hill in itself is worth perhaps $500m to Australia. The amount is not important. The fact is that it sent a signal to the international bankers and to the major resource developers of Australia that this Government could no longer be believed.

PARA.TAB: We see this legislation also as the manifestation of a broken promise in respect of the Wesley Vale pulp consortium. It has spent millions of dollars on the project. I think it has spent $8m thus far. Perhaps it might be said that the joint venturers are slow learners, but so far they have invested $8m in the project only to find that the goal posts continue to be changed.

When it sunk into this Government that the frivolous and capricious variations and determinations and the irresponsible changing of the rules irrespective of the economic cost to the community would discourage investors, the Mr Alan Griffithses of this world resolved that something had to be done to convince the developers that this Government actually wanted development. So we got this legislation.

It is no secret to anybody that the ACF has pressed, particularly in Tasmania, for more areas of native forests to be included in the national parks. It wants, of course, all logging of natural forests to be phased out.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's 27 per cent of Tasmania already.

—As Senator Sherry has said, it has 27 per cent already. It is the wish of those people that it be totally phased out. So the Australian people found themselves in a dilemma. They had a government that nobody trusted, a government that nobody believed and, frankly, a government that nobody wanted, on the one hand. On the other hand, they had an industry that was not prepared to invest in this country, invest Australian shareholders' money in this country, unless it could see black and white legislation. Never again will they have a Prime Minister lie to them.

PARA.TAB: As the machinations went on and the Left and the Right struggled in Cabinet, we saw Mrs Ros Kelly representing the conservation movement. Her job was to keep its vote. It was not a question of what was right and what was wrong; she was simply to keep that vote marshalled. She wanted a memorandum of understanding and Mr Alan Griffiths wanted legislation. Why the dichotomy?

Legislation requires an amendment to be passed through both Houses of the Parliament. A memorandum of understanding, simply at the whim of the Minister, can be changed, altered or broken. What Mrs Ros Kelly wanted was a continuing right to change the rules. Every time she got political pressure, she wanted to be able to say, `I'll go to Cabinet. I am going to fight for you and the rules are going to be changed'.

Mr Griffiths had enough brains to realise that on that basis there would be no future investment. It is interesting that Mr Hawke said that legislation did not need to be in place for a process to be followed whereby a State government which had come to an arrangement with respect to a proposal to establish a pulp mill could come to the Federal Government in respect of its requirements. He was quite right. Legislation is not needed, except with this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 and it is not without significance to note that the list of speakers has extended to approximately 27 senators.
—You are the first, are you?
—By aberration, I am in the first third.
—And you are all repeating yourselves, too.
—The Labor Party finds some sin in repeating the truth. The members of the Labor Party have difficulty because they continue to repeat untruths; it is an unsound principle.
