PARA.TAB: Prior to the dinner recess I said that it was not without significance to note the difference in the approach to this legislation between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly). On the one hand two of them saw the intrinsic merit in the legislation because they understood that businesses, companies and corporations would not continue to invest in Tasmania until black and white legislation was in place. Mrs Ros Kelly is carrying a brief for the conservation movement, and I do not mean `conservation movement' in the general sense of the word. I am referring to the extreme radical group which is anti-development and not pro-conservation. Members of that group did not want the legislation because they understand that legislation requires amendment by both Houses of the Parliament. However, a notional proclamation from a Minister without legislation is a much easier way of doing business.

One might well ask why it is that this legislation is necessary for the forest industry but it is not necessary for other industries. I ask: why is it not necessary for any other resource industry? I take it that the reason is that this debate has really reached the pinnacle of extremities, if honourable senators will forgive my indulgence in language. It is because the most extreme and hypocritical people are the ones who raise their angry voices—for reasons known only to themselves and not others—when it comes to dealing with forest resources.

It does not matter if other parts of the environment are despoiled and whether uranium, beach sands, coal, phosphate or iron ore are being mined. National legislation is not needed, but the timber industry has a special place. All that highlights is that this is not an economic or social debate; it is a political debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Politics in this place!

—This debate has been brought on because the Labor Government has been compromised at every step by the more radical sections of the conservation movement. If this were not true, this legislation would apply to every resource Act, but, of course, it does not. For example, special and unique federal legislation has never been required in respect of the iron ore industry. Iron ore is found in areas of intrinsic and natural beauty in Australia which compare with parts of Tasmania.
—Where do you find gold—in a shotgun?
—What the interjector is saying is not clear.
—It may be a good idea if the honourable senator ignores the interjections.
—I will take the advice of the Deputy President and ignore them. If he is making judgments of that value, I am inclined to take the same view.

PARA.TAB: The industry wants nothing more than clear and unequivocal guidelines about environmental constraints. Industry does not want to ignore the environment or put it aside. It wants clear, unequivocal, rigid, solid, fixed guidelines as to what is expected of it in terms of the environment. However, that is something that clearly this Government has been unable to provide thus far.

I conclude by unequivocally supporting the amendments. To the extent that legislation is necessary to bolster and buttress the integrity of this Government, I support the amendments moved by the Opposition and I particularly commend the integrity and fortitude of my colleagues from Tasmania and the contributions made by them. I ask: why is there a $100m criterion in respect to the trigger mechanism for this legislation? It is almost as if this Government—like every other spectrum of its political judgment—believes that big is beautiful. I understand one major sawmill operator exports something like $5m per year in non-value-added sawn timber products. The industry ought not be responsible merely for import replacement, but should create export earnings and a significant part of the industry will be denied that. While I do not suggest for a moment that exported value-added products contribute in any way to the non-value added exports, in terms of volume they have the capacity to be worth 10 times the amount.

Yet we again find how this Government—always a government of compromise, always a government of shoddy deals, always a government trying to find consensus where there is none—has found itself with legislation which it desperately hoped would satisfy both the extremes in its own political party and its supporters, while at the same time seeking to satisfy and reassure business in this country. Of course it has dismally failed.

My understanding is that the overwhelming majority of the industry is totally and absolutely opposed to this legislation in its present form. The sadness for me is that it is a repetition of that which we have seen so often in other projects around Australia. Without going through a long list, I look at the projects in Western Australia which have been held up on environmentally related grounds. The problem is not with satisfying environmental demands but simply with finding out what those environmental demands are. This is true of mineral sands, uranium, gold, nickel and the whole spectrum of resource development in Australia.

In many respects this legislation is a watershed. It is necessary because the Government is not to be trusted. I suspect that, as time goes on, fewer and fewer industries will be prepared to invest in Australia until such time as they are given black and white legislation.I trust that the amendments proposed will be carried and that in the event that they are not, this legislation will go off to a committee. I believe that the Government will oppose that because it will again find itself subject to a spotlight which will demonstrate the hypocrisy and dishonesty of its purposes and intentions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on the Forest Conservation Development Bill 1991. As a Tasmanian senator I feel particularly obliged to put my position on the record briefly, for there has been such a major campaign in my home State on the issue of resource security.
—Ha, ha!
—I am interested that Senator Aulich laughs because, as he does not visit Tasmania very often, perhaps he does not know about it.
—He has paid a price for that.

—Yes, he has paid a price for it. His own Party is not interested in listening to him too strongly. But some people in Tasmania have publicly called on Liberal senators to support this legislation and have tried to suggest that we are welshing on our State if we do not allow this Bill to go through in its current form. Most honourable senators here tonight would recognise that the responsibilities of senators are heavy and often onerous; and my colleagues and I do not undertake them lightly.
—It really worries you, doesn't it, Senator.

—There are a number of requirements made of senators, one of which is to represent their States to the best of their abilities. Another very important job of any senator elected to this place is to scrutinise legislation thoroughly as befits members of a House of review.

PARA.TAB: Tasmania needs jobs and needs them desperately, particularly because of the Labor bequest from both the Federal and State governments in terms of drastically bad unemployment, particularly of our young. APPM may provide jobs in a pulp mill, but it has not yet given any assurance that it will actually do so and, of course, not when it will do so.

The Opposition and the rest of the industry are seriously concerned about this Bill for reasons which have already been spelt out in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. Because of time constraints, I do not intend to repeat them. The Opposition has been trying to negotiate with the Government on this matter for several months. There has been no action from the Government. In the light of Mr Keating's previous opposition to resource security, we suspect that the Government wants this legislation to fail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you opposing it?

—The Government wants it to fail, but to appear as though it is the fault of the Opposition. I note that, despite the interjections which come in a cackling fashion from Senator Aulich opposite, who does not have the guts to get up and talk about this Bill, only one Tasmanian Labor senator is scheduled on the list to support it tonight, and that is Senator Sherry.
—I'll be speaking later.
—Order on my right!
—I suppose that we cannot count Senator Aulich as a Tasmanian senator any more.
—I live on one pension. How many times have you dipped into the public trough?
—We would be interested to know whether Senator Devereux or Senator Coates are truly supporting this legislation.
—Senator Aulich, it is Thursday night. Come on!

—I suggest that perhaps Senator Aulich is in an emotional condition, but I would not like to be too certain about it; I am not close enough. The situation is that our suspicions about the Government's ulterior purpose in this were confirmed during the debate in the House of Representatives on 2 March.
—Tell us why you are opposing it.
—Senator Aulich, you indicated that you are going to speak later tonight. I think you should leave your speech until then.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. My colleague Mr Miles on 2 March in the House of Representatives was debating this legislation when the honourable member for Denison, Mr Kerr, probably in a similar condition to Senator Aulich, interjected on Mr Miles. Mr Miles was saying that the only reason why the Government will not move an amendment is that it wants to try to leave us with what it thinks will be the odium of the next election—the northern pulp mill. The Hansard shows that Mr Kerr said, `You have got it'. Mr Miles then pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member admits it quite publicly. It is absolutely political. The Government is not interested in jobs. The honourable member for Denison has admitted that this legislation is in here tonight for purely political reasons.

Mr Ian McLachlan was also in the chamber at the time. He pointed out that it was said four times because there had been other interjections which had not been recorded by Hansard. For very clear reasons we are concerned that the Government is playing on a political agenda. We do not feel that that is any reason for this legislation, important as it is, to be treated in the manner in which it is by the Government.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy President, I draw your attention to the fact that the industry body wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 16 October last year asking then for this legislation to be withdrawn. Since then, the industry and the Opposition have proposed amendments over and over again, without success. Even APPM has acknowledged that it is flawed legislation, but it pushes for the passing of the Bill on the basis that it could be fixed up afterwards. That is not necessarily so and it is certainly no justification for passing faulty legislation.

I remind you, Mr Deputy President, that we have seen other industries come a cropper on unacceptable legislation. We only have to remember the wool industry's recent pleadings for changes to its legislation, and what sort of a mess that industry would have been in if it had got the legislation it was prepared to accept in the first place. It makes one realise that people who grasp at straws are likely to find that the straws are useless as crutches. Even APPM's head company, North Broken Hill Peko Pty Ltd, was a signatory to a letter to the Prime Minister just last month urging a widening of the eligibility of the legislation to include a regional approach. So this legislation should not pass in this form.

The National Association of Forest Industries has long pressed the Government to amend the Bill, without success. It is not alone. The major industries and the industry bodies share its concern. I will put on record what some of them have been saying about this legislation.NAFI has said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . restricting the legislation to $100 million projects effectively leaves most of the industry out in the cold.
"NAFI has a long held policy that it can not support the legislation in its current form and this policy will be maintained.

"The tragedy will be, if the Government rejects the amendments, a crisis of confidence in forest industries and other resource industries, leading to the loss of billions of dollars of investment and thousands of jobs—
The Forest Industries Federation of Western Australia wrote a letter to the Premier saying:
. . . without the amendments, the legislation does not offer long term security or the confidence for industry to invest in projects throughout the south-west—
of Western Australia. The Forest Protection Society Ltd said:
"This legislation needs to be passed by the Senate but only after it has been amended to encompass State\Regional Timber Strategies rather than just individual projects.
The Australian Forest Growers said:

"The surest way to encourage farmers to grow trees is to make them a commercial proposition, but without workable resource security for the industry today, who's going to be left to buy plantation product in 20 years' time?
"If the Government is really serious about wood plantations, it must accept the amendments which have been presented to it by the industry.
The New South Wales Forest Products Association Ltd says:
The absence of provisions for compensation makes the legislation unworkable to secure investment and employment.
The Australian Logging Council says:

Given the highly significant role of small business in the maintenance of Australian living standards, it is clearly inappropriate to pass legislation that can only be utilised by one or two Corporate players.
Passage of this legislation, incorporating the NAFI amendments, will protect working class Australians and at the same time provide a real boost to our economy.
The Pulp and Paper Manufacturers Federation of Australia, which is the peak body for the pulp and paper manufacturers, says:

It might appear strange that the organisation which represents the major pulp and paper companies supports amendments for regional resource security supporting smaller sawmill investment, however, there is both a principle and a practicality at stake here . . .

The principle is that providing adequate conservation is delivered by the legislation, and this is one of its major purposes, then all investments in value added industry whether it be for sawmills or pulpmills should be encouraged by resource security . . . Lack of such security is already causing industry to invest in countries other than Australia.

The practicality involved here is that many large investments could and should be taken by the pulp and paper industry which involve investments less than the $100 million which is the cut-off in the proposed legislation. These investments will also be in jeopardy if the amendments to the Bill are not passed.
The Australian Paper Manufacturers says:
The Federal Government could accept these amendments without a major change to the intention of the Bill.
We have asked Minister Griffiths to seek consultation with the Opposition so that effective amendments are considered.

That is a pretty long litany of requests for amendments from the industry throughout Australia, including Tasmania. The Government must either withdraw this legislation and replace it with a satisfactory Bill, or it should accept the amendments which the Opposition and the industry require. We propose to send this Bill to a legislative standing committee if the amendments are not passed in this chamber to give witnesses the opportunity to explain the deficiencies in the legislation. Perhaps then the Government will see sense. If it is not prepared to act in the interests of the entire forest industry, I will vote against this Bill, not because my Party requires it but because it is the only measure left to me to take in all conscience.

PARA.TAB: I am ready and willing to support resource security legislation, but not at any price. I do not accept this legislation in its present form. The onus is now on the Government. If the Federal Government really cares about jobs for Tasmanians and the establishment of a pulp mill in Tasmania, if it really is interested in resource security and the well being of the national forest industry, it will stop playing games and govern in the national interest. Otherwise, it must stand condemned by the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, this is going to be a fairly difficult debate. It will be a difficult matter for the Forest Conservation and Development Bill to be passed through the Senate and there is some doubt as to whether it will. We in the coalition believe that these matters should be referred to a committee if the Government is unwilling to support the amendments that the National Association of Forest Industries has put forward.

PARA.TAB: I support wholeheartedly the coalition's position for one very simple reason: in Queensland we have paid the price of environmentalism gone mad. In Queensland, we have the wreck of a timber industry. This once great industry has been decimated by environmentalists locking up more and more and more of the forest, providing no security for investment, providing no security for jobs, and providing no security for industry.

When we have, as we have at the moment, $1.8 billion of timber coming from overseas into this country every year, it is absolutely crucial for the future of our economy that we are able to turn that around. We need to be able to generate positive investment in the timber industry so that there will be jobs in the future and so that we will be able to avoid this continuing syndrome of import decline. It is therefore important that resource security legislation provide not just for the large pulp millers, but also for the small sawmillers. Unless we have that, the heart of our timber industry will be taken away.

I would like to take the opportunity to mention some of the people who have sent me faxes. Most particularly, I want to read a fax which I received from the Forest Protection Society, Brisbane Valley, Lockyer Branch. It reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator O'Chee

I would like to take this final opportunity on behalf of the Brisbane-Lockyer Valley Branch of the Forest Protection Society to make an appeal for your support concerning the amendment to the proposed Forest Resource Security Legislation, which is being debated in the Senate today.

Our Branch covers the entire Brisbane Valley and Lockyer Valley and consists of many small towns which will cease to exist if the Resource Security is allowed to be passed without the proposed amendments, put forward by the Unions and the National Association of Forest Industries.
We feel we should not be discriminated against because we have no projects in our area that will be valued at $100 million.

All our members are unanimous in their belief, that the proposed amendment to the Resource Security Legislation will ensure their future employment and the continued growth of the timber industry within our areas.
Yours faithfully
Joanne Werner
Secretary

That is but one of a number of facsimile messages I have received. I have received facsimile messages from the National Association of Forest Industries, Foxwood Ltd in Cairns, Logform in Kilcoy, Rankin Bros in Malanda, Bellthorpe Box and Timber Company in Woodford, Wade Sawmill in Maryborough, Rankin Timber and Trusses in Stratford, Davidson Sawmills, Ford Timbers in Springwood—an area where they have logged for 60 years—and so the list goes on. It is very clear that the small timber operators, the small sawmillers, the people who provide the bulk of the employment in the small towns of regional Australia, are opposed to this Bill being passed without the amendments that NAFI supports and that we in the coalition support.

PARA.TAB: It is passing strange that the Government should oppose amendments to this Bill which are supported by the unions. What this is all about is providing jobs—providing jobs where there would otherwise be no jobs. In support of this proposition, I draw the Senate's attention to the impact assessment of the World Heritage listing which was conducted by the survey research and consultancy unit of the Department of Anthropology and Sociology at the University of Queensland. It looked into what happened when the timber industry was closed down in north Queensland; and it looked into what happened when the World Heritage listing went through. Its finding was very, very clear. Over 645 jobs were lost directly as a result of that World Heritage listing—645 jobs in areas where these people have no other source of employment, where they will have no alternative but to be condemned to a long term future on the dole.

Let us get one thing clear: these are not people who take life easy. These are the hard workers in our society. Timber workers are some of the hardest working people in this country. For them, the shame of unemployment is a stigma almost too difficult to bear. I do not believe that I can, in good conscience, as a representative of Queensland, as a representative of people in regional Queensland, come into this Senate and vote for this legislation unless these amendments are passed.

I spent a portion of last week in the Brisbane Valley. I spoke to the sawmillers. I visited a sawmill which employs 18 people and which has an investment of half a million dollars. That may not sound like much on the scale of $100m but it is important to that town. It is important to the families of the 18 people who work there. It is important to the transport operators, and it is important to the region. In spite of the fact that the sawmill is small, in spite of the fact that its capital investment is only half a million dollars, it is very profitable because it operates in a niche market, producing mouldings and specialised cuts of timber—hardwood and softwood.

The bottom line is this: if we do not have the resource security for those small sawmillers as well as the big operators, we run the very real risk that our softwood plantations, in which this nation has invested hundreds of millions of dollars, will never be harvested anyway because there will not be the mills to process the timber.

It is just not satisfactory that the timber industry be put in the hands of only a couple of big companies. That is not what micro-economic reform or economic efficiency is about. Nor is it what a competitive and efficient economy is about. As far as I am concerned, a competitive and efficient economy is about giving every single operator a fair go. What is missing in this country at the moment is a fair go for the small operator, a fair go for the timber worker, a fair go for the truckie who transports it and a fair go for the towns involved. As I said, I cannot in good conscience support this legislation without amendments. I stand behind the timber industry; I stand behind the people who have been affected.

So that the Senate can peruse the impact of the World Heritage listing of the forests in north Queensland, the lack of compensation and the lack of job security, I seek leave to table an impact assessment statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that the Senate will recognise the very real fears of the timber industry throughout Queensland and not support this legislation unless the amendments proposed by the coalition are also supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased, briefly, to join my colleagues in proposing amendments to improve and make sensible the Forest Conservation and Development Bill. We in the Liberal and National parties have proposed 17 amendments, drawn with the full support of the forestry industry and the unions, which make the following improvements to the legislation. They would extend the eligibility for resource security to projects accredited under State forestry plans; remove the $100m limit on resource security; ensure that consideration is given to the provision of alternative resources where the resource security is lost because of unforeseen circumstances; and remove the clauses exempting the Commonwealth from paying compensation where resource security is lost.

PARA.TAB: My colleagues have explained the Bill in very great detail and have put forward arguments which I only hope the Government will take notice of and will accept. I particularly congratulate Senator Tambling on the way he dealt with the Bill here, and Mr Lloyd and Mr Chaney who have done so much work on the Bill in the other place. I also congratulate my colleagues in the Senate from Tasmania who have spoken on this Bill so forcefully. I again contrast their involvement in this Bill with the involvement of honourable Labor senators from Tasmania. I understand that only Senator Sherry is listed to speak.

I do not often agree with Senator Sherry, but I agree with him when he refers to the Australian Democrats as moonbeams. That seems to be particularly apt in describing the Democrats' attitude to this Bill—moonbeams with little light and little substance. Of course, the Democrats' attitude to this sort of legislation and similar legislation is so ridiculous that it really should not involve anyone spending too much time on the way they approach these sorts of things, except to concur with Senator Sherry in that one aspect of his speech on this Bill.

In common with all other senators, I have had a wide range of submissions made to me by various people involved in this industry, encouraging parliamentarians from all sides to support the amendments that have been proposed by the Opposition. I want to address some of the submissions in support of the amendments that have come from the north Queensland area which I principally represent in this Parliament. I refer to submissions I have received from Rankine Bros Pty Ltd, which operates out of Malanda, Stratford, Kairi, Cairns, Yungaburra, Mossman, Kuranda and Cooktown. I have also received submissions from Rankine Timber and Trusses which operates from Stratford in Cairns, from Foxwood Ltd which operates in Ingham, Innisfail and Cairns, and from Tully Sawmills, which obviously operates out of Tully.

I have also had discussions with the operators of the Ravenshoe timber mill. That timber mill has had a sorry history in recent times due directly to the inefficiency and the stupidity of the decisions made by this Government some years ago, which caused such untold misery and hardship to people in communities in Ravenshoe and in other areas on the Atherton Tablelands.

These companies are all very concerned about the future of what is left of the timber industry in north Queensland. There is only very little of that industry left following this Government's stupidity in the way that it dealt with the World Heritage listing of the rainforests. The World Heritage listing locked up some 900,000 hectares of rainforest in north Queensland, all but decimating the local timber industry.

The few remaining companies use locally, privately owned rainforest and hardwood as well as pine plantations and some crown hardwoods. But they also rely very heavily on sawn timber from southern Queensland and northern New South Wales to supplement their operations in order to supply the north Queensland building industry. In the case of Rankine Bros, a small amount of timber is also imported from overseas.

If resource security is not granted to suppliers of their timber in south-east Queensland and northern New South Wales, then the north Queensland industry is under serious threat. Northern timber industry leaders are rightly annoyed that the Government is happy to provide resource security to a $100m operation in New South Wales or Tasmania, but that the small operators in north Queensland are left in the cold without any guarantee whatsoever. Investment in the timber industry is a huge risk unless some guarantees are provided.

In 1989-90 we imported some $463m worth of sawn timber from overseas. Without resource security for timber suppliers in southern Queensland and northern New South Wales, there will need to be an increase in our sawn timber imports to supply the north Queensland area. Accordingly, the building industry in north Queensland will face higher charges.

Time is at a premium in this debate, but I want briefly to mention some of the things that were said in the submissions that have been made to me. Rankine Timber and Trusses from Stratford said, in part, in its letter:

SPEECH.PARA: We need sensible legislation that cares for ordinary people and their well-being not political solutions catering to the demands of multinationals or altruistic zealots.

I am pleased to see my Queensland colleague from the ALP in the chamber, and just wish that he would take some notice of what was said. I have a copy of a letter which Tully Sawmills wrote to all Queensland Labor senators—Senator Burns, Senator Colston, Senator Jones and Senator Reynolds. In part, this letter said:

I write on behalf of my family, my 25 employees and their families to express our disbelief and our disgust that your Government by way of this legislation proposes to grant resource security to pulp and paper mills but not to sawmills which are huge employers of labour and very important sectors of many communities.
Further in the letter they say:

We stress that without resource security it is impossible for our industry to undertake investment or maintain and expand employment. In fact it would mean the eventual closure of hundreds of sawmills and the loss of tens of thousands of jobs. Should that occur, I would suggest that all those who are directly and indirectly dependent on our industry would never be able to forgive your Government or your party.
That is a copy of a letter that was sent to me, and I guess to other honourable senators in Queensland, but it was addressed to the Labor Party senators.

PARA.TAB: I inquire of Senator Burns, Senator Colston, Senator Jones and Senator Reynolds what they are going to do about it. Will Senator Jones take any notice of that at all? Does he intend to do something for these small business people involved in the timber industry in his State? Senator Jones is shaking his head. He is not going to do anything. Those honourable senators do not give a damn about them. They care about the big multinationals, about the people with $100m or more, but they just do not care about the little people. I doubt that Senator Jones gets up that way very often.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think you might ask Senator Macdonald to direct his remarks through the Chair rather than at individual senators.
—I will do that.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—I would be grateful if you would do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very powerful point of order.

—Senator Short is quite right. Madam Acting Deputy President, we always knows when we are succeeding and when the Government is sensitive, because Senator Ray always gets up with his ridiculous, teacher-like points of order. One would expect something better from a Minister of the Crown. He still thinks that he is in the classroom where he is dealing with little boys. Senator Ray should just calm down. I should thank him for that point of order. We always know when we are getting close to the point because that is when Senator Ray gets up with his schoolteacher image and his cane and baton and tries to tell us how we should act.
—We are all fallible, Senator Macdonald.

—Yes, we are all fallible and Senator Ray probably more than most. Through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, may I ask the Queensland senators what they are going to do about it? I think Senator Jones kindly indicated by a shake of his head that they were not going to do anything about it. The Government just looks after the big people.
—Stop lying!

—Senator Ray is sensitive about not looking after the little people. I can understand that. The Government has put a million little people out of work. It just does not care about the little people at all. The Government looks after its big mates. It looks after the Bonds, the Holmes a Courts, the Connells; it looks after Kirner and the Victorian Government; but it just does not give a damn about the little people. It has put a million of them on the unemployment scrap heap and it does not care. As long as Senator Ray and his leader—whom I do not think he supported, but he has him now—can retain the trappings of office, that is all they are interested in. I can tell that when Senator Ray gets so sensitive when these facts are rammed home to him.

PARA.TAB: As I was saying, there is a plea from Tully Sawmills. I do not know whether any of the Queensland senators even know where Tully is, but there is a plea from one of their constituents. I just hope that in the course of this debate they will realise that those people in Tully Sawmills have some real concern with the legislation as it now stands. They plead to this Government and their Queensland representatives for some support and assistance in this.
Out of north Queensland in the rest of Queensland, the Queensland Forest Protection Society said some things that I think should be recorded. In part, it said in its submission to me:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't believe the towns and cities which rely on the jobs and revenue created by the 1400 sawmills across Australia are any less worthy of consideration than the big ticket investment item proposed to be given resource security under the existing legislation.

The financial and social security of hundreds of towns will be destroyed if Resource Security legislation currently proposed by the Federal Government is not amended to incorporate accredited regional forest plans.
Further in the submission it says:

The Bill before Parliament gives the Federal Government an ideal opportunity to finally resolve the forest debate through proper scientific processes and not the shonky deals which were the hallmarks of business and politics during the 1980's.
I add that the shonky deals were hallmarks of this Government as well. Further, the Caboolture branch of the Forest Protection Society said:

We will be watching with great interest and waiting while the politicians decide the future of 80,000 forest industry jobs and the many hundreds of communities who rely on this industry for their security.
We will also be remembering these same politicians when it is our turn to decide on someone's job and future—their's, at the next election.

I might raise that query with the Federal Labor members in north Queensland—Mr Lindsay, Mr Hulls and Mr Gayler—and ask them what they are going to do to protect the jobs of the timber mill workers in their area. In a submission made by another branch of the Forest Protection Society, it was said:
Uniform resource security legislation developed on a regional basis is what the industry and the economy needs, not just one or two major capital projects.
The Woodford branch of the Forest Protection Society, already quoted by Senator O'Chee, says:
If these amendments are introduced and passed,—
that is the amendments proposed by the Liberal and National parties—
we believe it will not only provide job security for thousands of workers and the many communities they come from but also encourage companies to start reinvesting in the Forest Industries.
The Forest Protection Society in Wide Bay states:
We should not be discriminated against simply because we do not have the magical investment figure as proposed by the current legislation.
The Brisbane Valley Lockyer branch of the Forest Protection Society said:

Our Branch covers the entire Brisbane Valley and Lockyer Valley and consists of many small towns which will cease to exist, if the Resource Security is allowed to be passed without the proposed amendments, put forward by the Unions and the National Association of Forest Industries.
Ford Timbers in a submission said, amongst other things:
. . . the proposed legislation, which is being debated today in the Senate, limits the application of Resource Security to projects worth $100 million or more.
This eliminates virtually all of the smaller sawmillers throughout Australia and offers them no protection at all.
Later it says:

Ford Timbers and its associated companies employ 120 people and have more than $13 million invested in sawmills at Woodenbong, Drake and Urbenville in northern New South Wales and a timber yard in Brisbane.

Ford Timbers has been operating now for almost 60 years and we have contributed a lot to the local economy. We want to see our future, and the future of our employees, protected by legislation which has been properly thought out.
Further in that submission, it states:
. . . the proposed legislation in its current form would offer no long term security to the timber industry generally and had to be amended if industry security was to be guaranteed.
Finally, I quote from a little submission from a little mill, Davidson Sawmill at North Arm. It states:
Without this security we cannot possibly undertake this, maintain or expand employment or continue support of our community or have in place a fully sustainable industry.
They are just a few quotations from a few of the submissions that I have received from people in the Queensland area who are very concerned about this legislation as it now stands.

PARA.TAB: I urge my colleagues, the Queensland senators from the Labor Party, to do some work on their Government to get it to accept these amendments which will look after the small people. I leave the Senate and my colleagues in Queensland with that plea.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 is supported by some sections of the timber industry; it is not supported by others, who believe it should have gone further than it has in the direction of providing resource security. On balance, I think it is fair to claim that this legislation has the support of the industry, if only for the reason that the industry believes it is better to have this legislation than to have nothing.

PARA.TAB: My own view is that the system which has been adopted by the State Government of Western Australia under which specified, identified areas of land are reserved for timber production and other areas of land or forest are excluded from timber production—leaving aside whatever reservations one might have about the proportions of those two decisions about forest use—is a better strategy to adopt than the one adopted by this Bill. Under such a strategy, particular parts of Australia would be geographically identified and designated as areas either available or not available for timber production.

Such an approach, of course, is stridently opposed by the Greenies because the Greenies are not interested in a compromise. The Green extremists want to close down the Australian timber industry. Nothing short of that objective will satisfy them. They are, therefore, completely opposed to any land or resource use legislation or measures which allow any identified part of the Australian continent to be used for economic purposes. They want to close down the lot.

This leads me to some of the fears I have about the specific clauses of this Bill. I will not read them at great length, but I refer to clause 16(3) and the consequential relevant references in 17(2), 17(5) and 17(6). These provide the opportunity, at least, for objection to be taken as to land which has been designated to be available for timber production, on the grounds that information not known at the time the designated Ministers made their decision has come to light and, therefore, the decision should be changed.

I believe there is a real danger that those clauses will be exploited in a way that the Government does not intend by Green extremists. Green extremists will follow loggers around every part of Australia, and every time those loggers want to do a bit of logging and cut down a few trees the Green extremists will claim that they have discovered some endangered species, or site of special cultural or anthropological importance, which can only be dealt with by taking the area out of timber production. I believe that is a real danger. I will be happy to be proved wrong, but I fear I will be proved right.

We have to realise that when dealing with Green extremists, we are not dealing with the sort of people who normally sit in the Federal Parliament or comprise the great majority of the membership of any of our organisations or institutions. We are dealing with fanatics. Even fanatics are entitled to some respect, I believe, if their views are held consistently, but consistency is conspicuously absent from the views and behaviour of our Green fanatics.

I will cite one example. The Green fanatic asserts that living standards and levels of consumption must be reduced. For example, we had Senator Chamarette in here yesterday saying that we do not need the mining industry because it gobbles up all the capital and does not provide many jobs. That, of course, expresses the views which are held by Green fanatics. They do not want the mining industry. They want to close down the mining industry, they want to close down the timber industry and, ultimately, they want to close down agriculture as well—at least, commercial agriculture as we know it.

The base of their claimed belief system is that real incomes and standards of living must fall. But what do they do in practice? For a start, their own propaganda organisations such as the Australian Conservation Foundation would much rather sponge on the taxpayers for funding than solicit donations from their claimed myriad supporters who, if they genuinely subscribed to this doctrine, ought to be quite happy to take the opportunity to get rid of some of their disposable income voluntarily and thereby reduce their individual standards of living. They do not do that. They sponge on the taxpayers and they want to continue sponging on the taxpayers.

The Green party in Tasmania put up 35 candidates in the recent State election, 34 per cent of whom were teachers—a very disproportionate number of teachers. If support for the Greens is as strong within the teaching profession as those figures imply, there ought to be some countervailing faction or influence within the teachers' unions not to obtain increasing levels of salaries and wages—as all teachers' unions, in common with most other groups, do—but to take lower wages, so that living standards can be reduced in accordance with the Green doctrine to which they profess to adhere.

What is even more directly relevant to the Senate is: how does Senator Chamarette, who is of course opposed to this legislation, believe that governments can afford to fund the sort of fiscal scam being perpetrated by her predecessor in the Senate, Senator Vallentine? Instead of the $85,000 lump sum payment to which she is entitled under the provisions of the legislation, former Senator Vallentine is attempting to obtain a lump sum payment of $165,000 plus a $16,500 pension indexed for life. How does Senator Chamarette believe that governments can afford to fund that sort of fiscal scam being attempted by her predecessor? If they followed her views, and the views of Green extremists in general, governments would be simultaneously closing down the industries that paid the taxes, to fund far more worthy areas of government expenditure than the fiscal scam which former Senator Vallentine is perpetrating.

Former Senator Vallentine has claimed that one of the reasons why she retired from the Senate was that it was `in accordance with the Green principle of rotating jobs'. I do not have any particular objection to the Green principle of rotating jobs. In former Senator Vallentine's case, she decided to rotate the job a bit more than six years after she got it. But she does not just want to rotate the job; she wants to pick up, instead of the $85,000 to which she is entitled under the legislation, a $165,000 lump sum plus an indexed pension of $16,500 a year.

I invite Senator Chamarette, who unfortunately is not here, at the earliest possible opportunity to make a personal explanation to the Senate about whether she, too, supports the `Green principle of rotating jobs' embraced by former Senator Vallentine. If so—assuming she survives that long—does she, six or six and a half years hence, intend to resign from the Senate and emulate the example of her predecessor and attempt to pick up, not the $85,000 in present value dollars to which she would explicitly be entitled under the relevant legislation, but $165,000 plus $16,500 for life? I invite Senator Chamarette to take the opportunity to make a personal explanation, either later tonight or tomorrow, as to whether she accepts that Green principle and, if she does, whether she intends to follow former Senator Vallentine's example and repeat the same fiscal scam which she is attempting to run right now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, the Senate has before it legislation which attempts to please too many people and, in the process, fails to achieve its objective of resource security, particularly for the sawmillers and loggers on the north and south coasts of New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at what the Forest Conservation and Development Bill was meant to achieve. Firstly, the Bill is meant to provide for the identification of forest areas of significant cultural, environmental and heritage value, and to provide for the protection and conservation of those areas. Secondly, it is meant to facilitate investment in enterprises in major wood processing projects for the production of value added products for export, import replacement or both. These are definitely sound objectives. It is unfortunate that the Bill is far from satisfactory in achieving them.

The Labor Government, with this piece of legislation, has failed to address the real issues of the Australian timber industry. That industry urgently requires true resource security legislation that has been properly thought out—security that will provide for investment, security that will provide jobs and security that will provide a future for many people all over Australia who are tied to the timber industry. This Bill does not provide that security. It does allow an undefined or, should I say, an unlimited level of intervention by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy; it applies only to projects to a minimum value of $100m; and it results in bureaucratic duplication, regulation and red tape. Most importantly, however, it provides absolutely no security whatsoever for small businesses in the industry.

This very important part of the industry has been totally ignored by this legislation. What is the point of introducing resource security if a government is not going to provide it to the people who need it most? My office has received complaints from all areas of New South Wales about the Bill before the Senate tonight, asking for the right legislation to be introduced.

The Labor Government has failed to see that its lack of proper resource security is adversely affecting the families that are involved in these industries. This is obvious from recent correspondence. From the Bombala Timber Support Group in the south-east of New South Wales comes this comment on the legislation:

SPEECH.PARA: If implemented in its present form, it would mean the end of our hardwood mills `Tablelands Bombala' and `Plateau Nimmitabel'. It is vitally important for future investment that resource security be granted but please take into consideration existing small timber companies.

All honourable senators would have seen the correspondence from Slater Contracting Company of Eden urging us to support the proposed amendments to the legislation so that it can once again employ trainees, expand staff and replace its ageing equipment, which will give a much needed boost to my former home town of Eden and will help get the economy going down there again.

PARA.TAB: Another example is Ford Timbers, an employer of 120 people in northern New South Wales with $13m invested in various sawmills. The Managing Director of that company has stated that, unless the legislation caters for all players in the industry, the legislation is virtually worthless. The legislation in its current form will offer no long term security for the timber industry generally and it has to be amended if industry security is to be guaranteed.

The Government fails to realise that these people are making a very significant contribution to the Australian economy, but that that contribution is in jeopardy due to the irresponsibility of this Labor Government. Of course, resource security legislation would simply not be necessary if it had not been for the past interference of the Federal Government that has destroyed confidence in the forest products industry.

The lives of the people in the timber industry have been adversely affected by the past action of Labor and, because of the inadequacies of the current legislation, they must continue to live under the spectre of future government interference. This means that the capital necessary for industry to continue, let alone expand, will simply not be forthcoming. People will simply not invest. Banks will not lend when they cannot be assured that the Federal Government will not just come in on the side of any pressure group and restrict projects so much that they are no longer viable.

The people in the timber industry should not have to put up with such insecurity. It is an industry that directly employs thousands of people, and an even greater number indirectly. Many service towns depend on it. These people contribute to one of the biggest export industries in Australia. No-one would disagree that Australia needs more value-added exports, and that is what these industries can supply. So why is the Government refusing to recognise their importance?

There is a great outcry from the forest products industry. Any resource security legislation needs to include all players. It needs to include the established industry and the small participants, not just new projects worth $100m. For this reason alone, the legislation has failed. But there are other problems that the legislation has also overlooked.

The Government has declared that it will not intervene in a project once it has been given the go-ahead under this legislation. The Government claims that these projects will have resource security. However, with this Bill the Minister reserves the right to act on a major and unforeseen environmental or cultural impact not identified at the time of initial access. This exceptionally broad provision gives the Minister enormous scope as there is no definition of what comprises an unforseen event. How can investors possibly feel that they have resource security when they do not know on what basis, or when, the Government can intervene in their particular project? This loophole in the Bill makes a farce of the whole purpose of resource security.

Yet another problem with the Bill is that it provides the opportunity for total duplication of assessment and processes. The Bill is so broadly worded that it permits the uncooperative overlapping of procedures. It does this because it requires assessment by the Commonwealth Government not only of environmental factors but also of social, cultural and economic factors. It is therefore duplicating, once again, State processes.

Yet again, industry is stifled and inhibited by bureaucratic processes. Layer upon layer of regulations already bog down what projects are able to get under way. These delays are costly and often fatal to projects. The forestry industry does not need this further interference by the Government. These areas can be dealt with without the Federal Government unnecessarily creating more red tape.

The Bill also specifically excludes any compensation by the Commonwealth in the case of the loss of secured resources. This is totally unacceptable and yet another problem with this very poor piece of legislation.

All these aspects considered, it can be seen that the Bill is a hopeless compromise that tries to please everyone but in fact dismally fails to please anyone. The forestry industry is begging the Government to amend the legislation, to make it viable and to provide some real resource security.

The Forest Protection Society of New South Wales has urged the Government to accept the amendments because if it does not the New South Wales industry will be left out in the cold. The National Association of Forest Industries accepts that there are important issues which need to be handled in detail and with responsibility. The coalition totally supports the need for resource security and development of large forest industry projects, such as pulp mills in Tasmania. We are willing to work with the Government and industry to draft appropriate and suitable legislation to offer resource security. Therefore, the future of resource security lies with the Labor Government. Its present attempts are unsatisfactory.

This Bill must be rejected as it ignores many of the issues fundamental to resource security. The Bill ignores a large part of the forest industry—the sawmillers with businesses under $100m. It simply does not provide security for the industry it does cover because of the potential for ministerial intervention. It rejects compensation and it ties up projects.

This Bill is not about resource security; it is another example of the Government's attempt to govern the country by avoiding the real issues and, in the process, creating a legislative mess that is a disincentive to investment which is badly needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Coulter rightly observed, the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 neither conserves forests nor does it develop them. Its title is really quite a misnomer and is misleading.

PARA.TAB: The concept of resource security, which has been at the heart of much of what has been said about this Bill, has a basic illogicality about it. It is an illogicality which, I suggest, is derived from the colonial concept of land grants. Land was granted with freehold title to those who were already privileged enough to have sufficient capital to engage in what was then described as the fight to tame mother nature, to tame the land. But this was done for profit.

While this may have been thought appropriate in the colonial period of our history—and there is even a considerable body of opinion to suggest that it was not appropriate even then—the fact is that this country is not now a colonial outpost, and such colonial attitudes are not appropriate. The concept that is embodied in what I have just described is supported and promoted in this very Bill. It is promoted by those people who wish to privatise all enterprises. I suggest that that is where the illogicality lies.

It is proposed to remove a significant proportion of all commercial risks by using a public resource while retaining private commercial control over that resource. In other words, control over that resource, which has been defined, mapped and protected from the ravages of fire, flood and pests, at great cost to the community—a resource which has been nurtured by the community—will now be dedicated exclusively to the profitable exploitation of private investors.

I believe it is illogical because those who believe that the markets should rule and those who do not believe in the public ownership of enterprises are the very same people who support this Bill—the very antithesis of a market-driven enterprise. In this Bill the resource is not subjected to market forces; rather, it is provided—I will have more to say about that word later—exclusively with guarantees to a limited select group of entrepreneurs. The Opposition rightly criticises the lack of consideration given to other potential users of the resource—the smaller sawmillers, the specialists or even smaller integrated enterprises. That is about where its concern stops.

I have heard little mention in the debate so far about the artists—the sculptors, the people who engage in the craft of marquetry, which we see such fantastic examples of in this place, the craftsmen, the jewellers and the producers of imaginative furniture and chattels. Those people's access to this resource has not been a concern expressed by the coalition so far. These talented artisans add immense value to resources which are not even recognised by others.

I will take some time to relate an anecdote which is most relevant in this situation. In 1987 I was lucky enough to be introduced to a carpenter who had successfully engaged in a building project which involved building five domestic cottages in a most idyllic setting in a seaside area of Hobart. The fascination of these cottages is that they were built from timber which had been described by Tasmania's Forestry Commission as non-existent. The cottages were built from considerably large section poles of celery-top pine, a timber which is renowned in Tasmania for its special qualities. It is an attractive timber which is durable, hard and strong and has a beautiful honey colour, such that it is often confused with Huon pine. It has a close grain.

These cottages had been built out of celery pine logs and sections which have been described by our Forestry Commission as non-existent. They were non-existent because there had been a clear-felling operation and a firewood-gathering operation, a licence had been granted to craft-wood gatherers and there had been a regeneration burn over these logs. In other words, according to our Forestry Commission all gettable useful timber had been removed.

This carpenter, with a small one-tonne Toyota truck, had been able to glean sufficient timber from this area to build, at considerable profit to himself and considerable satisfaction to the owners, five beautiful cottages which stand to this day as a testament to the ignorance of the Forestry Commission advisers at the time.

The other anecdote that I would like to give is a very personal one. This week I was trying to have built for me an extension to my house, which involved a new kitchen bench. I thought it would be rather attractive to use some of this celery-top pine. I found that this attractive timber is not purchasable in Tasmania, the State in which it is endemic. It is not possible to buy sufficient celery-top pine in Tasmania to make one kitchen bench. It is available in Victoria. I would have to buy it in Victoria where it is being sent from Tasmania.

Why has this nonsense perpetuated? Because small efficient local mills are unable to gain access to the resource. Even now, such enterprises have been denied access by those who control the forest resource. I believe this is next to criminal because the resource is not particularly scarce. As a matter of fact, in several places it is quite plentiful. It is unavailable in Tasmania because the timber gathering methods that are used, and the size of the enterprises needed to afford the machinery which uses those methods, prevails in such a way that the specialist timbers have become unattainable. I cannot buy that particular type of timber this week because of the very methods that are used in harvesting our timbers in Tasmania.

The clear-felling mentality dominates our forest resource extraction methods. There is no longer room for the specialist miller who selectively logs for specific purposes. The only method that is used and endorsed by the Forestry Commission is to indiscriminately cut all trees and to categorise the logs so obtained. This is very much a mechanical process; it is not a labour intensive process. The typical machinery that is used in this process is able to cut, lop, strip, debark and load a log onto a truck. One machine and one operator are used.

I did not listen to all of Senator Sherry's contribution; I got a little excited about his references to our approach to this matter. I suspect that Senator Sherry is perhaps caught up in the romanticism of some of the timber worker pictures that he may have seen. The old pictures of the well-muscled timber workers who scale the forest giants and open the face with a kelly axe, stand on wooden planks with steel shoes that are magically stable and then heroically swish through the huge trunk with a two-man broadsaw should be forgotten. It does not apply any more; it is not there. That image has disappeared. Thousands of such skilled workers have been forced to leave the industry and have been replaced by the machinery which the large companies have been able to afford.

The industry is no longer labour intensive. The efficient use of the modern tree-harvesting machinery requires that a uniform tree size and description is tackled. Smaller, larger, shorter or longer trees are actually a nuisance. I suspect that is why it is very difficult to buy specialist timbers. Different species get in the way. At this stage the price differential hardly justifies the effort required to recognise the species, to trim it properly and to place it aside. It has been said to me that it is more efficient to use the machinery to squash the minor species than to leave them behind as fuel for the infamous regeneration burn.

We have here another example of a recently developed myth which has been used to justify the practices which monolithic forest exploiters have recently developed. The fact is that fire has always been part of the scenery in Australian eucalypt forests. There is another indisputable fact that other species, such as banksias, are able to survive low intensity fires and then prosper in the post-fire environment where competition has been reduced.

It is also a fact that huge broadacre fires are not necessary to provide regeneration. It is not a fact that such broadacre fires have been a regular part of the ecology of our old growth forests. Just as small-scale selective harvesting can provide us with specialised timbers, so can they be followed by small-scale fires which can provide the regeneration necessary to retain the character of eucalypt forests.

I will deal with a couple of other myths as well. It is a fact, as was mentioned by Senator Newman, that Tasmania needs jobs. It is a simplistic statement which is a truism. Senator Newman continued to follow on with something about which I admire her perceptiveness in bringing to this chamber. She told us that if APPM provides a pulp mill it may provide jobs. But that company has not yet said that it will provide a pulp mill. I emphasise the word `provide'. Her choice of words makes it seem almost as though the company was going to present us with a pulp mill as a gift.

I agree with Senator Newman's perceptive observation that no individual or company has yet guaranteed investment of any nature if this legislation passes. In other words, no Bill, no mill. But if the Bill passes, will mills be guaranteed? The answer is no. Senator Newman was right in her perceptions. It is a myth that passage of this Bill could deliver projects, jobs, or anything else.

A lot of correspondence has been quoted, particularly by members of the coalition from whom we have had emotional blackmail to encourage the passage of this Bill—blackmail which has suggested that, unless the Bill passes, certain projects will not occur, certain things cannot continue. I agree strongly with Senator Newman that no guarantees have been delivered by any of that correspondence. A great deal of fear has been delivered, but no guarantees. The promise of downstream processing which might derive after the passage of this Bill is a hollow promise. I assure those interested in this issue that real downstream processing will not occur. Woodchipping will occur, pulping might occur, but the real value adding will not occur.

I found myself experiencing quite a strange set of emotions, as I was agreeing with Senator Campbell. That is something I have not done before and it was quite an experience. I was pleasantly surprised. I must make a fuss about this because Senator Campbell got it right. He described to us the benefits of private nurturing and developing of forests in South America and in South Australia. Senator Campbell rightly observed that some of the forest products—such as resins, oil pigments, brazil nuts and rainforest crunch peanuts—had been profitably extracted from forests in South America under private ownership.

Senator Campbell mentioned correctly Dr John Walmsley in South Australia who has nurtured a forest and derived a considerable income from it. He has given tens of thousands of people considerable satisfaction from visiting the forest which he has nurtured. The important thing to note is that Dr Walmsley has purchased the land; the investment in the forest has been paid for entirely by him and it is in his title. He owns the resource and he has the ultimate security over that resource—he has paid for it. That is vastly different from what is proposed here. To ensure proper security of resource, its title should be bought and fully paid for.

Senator O'Chee interested me with his contribution, part of which I listened to. He again engaged in the correspondence reading device. He suggested that hundreds of millions of dollars invested in softwood plantations would be wasted because such plantations cannot be milled unless the hardwood mills have been granted security over the forest resource. I would describe that as utter nonsense. It illustrates a total misunderstanding of the milling industry, an industry which in many cases—certainly in Tasmania—has mills based on the harvesting of specific species.

Tasmanian sawmills specialising in the plantation harvesting and production of radiata pine logs and radiata pine planks for both building work and furniture construction are not threatened by the rejection of this Bill—quite the opposite. Such plantation industries have developed their resource, they have security over their softwood plantation resource, and they have the sort of security which Senator Campbell mentioned as most desirable: they own their resource.

I also agreed with Senator Macdonald. He read from a letter to him which suggested that this legislation was to provide security to pulp mills, paper mills and multinationals but not to the smaller operators, especially sawmills.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—I acknowledge that Senator Baume agrees with that criticism of this legislation. I am sorry that I do not expect his acknowledgment of agreement with what I am about to say next. Apart from the omission of the smaller operators, the whole concept of resource security as described in this debate rests entirely upon the exploitation of timber in our forests. We have heard about timber as though it were the only resource available from our forests.

PARA.TAB: The omissions are well understood by most Tasmanians. I am surprised that the Tasmanian senators who have contributed to this debate so far have not mentioned this aspect. We in Tasmania should all be well aware of the fact that scenery is a resource. The tourist industry has been ridiculed for decades because it is seen as a soft industry. It is not one of those hard, driving, tough industries involving lots of noisy machinery and crashing, crunching and bashing about. It is not a macho industry at all. It is considered a soft industry. The fact that it was ridiculed for some decades is ridiculous. The tourist industry is a huge export industry. We do not export the views, but tourists travel to our scenery and pay us with their foreign currency to look at it. That resource is not guaranteed by this legislation.

The biological diversity of our forests is an unquantifiable resource which we have not yet fully tapped. Through our own ignorance we know little of the chemical, medicinal, genetic and agricultural treasures which are hidden in our old growth forests. The fauna of our forests is also a resource which is not guaranteed by this legislation. The biological diversity includes our former species. These treasures of our Australian heritage are threatened directly by the clear-felling, large scale, machinery-driven, broadacre fire regime which this legislation would encourage. Our native fauna is a resource which is not guaranteed by this legislation any more than our native flora is.

There is even another resource that is not guaranteed by this legislation. I hesitate to mention it because by doing so one draws attention to the fact that it is not guaranteed. As a result of this, we could see a proposition that seeks somehow to guarantee it. Senator Panizza would be understandably disappointed that exploiters of our mineral resources which may be found in our forests will receive no guarantees from this legislation.

I conclude by repeating the basic observation which has been made so often about our forests. This Bill is entitled the Forest Conservation and Development Bill. The observation which has been made, and which I repeat, is that forests are not developed by clear-felling. To develop our forests we need to nurture them. That is not necessarily incompatible with proper, selective gleaning of the resources of our forests. I would never support the proposition that we do not glean resources from these forests.

The gathering of timber, the processing of timber and the value adding of any of the resources is not incompatible with the nurturing of the forest as itself. This attitude is one which, throughout history, has been proven to be correct. We know of the cultural, sociological and economic development of our society that has been possible through entering forests to glean resources, not to harm the development of the forests but to protect them from the ravages of fire, plague or any other threats which might come to them and then to be able to revisit the forests to gain from them the resources which have been regenerated by the fact that we have been able to nurture them. Many previous generations of smaller sawmillers have followed those sorts of practices and they have nurtured and protected our forests without destroying them.

The central theme of what I have said tonight in contribution to this debate has been that modern forestry practices and methods are the greatest threats to our forests. In my opinion, they pose a threat of turning what is now forest into monoculture. That would bring the hazards of any sort of monoculture: the susceptibility to pests; the susceptibility to fluctuations in world markets; and the danger of damaging the substructure of the soil which provides the basis for that culture.

Monocultures bring with them many hazards. We fail to recognise that modern forestry practice is essentially monoculture. We do not pay sufficient regard to that. We do not recognise that what we are doing is a cheap version of tree farming. If we were honest and faced up to that, we would not disguise such forestry practices as forestry practices. We would not try to pretend that what we were doing was forestry. We would face up to what it is.

These modern forestry practices are encouraged by the very nature and content of this Bill because of the inadequacies that have been properly identified by the coalition. Also, this Bill does not recognise the other resources that are contained within our forests. It does not make provision for their development, just as it does not make any proper provision for the development of the timber industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Forest Conservation and Development Bill. Firstly, I support my colleagues with regard to this legislation; that is, I oppose it unless the Government is prepared to accept the Opposition's amendments. I add that these amendments have the support of NAFI and the unions involved.

PARA.TAB: I would like to highlight a couple of areas in which this Bill fails. I have no intention of going over all of the areas because my colleagues have already done that. Particularly relative to the Western Australian situation, this Bill does not include security for business operations under $100m. Even then, the security for the $100m is of dubious value.

Another point I wish to raise, which was brought out very succinctly by Senator Walsh, is the fact that this Bill will give those extremists in the conservation movement or the extreme greenies a legal opportunity to harass loggers, to follow them around looking for areas where they can take action, under the protection of a Bill, to stop that logging. That is a very bad aspect of this particular legislation. In that sense, it gives no security whatsoever. Of course, the flow-on impact of that down the line will mean that we will see, I believe, the most organised harassment of an industry ever seen in Australia. That will cost many people in the chain of the forestry industry their jobs.

I would also like to mention the Western Australian position because I have had representations from people in Western Australia; my colleagues have also had representations from people in their States. I wish to mention the State branch of the National Association of Forest Industries and, in particular, Trish Townsend and a group of people she brought to see me in my office last week. That group consisted of sawmillers, people in the transport area of the forest industry, people working in the mills, representatives of the unions involved in the full chain of the forest operation in Western Australia. To a person they agreed, after we had discussed this legislation, that it should be opposed unless the Government is prepared to accept our proposed amendments.

I also wish to make some comments about the existing Western Australian system with regard to the management of forests. I firmly believe that it is, in fact, an area that the Commonwealth should keep right out of. It should be left to the States. Western Australia has provided the model by which this can be done.

I was fortunate this week to do a tour of our south-west forests with Mr Peter Johnson, who is the manager of the Kruger National Park in South Africa, and Dr Syd Shea, who is the Director of the Department of Conservation and Land Management in Western Australia. It was spelt out quite clearly, in terms of the forest operation in Western Australia, that the Department does take into account the various values, some of which Senator Bell has just raised.

It takes into account, for example, the importance of tourism and forestry to tourism. It takes into account conservation values in the sense of salinity control, water control and water preservation. It takes into account conservation requirements with regard to flora and fauna. But importantly also, it has a reasonable and rational manner for dealing with forestry. It has designated certain areas of the forest for particular uses. That does not preclude, except in the case of national parks, the other various values being utilised throughout the whole forest.

I mention some of the things that we saw in terms of the management of forest. One of the most outstanding things we saw was forests that had been severely affected by dieback, fire and a number of other minor problems cleared and replanted with karri trees. We saw areas where karri trees had been planted some 40 years ago. We also saw the various stages of trees, those that were planted 40 years ago and those that were planted six months ago. We saw karri trees that were planted just six months ago which today are about two-thirds of a metre high. They are thriving and growing back in the land.

We also saw in some areas where globulus had been planted and those trees were thriving and doing very well. We saw how CALM operated in terms of logging, sawmilling, and the thinning and removing of undesirable species. I want to say that that is the type of model by which we should be managing our forests so that we do utilise or maintain the various values in conjunction with a profitable, successful forestry industry.

I wish now to touch on the other aspect of forestry that has developed in Western Australia, that is, on-farm forest production. I was fortunate back in 1986 to be involved with the manager of CALM and the then State Government Minister in putting together what is now known as the on-farm forestry policy. That policy developed a number of aspects. Probably the most important one that I wish to mention here is a model of a sharefarming agreement which allows, in conjunction with the Department of Conservation and Land Management and also with WACAP, sharefarming agreements to be put together, thus enabling private land holders to participate in forest production in Western Australia.

The essence of these agreements is a joint effort between the farmer and CALM or WACAP. Trees are planted either by the farmer, CALM or WACAP and a system of payments is put in place, whereby the farmer can be paid an annuity per year for the estimated life of the forest. Through that operation, agreement can be reached, for example, over a 10-year period, which is the usual time taken. The farmer can take a 10 per cent annuity if he chooses on the estimated value of the forest at the end of the time or, if he so wishes, when negotiating that share farming agreement, he can take a 5 per cent annuity of the estimated value which would leave 50 per cent at the end of the 10 years. Then CALM or WACAP will share equally in the price that is obtained at the end of the 10-year period. That demonstrates quite clearly that commercial, private, on-farm forestry can operate successfully alongside those public areas in Western Australia that have been designated for forest use.

I want to make some comments about the Commonwealth and its role and, in particular, the Australian Heritage Commission. Over the last 12 months the Australian Heritage Commission has looked at forest areas which have heritage value and has identified them. It has come to a very successful agreement with CALM or the State Government concerning those areas that have been identified. However, then it became greedy. It decided—without any discussion with the private land-holders involved—that it would list 300 farms under the National Heritage Listing. That meant that the contributions of all the farmers who had gone into share-farming agreements with CALM and WACAP, made an investment and planted trees were being put at risk. As I am sure all honourable senators know, the Australian Heritage Commission has enormous powers. Fortunately, through political pressure and other means, it has been forced to withdraw that heritage nomination.

I wish to make the point that the Commonwealth Government should keep right out of this area. It should be left to the type of agreement and arrangements that we have in Western Australia. The action of the Australian Heritage Commission was an infringement of the rights of those individual private landholders—and this is where I disagree with some of the statements made by Senator Bell. He inferred that under private landhold arrangements and forestry their product would be safe. In fact, under the current Australian Heritage legislation, it is not safe.

The next point I wish to refer to concerns the genuineness of this Government about this legislation.
