I suspect—and I have it on good authority—that Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, and also Senator Richardson, who sits in this chamber, would dearly love this legislation to be defeated, because they could then say to the Australian public, `We have tried', and yet at the same time say to the greenies, `Well, we have not really done anything. You still have the same situation as you had before'. I question the Government's genuineness and the Opposition will test it when we come to the amendments. The amendments will improve bad legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they won't.

—They will improve bad legislation and the honourable senator should talk to the people in the industry if he does not believe that. Perhaps he should move back to his own seat and make his interjections from there.

PARA.TAB: The amendments will improve the legislation and that is borne out by all the material that I have in front of me. I have no doubt that Senator Sherry has received the same material. In fact, I know that the Prime Minister has received the same material. I will not quote from the letter to the Prime Minister because it has already been quoted in this debate tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —So has everything.
—The Minister is having a little mumble over there as well. I hope the book that he has in front on him is a good one!
—It is the Oxford Dictionary of Popes.

—Good. I believe that the Prime Minister would prefer to see this legislation defeated. I wind up my comments by saying that this legislation does not give the security to the forest industries that the Australian public has been led to believe it provides. The whole issue of running the forests and looking after them should be left to the State governments. This legislation should be rejected unless amended. The industry wants the amendments; the unions involved want the amendments. The stumbling block is the Government.
—But the union groups will support the legislation.
—That is not what I have here. The honourable senator should move back to his seat.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—If Senator Sherry wishes to participate in the debate, he must return to his seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991. Before I begin my criticism of the Government's action and of the contents of the Bill I must declare an interest, because one of the beneficiaries in this legislation is APPM and I currently have a logging contract with that company. However, that might mean that I bring a very practical perspective to this legislation.

PARA.TAB: This is indeed a very bad piece of legislation. It is bad because it really does not offer the sort of security that it pretends to offer. It is a label without substance. It does not affect the Commonwealth's decision-making power in relation to world heritage and conservation, for example, and I refer to clause 25. It permits another Act to be put through this place that overrules the present Act and actually encourages those who are against logging to go out into the forests and discover species for the purpose of ending logging in that area. Currently, there are some very unacceptable provisions in clauses 9 and 23 concerning no compensation. However, I understand that some verbal undertakings have been given that these may be withdrawn. I certainly hope so. That will improve the quality of the legislation.

There are a number of reasons why this Bill is attracting so much attention at present. Since 1985 there has been a heated and often highly politicised forestry debate which has been waged both on the mainland and certainly in Tasmania. Speaking from Tasmania's point of view, I have to say that the Commonwealth Government has not had a very good record of upholding any agreements it has made with the Tasmanian forest industry, and nationally the industry is not prepared to invest in value added or other projects without resource security.

In 1985, the Tasmanian woodchip industry, represented by APPM, Forest Products and Forest Resources along with the Forestry Commission put together an environmental impact statement—an EIS—for the industry. A number of environmental issues were looked at in putting this publication together, including how special areas should be managed. A number of working papers relating to the environmental impact study were also presented after a substantial amount of research. A lot of work was also done on the measurement of the available resource on both Crown land and private property.

Once this EIS was complete, Mr John Kerin, on behalf of the Federal Government, signed a memorandum of understanding dated 12 June 1986. This memorandum of understanding ratified forest management systems in Tasmania and specified requirements for further research. This research has been ongoing. It is administered by the Tasmanian Forest Research Council under a person at the University of Tasmania and is funded by a levy on woodchip exported from Tasmania imposed by the Commonwealth.

This memorandum of understanding was thought to be an agreement which the State and the forest industries could work to and use as a planning tool. It was thought that the Federal Government was happy that the forestry operation should go ahead as per the environmental impact study. The fact that it had been signed by Mr Kerin as the Minister indicated this.

However, the memorandum of understanding was broken by the Federal Government within six months of it being signed. Although the environmental impact study stated that logging management plans under two areas, Jackeys Marsh and Lemonthyme, were to be logged, the Federal Government did not allow logging to proceed under these plans.

In late 1986, another committee was established to look at whether logging should be allowed in the Jackeys Marsh and the Lemonthyme areas. The committee consisted of five members. Three of those members recommended that the Lemonthyme area not be logged. Similarly, three of the five recommended that Jackeys Marsh be logged.

Following the Nix report, the then Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, via the press, stepped in and stopped the logging in Jackeys Marsh and the removal of pulpwood from Lemonthyme. The then Minister, Mr John Kerin, on hearing about the announcement when he arrived back from overseas, immediately apologised and said that it could not be correct. Needless to say, poor John Kerin had his knuckles rapped and the announcement stood.

The industry was immediately stopped in its tracks without ever a letter by the Prime Minister having been received or without ever any justification having been put either to the industry or, for that matter, to the Forestry Commission which managed the forests on behalf of the Tasmanian people. It was a disgraceful situation.

Whilst on the topic of Jackeys Marsh, let us dwell for a moment on its history. The area was nominated for National Estate in the mid-1980s and put on the interim list virtually straightaway, which afforded it National Estate status. The listing was finally gazetted in February this year, some seven years later—and then only after much review.

The reasons for National Estate nomination as per the application to the Australian Heritage Commission were twofold: firstly, it was claimed that there were a number of rare and endangered plant species—this is one of the weaknesses of the Bill—which had made it worthy of listing. Secondly, and more generally, it was claimed that there were landscape and aesthetic values—this is already covered by the Bill.

The final listing has rejected the aesthetic values and has confirmed, in much smaller areas than those first nominated, that the plant species concerned justify listing. In listing these plant species, though, it is acknowledged—and I emphasise this—that the species were found to be also present in logged-over coupes.

I wonder whether the Prime Minister has ever stopped to reconsider the decision he made in 1987. In hindsight, and scientifically speaking, it was definitely a wrong decision from all points of view. The then Prime Minister then made his `no more logging in Jackeys Marsh' statement. He also announced a further inquiry.

Many of those present would remember the Helsham inquiry which commenced in 1987 and ran for something like 12 months. While the Helsham inquiry was, specifically on World Heritage qualifications, of a circumscribed area—that is, the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests—it also investigated the whole spectrum of native forest management issues, the significance of the forestry industry in Tasmania and the impact on that industry of any change in resource accessibility as a result of a change of World Heritage boundaries. The upshot of that, again in terms of forest management, was that, while there was and will always be further research needed, in general forest management was not producing unacceptable impacts on native forests and that the industry was efficient.

This led to the Cook-Groom agreement of late 1988. Senator Cook, the then Minister for Resources, and Ray Groom, the State Minister for forests, again ratified forest management systems in areas outside the World Heritage area. The agreement also declared that the Government would not unilaterally impose any more World Heritage listings in Tasmania. But this Bill specifically provides that this may happen.

Two of the Helsham commissioners also recommended that a very small fraction—about 10 per cent of the inquiry area—should be proposed to UNESCO for World Heritage listing. The other commissioner recommended essentially that all the inquiry area should be included while Senator Richardson suggested that well over 100 per cent of the inquiry area should be listed. That is what happened; 100 per cent was listed.

So time and time again the Tasmanian forest industry has been inquired into and given a rating on its operations. Yet time and time again the Federal Government, for whatever reason, has gone back on its agreements and made decisions which have no reference to the inquiry's findings. This Bill provides the opportunity for history to be repeated again and again. In fact, I submit that, as a result of this Bill, there are even more opportunities than ever before for this to happen.

Previously, the Government has broken written agreements. This is the real reason that the industry distrusts the Government and now wants resource security legislation. John Hewson has said that, under a Federal Liberal government, resource security would not be needed. We can trust John Hewson. Effectively, the Government threw science out the window and did what was at the time politically more acceptable to the ALP.

As if there had not been inquiries enough already, the Resource Assessment Commission started a forest inquiry in November 1989. It has put its final report on that inquiry in to the Prime Minister in the last day or two. While this inquiry is national in scope, it still represents in part yet another inquiry into Tasmanian forestry practices.

Without knowing exactly what the final draft says, the draft report, put out in the middle of last year, and subsequent meetings between industry and the RAC have essentially confirmed that modern forestry practice in native forests presents no problems. For example, the RAC draft report explicitly notes that no species extinctions can be attributed to forestry in the 200 years of white settlement. That is a very significant statement. The Commission has also confirmed the importance of the industry and, in general, its efficiency.

Finally, the latest of the inquiries at a State level, the Forest and Forest Industries Council and the production of a forest and forest industry strategy, has been going on over the last two years. This inquiry also put forest management practice under the microscope. In this case, the environmental lobby was involved for the majority of the inquiry.

The relevance of the FFIC and that process is that it has led to State resource security legislation which incorporates procedures for protecting new values as these become apparent, within a broad framework of certainty of access to resource for the industry. In other words, resource security does not by definition preclude the protection of values. It simply imposes a discipline on governments to make sure that they can justify further restrictions. But that is not the case with the Federal legislation.

For the last seven years, the life of Tasmania's forest industry has been one long, continuous inquiry interspersed with agreements that have not been upheld. Not one inquiry has resulted in a more secure working environment for the industry, and that is indeed regrettable. What will it take for confidence to be restored to Australia's forest industry, and for that industry to feel assured of its future and start to plan ahead? The answer is quite simple: all it wants is workable resource security legislation while we have this present Government.

I am pleased that the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 is to be referred to a committee because, as it stands, it is not a workable piece of legislation in terms of providing the needed security. The national bodies do not help because they seem to have three positions. Australia's forest industry, particularly in Tasmania, has been through a torrid seven years, and it is the Federal Government which has put it through this torrid time. I put on record that I strongly support the amendments that have been proposed and I trust that reason will prevail so that this Senate can deliver a proper Bill. Tasmanians then will be able to breathe a sigh of relief as the passage of this Bill, correctly amended, will ensure that a pulp mill will be built in Tasmania.

APPM is indeed a very brave company at this time. It is important to note that it has allocated, through North Broken Hill, a sum of money for the development of a pulp mill. That amount of money will not stay there indefinitely because there are alternative uses in a mining group which can utilise effectively and efficiently those investment moneys. Therefore, it is up to the Senate to give the directors the confidence to proceed with a pulp mill which will make a great deal of difference in Tasmania.

APPM has stated that there are three remaining items to be completed before it enters the 72-week State-Federal Government assessment procedure that will examine the environmental, economic, social and community impact of the mill. Therefore, a lot of criteria have to be met. One of them, naturally, is resource security, which we hope the Bill, in an appropriately amended form, will deliver.

There is also a requirement for the Commonwealth to complete its studies on Tasmanian forests. That requires the cooperation of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) who is known to be not a great supporter of this legislation. So we will see further tension within this Government, further procrastination and delay. Even though we may get the resource security legislation, the Government still has this vehicle—this second tier—by which the poor old company has to wait while the Government completes its studies on the Tasmanian forests. The industry has been through seven torrid years, with numerous inquiries, broken agreements and still another vulnerable hurdle has to be overcome. Yet, to the credit of APPM, it is prepared to wait.

TALK.START.PARA: —They deserve a Victoria Cross.

—Not only does APPM deserve the Victoria Cross, but also it is a company that deserves some recognition. It is prepared to put its money up, but the conditions are pretty tough. It also needs a partner because the mill is going to be on a world scale. If this Bill is not passed, it will be so much more difficult for such a company to attract a partner on an international scale. We trust, from certain discussions, that the Government may be prepared to delete the no compensation clause—clause 23—which would also involve clause 9.

PARA.TAB: It is important that the Tasmanian Government has placed its confidence in this project. Both the Commonwealth and the State of Tasmania have undertaken to enter into an intergovernmental agreement designed to ensure that alternative wood, at no additional cost, would be made available to the mill in the event that further areas of forest were to be locked up in the future. Certainly the Tasmanian Government would honour that agreement, but the manner in which the Federal Government has walked away from signed agreements, signed undertakings, does not give people a lot of optimism.

Let us hope that the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs which will be examining this Bill can put the Bill in order, after appropriate input from a wide range of participants and interest groups, to ensure that when this Bill comes back into this Senate next Thursday it will be passed. Thus, the forest industry will be given a measure—and that is all we can really say—of comfort which it is prepared to accept, so that it can concentrate on future growth and prosperity and, in Tasmania's case, the economic well-being of the State, instead of just having an inquiry or another series of inquiries.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with concern to Senator Watson as he reiterated the saga of the Tasmanian timber industry over the last seven years.
—Similar to Victoria.

—I was going to suggest that it is not greatly different from the saga of the timber industry in Queensland where many thousands of good, decent unionists have been sold out by the ALP. The ALP has decided to ditch—to dump—its grassroots support, to turn its back on the decent working men and women of Australia and to support the white wine socialists and the Volvo yuppie group.

PARA.TAB: Tonight we are debating the Forest Conservation and Development Bill. It is an attempt by the forest industry and the unions to get some sort of working harmony that will allow development in the industry. The Government has said that it is not prepared to help, under any circumstances, unless people are prepared to spend $100m. So, in effect, the legislation before the Senate tonight will give resource protection to a proposed pulp mill only, the APPM, which I believe the Government desperately needs. The $100m threshold contained in the Bill is far in excess of any other company's investments in Australia. It is just another indication that the Government has really deserted the timber industry.

Senator Kemp says the Government has deserted the timber industry in Victoria, Senator Watson says it has deserted the timber industry in Tasmania and I can certainly vouch for the Government's desperate attitude to the timber industry in Queensland. Since this Government has come into power and put the environmentalists in charge of the arts, sport, tourism and the territories—and has now placed Mrs Kelly in there, who is a mere puppet of Mr Toyne—the Greens have had a field day.The sawmill industry—the timber industry—just cannot be confident that it has any long term future at all.

This is a very important industry to regional Australia. It is the biggest employer of people—it employs 106,000 people—and it could employ many more if resource security was available to all timber mills and pulp mills.These are the types of jobs that Australia desperately needs as our factories close down and one million people are unemployed. This is one of the few areas where semi-skilled workers have some sort of employment potential. It is one of the very few areas where we can offer them jobs.

These jobs cannot be created unless the Government is prepared to accept the amendments proposed by the industry and the unions. The Government appears to have no inclination to do that. I do not know how members of the ALP can come down here and turn their backs on their constituents. Is the ALP trying to fill the niche market that the Democrats have taken? Is it a party for the worker any more? No wonder a union, the AWU, in Tasmania has said that the ALP no longer represents the worker and has disaffiliated itself.

There are at least 100,000 jobs, and there could be another 40,000 jobs, that could be provided if this legislation were to go through with the amendments. Unless this legislation goes through, we will not even hold the employment line that we now have in the timber industry. There will be more lay-offs because of the Government's failure to back the industry and union amendments. The banks would not put confederate money into the timber industry at the moment unless there was some type of security.

Really, the Labor Party has to make up its mind where its political niche is in the marketplace. It has to make a decision as to whether it will walk away from its past. It has to make a decision as to where it stands and what its prospects are for the future. It also has to decide, in the light of its centenary last year when many of its heavies gathered under the Tree of Knowledge in Barcaldine, whether it is a working man's party, or whether it is a party that represents only the environmentalist. Tonight, when the vote is taken, will really be the moment of truth for the Labor Party.

The record in the timber industry since the Labor Party came to power in 1983 could only be described as appalling. In north Queensland, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen knows only too well because she has been up there a number of times, in the towns of Ravenshoe and Milla Milla on the tablelands, 3,000 jobs were destroyed; 12 sawmills were closed down. That area had been logged for 80 years. Sure, the area was not in its pristine condition but it was still there and it was still providing a base for 3,000 people who were drawing an income from that industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened to them all now?

—If I were to go through the sorry saga of the people who lost their jobs in that rainforest area it would be a very sad story. Senator Bjelke-Petersen knows only too well that the traditional people who had earned their living from that forest area for a number of generations—those proud workers—were reduced to picking up papers, cleaning toilets and painting roadside signs. They were given absolutely menial jobs that had no long term future whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: Only two months ago, the Queensland State ALP closed down the logging on Fraser Island with a further loss of 400 jobs. Those small communities that relied on the timber industry, like Ravenshoe, have been turned into a disaster area—broken marriages, wrecked businesses, people losing their self-respect and skilled fourth and fifth generation workers put on very menial jobs. The jobs that are provided are short term jobs with no future.

In Maryborough the Goss Government has made the same commitment, saying it will compensate Maryborough and the timber industry. It has taken the heat off in the short term, but the timber industry deserves better than that. It is not Australia's biggest rural industry but it is the largest regional employer in regional Australia, and it deserves some long term future. The Government could give that long term future tonight if it were not beholden to the Phillip Toynes of this world and the Green movement. The Government may feel it is in debt to the Green movement because it ensured the Government's return to power at the last election. But in paying off that debt, the Government is short changing its grassroots union members.

The timber industry needs a base to work on. If it could have resource security it could invest in the long term by developing plantations, employing more people, gaining investment and borrowing money. Unless the Government recognises this, the hardwood timber industry as we know it now will not be in existence in 30 years time. We will be importing all our timber. We are already importing over $2 billion worth of timber into Australia, which is around 8 per cent of our trade deficit.

I have been around politics for a long time and I can say that that environmental vote will not be there next time. People are worried about their jobs, their children having jobs or their grandchildren having jobs; or being able to pay off their mortgages on their homes. There will not be that 10 per cent environmental vote. So Senator Cook is on a loser; he may have paid his debt but he will not get the return at the next election.

The Government has more than paid its debt to the Green movement; it has paid it a thousand times over. It has paid it with its two uranium mines policy, its World Heritage listing and its National Estate listings. The Green movement gets put ahead of the traditional unionist supporter every time; he is a second class citizen when it comes to the timber industry. After this little performance tonight, the timber industry and all those who work in it should protest by disaffiliating themselves from the Labor Party. I would not be surprised if they did.

TALK.START.PARA: —You'd love that.

—It would be justice if they turned their backs on the Government and walked away because it has neglected them. The Government has kicked them and done nothing for them. When they have paid $200 in hard-earned cash in union fees, the Government has kicked them every time. It would be no wonder if they turned their backs.
—The National Party supporting the union movement! This is a hell of a surprise.
—It is the Liberal Party in Tasmania that gets the blue collar vote.

—The coalition should get the blue collar vote not only in Tasmania. If the workers knew just what the ALP does to them in this timber industry, they would turn their backs on it forever, as many of them have done in the timber areas of Queensland.
—The workers are a bit smarter than you give them credit for.

—That is why they are going to neglect the Government and walk away from it, as they have done in Tasmania. That is the first wedge in. The Government will see many more of them deserting it as long as it treats them in this offhanded, cavalier fashion. The Government thinks that it has a mortgage on the workers' vote and that it can just walk away from them every time they need it. Even a worm will turn if one treats it badly enough.

PARA.TAB: A sum of $4.6 billion is involved in the processing of hardwood and paper pulping. In the sawmill industry $235m is being invested by 1,200 sawmills. Australia needs the timber industry and Australia needs the jobs that that industry provides. Australia needs import replacement, and it could have all of those if this Government accepted a commonsense approach. Because of the Government's refusal to accept the amendments, we will get less rather than more investment. Our sawmills are becoming uncompetitive against imported timbers. We are now importing 30 per cent of our domestic consumption, much of that coming from countries that are just clear-felling, ripping bulldozers through forests which will never be reproductive again.

This legislation is for only one company. Senator Bjelke-Petersen may remember, as many of us do, the 3,000 people who came down here and encircled this Parliament with their trucks in a very orderly demonstration. They said they would not leave until they got some satisfaction, some guarantee that they would have resource security. The Government promised that they would have that. Those people drove away misled. They drove away from this Parliament after a week of camping out there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three hundred and eighty-three.

—That is right. The Government did not keep its word again. Those people put their trust in the Government. It said, `Go back to your homes; go back to your industry. We will give you that resource security'.
—Get it right.

—Well, the resource security is right. I am 100 per cent right. The Government promised those people, but when they went back they found that they had been misled again. None of those small business people will get any benefit out of this legislation whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: This legislation is flawed. It does not offer resource security. It is a sham. It is a disgrace to a government that calls itself the workers' parliamentary representative that it should reject this legislation by not accepting the amendments of the union. This legislation does not deserve any support, and I will not be voting for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 and this is the second reading debate. Might I say before I go on to the detail of my remarks that it is my understanding that the second reading of this Bill has been agreed and will be voted on in the affirmative, but that the Bill will be referred to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs for examination and report back to the Parliament. That is my understanding of the immediate fate of this Bill.
—Subject to a number of very strong reservations.
—No doubt the reservations are on the record, Senator Tambling, and they are well-known, not that we accept them. Nonetheless, I am merely indicating the broad direction of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the National Party, Senator Boswell, has just concluded his remarks, and there are two points I want to make before he leaves the chamber, since he is edging towards the door. First, he has propounded the preposterous notion that somehow or other I am in the pocket of the Greens. I think that even Senator Boswell would admit, perhaps in the back bar over a beer, that there is not a single Green in Australia who would lay claim to me. That is a well-known fact. Therefore, the credibility of Senator Boswell's statement is basically false.

Secondly, and more importantly, Senator Boswell said in his remarks—and I took notes—that the Government has deserted the timber industry. I want the record of this debate to show that it is this Government that has brought to this chamber legislation for resource security for the timber industry, and it is the Opposition that is opposing it. Let us get that right. We support it; we have brought it here. The Opposition opposes it.

On 29 November 1991, the Government introduced this Bill, the Forest Conservation and Development Bill. In introducing the Bill, the Government thought there was some prospect of this Parliament hearing some rational debate on what clearly is a significant and important issue confronting Australia and this industry. But I must say that having listened to the more recent debates and the earlier debates on second reading, I have witnessed a contribution from the Opposition that has made it very clear that this chamber and Australia have lost the opportunity for a rational debate because of the irrational content of much of what the Opposition has said.

When introducing this legislation, the Government wrote to the relevant Opposition shadow Ministers informing them that while the objects of the legislation were in themselves straightforward, the detail of the legislation was complex. Because of this, the Government extended an invitation to the Opposition to meet and discuss the legislation prior to this second reading debate. But did the Opposition accept that invitation? The answer to that question, as the Opposition knows, is that it did not. Instead of an informed and rational debate, we have witnessed an ill-informed second reading debate on an issue of considerable national importance. More is the pity, and the pity resides, I think, with the Opposition.

Rather than oppose this legislation, the Opposition should grasp the opportunity to try to understand it. It may well rue its failure to do so. This Opposition, notwithstanding its facade of wanting to get major projects started in Australia, has adopted a duplicitous position of saying that it would on the one hand build Wesley Vale, but hypocritically is opposing this legislation which is so necessary to enable a northern Tasmanian pulp mill. Previous Government speakers have asked the Opposition these questions. Why is the Opposition forsaking the national interest for short term political expediency? Why will the Opposition not allow the world scale northern Tasmanian pulp mill project to proceed? The only answer to that question is that the Opposition is prepared to forsake the national interest because it mistakenly believes that there is short term political gain in adopting the position that it has.

When I consider the Opposition's position, I have to ask myself: where are those politicians in Australia who are prepared to consider the issue on its merit rather than for short term political gain?

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are those who are prepared to consider it on its merit, and where are those who are prepared to put the national interest first? These traits are certainly not evident in the Opposition, nor in its Leader, who repeatedly reminds this House that he would allow the Wesley Vale pulp mill in Tasmania to proceed. But in marshalling his colleagues to oppose this legislation, he cannot deliver on that commitment.

PARA.TAB: Let me explain why this is so. North Broken Hill, the company which would build the Wesley Vale pulp mill, recently issued a press statement urging the Opposition to support the passage of this legislation through the Parliament. North Broken Hill said:

SPEECH.PARA: This would be a significant step forward in the advancement of this nationally important project.
North Broken Hill said that enabling this legislation to go through would be a significant step in allowing Wesley Vale to proceed.

PARA.TAB: North Broken Hill goes on to say that `the industry is totally unified' and that if there is to be a pulp mill in Tasmania, `both the Government and the Opposition must support the current legislation'. That is what the company says. The Opposition, whilst bleating its concern about getting major projects started in Australia, has adopted the duplicitous position of saying it would build a world scale pulp mill in Tasmania and yet is opposing this legislation.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was saying that with this action, the Opposition has abrogated a key commitment cited on page 63 of the executive summary of the Opposition's own tax package which states:

SPEECH.PARA: We will. . . not hinder any pulpmill proposal which meets the current pulpmill pollution guidelines and which satisfies relevant heritage, social and economic requirements.

Why? For short term political gain; to try to be different from the Government. In doing so, the Opposition is prepared to forsake, as I have said, the national interest. But there is more, much more, which shows that this Opposition is out of step with the industry and the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: Let me make these points about the industry's reaction to this issue. In March last year the National Association of Forest Industries said:

SPEECH.PARA: The role of the Federal Opposition in this debate has been a bit ambivalent.
NAFI goes on to say—and this is the industry association—

TALK.START.PARA: —What did they say in March of this year?
—Order!
—Maybe Senator Tambling wants to shout me down; maybe he does not like to hear this.
—Why don't you read what they said this week?
—Order! Senator Tambling!
—It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has been very quick to castigate the Government for the things it has done to the industry in the past but has been slow in putting their own cards on the table.
Even better, NAFI goes on to say:

NAFI met with Dr Hewson and had numerous discussions with Opposition parliamentarians. It is considered most unlikely that they would oppose legislation when it is put forward by the Government in the House.
That is what those in NAFI thought when they talked to those opposite and their Leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the date? Twelve months ago.

—How things have changed. Either NAFI got it wrong or the Opposition has been misleading the industry association—probably the latter, I must say. But there is more. In December last year, North Broken Hill, the company intending to build Wesley Vale, said—
—What date?
—Order! Senator Tambling, I understand that you have already spoken in this debate.
—The company intending to build Wesley Vale said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to express our appreciation at the considerable effort of the Government in achieving significant progress towards ensuring the future of this vitally important industry.
Again, in opposing this legislation—

TALK.START.PARA: —What date?

—I have said, in December last year. If Senator Tambling would stop interjecting and listen to my argument he would perhaps be persuaded, but he has allowed his own prejudice to creep in. Again, in opposing this legislation the Opposition is prepared to forsake the national interest. On 23 December last year, the company intending to invest in a $850m expansion of its Maryvale plant, Australian Paper Manufacturers—another major manufacturer in Australia—said:

SPEECH.PARA: We accept the involvement of the Federal Government in the concept of resource security and will work with the Victorian and Federal governments and the National Association of Forest Industries to reach appropriate guarantees through legislation.
To cap it all, the company, North Broken Hill, wrote to the Government on 25 February this year—and, we believe, wrote also to the Opposition in similar vein—and said:

In relation to the proposed resource security legislation currently before the House, we would urge that this legislation progress as rapidly as possible as it is our opinion that this will provide an immediate signal to potential partners of the willingness of the Federal Government to create the necessary environment to allow the development of this nationally important project.

North Broken Hill has now confirmed that the revised depreciation regime announced by the Government's One Nation package meets its requirements in the case of Wesley Vale—that is, that the company would build a world scale pulp mill now. It says that this Government's depreciation arrangements, as announced in the One Nation package, meet its approval. Yet the Opposition is still opposing the passage of this Bill.

PARA.TAB: I do not ask this question lightly, but it must be asked: is the Opposition trying to marshal a capital strike at the expense of the national interest? I wonder what Ray Groom, the new Tasmanian Premier, feels about having his main election pledge blown out of the water by the Leader of the Opposition. Mr Groom committed himself to building three new pulp mills in Tasmania. Without this legislation, there will be no investment and Premier Groom and the Tasmanian Liberals will not be able to deliver on their election pledge.

Tasmanian Liberal Senators Archer, Calvert, Newman, Walters and Watson, together with Tasmanian Liberal members of parliament, well know that they have to accept a decision so obviously against the interests of their own State—in this case, Tasmania. These members know what is in the interests of Tasmania; indeed, most privately support the legislation. They still have an opportunity to represent their State. They should summon the courage to demand that Dr Hewson allow the legislation to pass through the Senate, which would mean a vote for jobs in Tasmania and a vote for growth in Tasmania. They should stand up for the views of the Tasmanian Liberal Premier who has condemned the Federal Liberals on this issue. What did Ray Groom say? This is what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't mind saying I want the coalition in Canberra to support the legislation.

That is what the Tasmanian Premier said. That is from a State House. Honourable senators here from Tasmania are elected to represent their State; that is the view of their own Premier; why do they not back him?

PARA.TAB: Not only have the Federal Liberals marginalised Tasmanian Liberals, they have also done the same to the coalition of local councils in northern Tasmania. On Monday of this week, the Chairman of `Tasmanians for the Future' wrote to the Opposition pleading with it to minimise its demands on the legislation and support the passage of the Bill through the Senate. Having had that, the Opposition has brought a lot of passion to this debate but, I must say, very little conviction.

The Opposition's revised position can be summarised as these points: firstly, the legislation should allow for State forest industry investment programs which do not meet the $100m eligibility threshold; and secondly, the compensation provisions should be removed from the Bill and wood compensation arrangements provided through inter-governmental agreements.

I would like to reaffirm the Government's position on each of these points. Concerning the first proposed amendment relating to the eligibility of forest industry investment programs, the Government fully appreciates the important role which the sawmilling sector plays in the industry and its concern to have secure access to forest resource. The Commonwealth will provide a legislative level of resource security for the sawmilling sector, provided it can form an enterprise to meet the eligibility criteria clearly specified in clauses 5 and 11 of the Bill.

In addition to the legislation for the sawmilling sector, the Government intends to provide non-legislative resource security for investments which do not meet the $100m threshold. The arrangements to be offered by the Commonwealth through formal Commonwealth-State agreements are similar to the provisions in the legislation in that they include comprehensive, up-front assessment and provisions to accommodate changing circumstances of an exceptional nature.

The type of project the Government envisages which could well use these arrangements is, for example, the hardwood sawmilling industry in the south east forests of New South Wales which at this stage cannot meet the $100m eligibility threshold. In this instance, the Commonwealth would require a number of provisions: that the enterprise must be willing to commit either to value adding investment or to industry restructuring; that the relevant State government must be prepared to offer a longer term, contractually based supply licence for sawlogs to enable the investment to proceed, such as has been the case in Victoria and Western Australia; and, thirdly, that the woodchip export company must have invested or be prepared to invest in other value adding activities in Australia, either in sawmilling enterprises or commercial plantations, and agree that domestic value adding of the woodchips has priority over their use for export.

To the extent that the Commonwealth is involved in export licensing in the region concerned, it will offer a longer term export licence to the year 2000, and thereafter on a case by case basis, on the understanding that if the woodchips are required for domestic use then, subject to market consideration, they should be directed to that end. This should not detract from the Commonwealth's firm desire to achieve maximum domestic processing of woodchips by the year 2000 or soon thereafter.

In relation to compensation, the Government believes that there are adequate provisions in the approaches outlined in the Bill to ensure that, even in the unlikely event of resource withdrawal, adequate resources would remain available for the projects. These provisions are outlined in clause 9 of the Bill, which authorises the Commonwealth to enter into an agreement with a State concerning the provision of resource security for a wood processing project.

The agreements envisaged by the Government will include matters such as surety of wood supply in the event of resource withdrawal. Such agreements are to be legally binding. For instance, the catchment area for a project should be defined to include a margin for the protection of environmental values, and this would be specified in the

SPEECH.PARA: agreement between the Commonwealth and the State.

PARA.TAB: While the Bill explicitly rules out liability by the Commonwealth or a State to pay financial compensation, it does not prevent the provision of structural adjustment assistance, such as the Government has provided in the past in cases involving World Heritage listings of the forests of south-west Tasmania, the north Queensland rainforests and, most recently, in response to the cessation of logging on Fraser Island. Furthermore, there is nothing in the legislation which would preclude a State agreeing to make available alternative resources of equivalent quantity, quality and price in the event of the withdrawal of resources due to unforeseen circumstances.

In conclusion, the combination of the legislated resource security for large projects, including integrated hardwood sawmilling projects and large-scale plantation programs, together with the framework of enhanced intergovernmental agreements for smaller-scale investments in the hardwood sawmilling industry, is an unprecedented package which delivers security and incentive for industry restructuring in an environmentally responsible framework.

For all of those reasons, and based on what I have put in this closing debate to the Senate, the Government firmly believes that the legislation is sound public policy. The Government urges—and I ask the Opposition to hear this—the Opposition to reconsider the amendment and to support this legislation and its passage through this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to keep the Senate long because this measure, as I understand it, is to be voted upon tonight. I wish simply to indicate the way that I will be voting on this subject, and the way that I will be voting on the amendment moved by the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition's amendment has a number of features that recommend it to me. I wonder, though, whether it could not be adequately dealt with in the committee to which this Bill is going to be referred. My problem with it is that it indicates that the Bill should be withdrawn and introduced in an amended form. I do not see any reason to withdraw the Bill since it is going to a committee in any event and, as I understand it, is to be returned to this chamber not later than Thursday of next week. The Bill is here and, in my view, should not be withdrawn; we should persevere with attempts to improve the Bill in that committee and in the Committee of the Whole. Therefore, it is my intention not to vote for the amendment, but to vote for the Bill.

In the final analysis, after all of the considerations are made by the committee, obviously one will have to consider this question in two ways. The first is the way it will impact on the industry generally within Australia. Obviously, one is elected here as an Australian senator to take the view of how legislation is going to impact on the nation as a whole. Secondly, one is also here representing the State from which one is elected, in particular. It has often been said that this is the States House, and it is important in respect of this legislation to recognise that, in the final analysis, my decision will depend on how I assess the impact of this measure on my own State of Tasmania, in particular.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Tambling's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few helpful comments to improve understanding about the industrial relations situation concerning APPM. The position is that the company has notified the unions concerned and all its employees that it has withdrawn unilaterally from all over-award agreements. However, the fact is that it will still provide several of the over-award benefits which had previously been the subject of those agreements, but only to existing employees. It is not proposing that future employees be granted those benefits.

PARA.TAB: I was surprised to hear that APPM was so sensitive that it wanted the question of the conditions to be clarified. The fact is that it has given notice of withdrawal from all agreements. That was the term of the advise—

TALK.START.PARA: —That was never in question. The benefits have been withdrawn.

—It has withdrawn from the agreements. Certain of the benefits under those agreements are to be maintained for some employees. On 3 March the unions concerned and the employees were given very badly worded advice that the company:

SPEECH.PARA: retires from all such agreements and/or arrangements with effect from 2 April 1992.
Please also be advised that site access for union officials will be granted by the company strictly in accordance with the Award effective from 3/3/1992.

The point is that there was no doubt whatsoever that the company had withdrawn from all agreements. It is acknowledged that several of the conditions within those agreements were to continue for existing employees. I hope that this sensitivity to that point is a sign that the company does not intend to act in as much of a Rambo fashion as at first thought. If that is so, if that is a signal, that is good. All I would ask of the company is that it agree to sit down and talk with the unions as the workers' representatives. The unions have been, over some time, acting quite reasonably in discussing work practices and so forth at APPM and elsewhere.

PARA.TAB: When I asked a question during Question Time earlier in the week, I referred to the company as one which was seeking government assistance. That is true. The company was pushing for resource security legislation. I will not transgress by referring to the earlier debate, but that is a fact that I will mention in passing. The company wanted that legislation, it wanted ministerial intervention in relation to its loss of the Telecom phone book paper contract. The company argued that it needed to pull out of these over-award agreements because of its costs and its need to become more efficient. That is not necessarily something that anyone would disagree with. But there is a way of going about that that ought to be more reasonable than the unilateral and confrontationist way in which the company has approached this.

In relation to the Telecom phone book paper contract, I am told that the comparative figures for wages for a person at the Wesley Vale plant is $510 compared to $560 at ANM for the same job. Yet ANM won an increased contract for Telecom paper at APPM's expense. The question of employee costs does not seem to add up.

I hope that this issue at APPM does not develop into a nasty dispute. There is the possibility of that happening. I am pleased that the President of the ACTU, Martin Ferguson, has become personally involved in dealing with this matter. The ACTU is obviously taking seriously what could be a nasty dispute. I believe the unions concerned are acting very responsibly. The Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, has certainly acted appropriately in asking the Industrial Relations Commission to regard the matter as one subject to the public interest in the hope that the employer would agree to sit down and discuss the sorts of things that are on its mind about work practices, costs and so forth. The problem is that, on the face of it, the company is being highly confrontationist about it. It is in the same stable as the Peko-Robe River mine. It was the North Broken Hill Peko company which caused so much trouble several years ago.

I think it is important, for a clear understanding of this dispute, that it be acknowledged that there has been this apparently confrontationist and unilateral withdrawal from agreements which were long established. As I said earlier, several of the conditions are to continue for existing employees. That seems to be out of the goodness of the company's heart, not because it has been subject to the agreement. The company has decided that itself because it does not intend to deal further with the parties to those agreements, being the unions representing the employees.

I believe that the responses of the Government and the union have been reasonable. I hope that the sensitivity to the facts of the situation as exhibited today is a sign that maybe APPM, in its own interests as well as those of its employees, will not press ahead with being confrontationist and unreasonable in its industrial relations stance from now on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like briefly to expand on and clarify some comments I made earlier on the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, entitled Come in Cinderella: the Emergence of Adult and Community Education. I commend the work of the inquiry. I believe that the senators made a very thorough investigation. People working in the area of adult and community education had high expectations of the inquiry, especially as the last review of this kind had been done in 1944. It has been conveyed to me that they were delighted with the report and would like to see it followed up in 1992.

PARA.TAB: Australia has been slow in recognising the value of educational programs which are made available to adults who have returned after long breaks from formal study. In particular, women have benefited from this and represent 75 per cent of the clientele of this educational facility. It is important to the quality of life of adults of all ages to have access to such opportunities. It will benefit the productivity of our nation.

I have been requested to stress the need for a well planned Commonwealth structure that is based on well formulated national policies. This would allow Australia to occupy its rightful place in international forums where previously no united national voice has been possible. This would augment the support already strongly emanating from local, regional and state resources.

Earlier, I mentioned some concerns about the omission from this report of the importance of the adult education program to women. There is a very high level of participation on the part of women, as I have already mentioned, and the benefits gained by women are substantial. Nonetheless, the organisers and administrators in this educational sector are not adequately recompensed for their work and the majority of them are women. The reality is that women in work in the community are still disadvantaged in comparison to men when it comes to fair and reasonable access to learning opportunities in adult life. I conclude by saying that I endorse the enlightened approach to education that this sector offers to the community as a whole, and to women in particular. It recognises the lifelong value of education and its aim of preserving, cultivating and stimulating our growth as human beings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speakers tonight have covered a range of subjects: Senator Boswell on trade; Senator Chamarette on women in the work force—a subject on which this Government has recently made a significant pronouncement; and Senator Coates on the question of APPM.

PARA.TAB: That brings me to the comments I made in my answer earlier in the week to the question from Senator Coates. PARA.TAB: The rest of my answer to Senator Coates on that day essentially goes on to describe the events that were undertaken by me, the role of the Commission and some observations, which still remain true, about the industrial policies of the Opposition. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the wholesale sales tax system distort the price mechanism and the allocationary efficiency of the market by distorting price relativities, which in turn distorts market signals and in turn production decisions and consumer preferences; if not, why not.

(2) Would a single tax rate on all goods and services, rather than four different tax levels on some goods but generally not on services, improve the functioning of the market and increase national production; if not, why not.
(3) Would taxing goods but not services induce a supra-optimal level of production in the services sector and a sub-optimal level of production in the goods sector; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The extent of post-tax changes to consumption and production decisions from hypothetical pre-tax positions depends on the own-price and the cross-price elasticities of demand and supply among all goods and services. This is a complex empirical question. Moreover, whether such effects are seen as distortions is in part a normative issue.

(2) One cannot be certain, because of the complicated empirical and normative issues mentioned in (1), whether a uniform rate of tax on all goods and services would increase national production or improve the operation of the market. A further consideration to be borne in mind is that uniformly taxing all goods and services has not been achieved in any jurisdiction, and the administration costs of such an approach would need to be offset against any possible allocative efficiency gains from more uniform taxation of a broader base. Further, important equity issues have to be weighed in designing any taxation structures.

(3) The existing sales tax can be expected to impact less heavily on services than on the production of those goods directly subject to sales tax, although a significant proportion of goods are exempt from sales tax. While the wholesale sales tax does not directly tax the output of the services sector, the service sector does bear the sales tax on any of its taxable inputs. As shown in Press Release No. P36 of 1 December 1991 by the then Treasurer, the contribution of the sales tax to the costs of service industries is typically of the same order of magnitude as for the goods-producing industries. Whether the resulting pattern of production is considered `supra' or `sub' optimal would depend on the complex empirical and normative issues noted above.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many war widow pensioners have been identified by the Department of Social Security (DSS) as being financially disadvantaged as a result of restrictions on eligibility to some DSS pensions and the freezing of age pension.

(2) What would be the full year cost (in 1990-91 dollars) of ensuring that no war widows were financially disadvantaged by maintaining a war widows pension entitlement as opposed to revoking this entitlement and obtaining benefits exclusively under the Social Security system.

(3) What would be the full year cost (in 1990-91 dollars) of ending the discrimination against war widow pensioners by removing the freeze on age pension available to war widows and restoring it to 1990-91 levels.
(4) What progress has been made on the Government's consideration of options for ameliorating present discrimination against war widows.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) At January 1992 there were some 44,100 war widow pensioners whose rate of Social Security pension was being paid at the rate payable before 1 November 1986. The number of war widow pensioners excluded under the Social Security Act from eligibility for sole parents pension, widowed persons allowance, job search allowance, newstart allowance or sickness allowance is not known.

(2) War widow pensioners with dependent children could, depending upon their private income and place of residence, receive a greater total amount of income support by surrendering their war widows pension and claiming sole parent pension in lieu, since the rate of Social Security guardian allowance ($28.70 per fortnight) exceeds the rate of Veterans' Affairs domestic allowance ($24.00 per fortnight) and sole parent pensioners may qualify for remote area allowance ($14.00 plus $7.00 per child per fortnight). War widows would need to have little or no other income above the Social Security income test free area to benefit from these arrangements. War widow pension is income-test-free. Although no information on numbers in this situation is available, total costs would be relatively small, especially since there are likely to be very few war widows with this combination of circumstances and war widow pensioners are free to seek Social Security payments if it is to their advantage. Most war widows are better off receiving war widow pension.

(3) The estimated additional cost in 1990-91 of removing the ceiling on Social Security pension payments for war widow pensioners would have been some $53m. (This estimate assumes that the amount of war widows pension would have continued to be regarded as assessable income for calculating Social Security entitlements.)
(4) Consideration of issues relating to payment of war widows who receive social security payments will continue in the context of the 1992-93 Budget.

PARA.TAB: (1) SPPs may be either permanently exempted from taking maintenance action or temporarily exempted.
At 31 January 1992, there were 279,340 people receiving SPP. Of these, 42,079 (15.0%) had been granted a permanent or temporary exemption from taking maintenance action.
(2) The categories of exemption and the proportion of the total SPP population were:
30,143 (10.8%) were permanently exempt. Of this group the reasons for exemption were:
where clients fear that, if they take action for maintenance, the non-custodial parent will react violently toward them or their family—4,318 cases (1.5%);
where clients do not know the identity of the father—6,594 cases (2.4%);

where circumstances exist where it would be a harmful or unreasonable imposition to expect clients to seek maintenance, for example, where the child was born as a result of rape or where extreme emotional trauma would be involved—5,604 cases (2.0%);
where a non-custodial parent is deceased—6,942 cases (2.5%);
where the non-custodial parent is overseas or in gaol—5,446 cases (1.9%); and

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Veterans' Affairs: British Commonwealth Occupational Forces

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 27 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: Are members of the British Commonwealth Occupational Forces recognised as returned service personnel for the purposes of veterans' entitlements; if not, why not?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Entitlements for members of the BCOF are dependent on the date and circumstances of their enlistment.

(a) Enlistment in the Australian Imperial Forces (AIF) continued after the date of the Japanese surrender (16 August 1945) until 1 July 1947. After that date a special force known as the Interim Force was raised, specifically for the purpose of serving as occupational forces in Japan.
(b) All members of the AIF and Interim Forces are veterans and eligible for certain benefits, including disability pension, under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA).

(c) Members who served with the BCOF are not eligible for service pension in respect of that service alone. Service with BCOF at the end of World War II was not service during a period of hostilities (defined as being 3 September 1939 to 29 October 1945 (inclusive)), in which danger from hostile forces of the enemy was incurred. Nor was it service in an operational area as required for eligible service after World War II.

(d) Persons who enlisted in the permanent Australia Defence Forces after 1 July 1947 are not eligible for benefits in respect of their service in the BCOF. They were eligible for benefits under the Compensation (Commonwealth Employees) Act, and, in some cases, might still be able to claim under the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act.
